description:
People create libraries in all shapes and sizes to serve their local communities. This set of free to use images represents buildings in almost all 50 states of the United States.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.
content.meta_description: People create libraries in all shapes and sizes to serve their local communities. This set of free to use images represents buildings in almost all 50 states of the United States.

items.title: For greater knowledge, on more subjects, use your library more often. Illinois WPA Arts Project, 1936-1941. Prints & Photographs Division
Noyes Library for Young Children. Kensington, Maryland. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith,  2011. Prints & Photographs Division
Bethune-Cookman College. Students in the library reading room, Daytona Beach, Florida. Gordon Parks, 1943. Prints & Photographs Division
Public library in Antonito,  Colorado, near the New Mexico border. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2015. Prints & Photographs Division
Library and Innovation Center in New Castle, Delaware, defines itself as "a community learning and resource hub." Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2018. Prints & Photographs Division
Silence. Lithograph by Mabel Dwight, 1939. Prints & Photographs Division
Patterson Park Branch of the Enoch Pratt Free Library System. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2011. Prints & Photographs Division
The easily identifiable J. Erik Jonsson Central Library, Dallas, Texas. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2014. Prints & Photographs Division
Public library in the southwestern section of Mississippi, in the piney woods. Photo by Dorothea Lange, 1937. Prints & Photographs Division
"Bookmobile" bus belonging to the Perry County Public Library in Hazard, Kentucky. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2020. Prints & Photographs Division

Creating the first fully developed children's department in 1899 is one of the historic milestones claimed by the Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Carnegie Library. Photo, 1900-1905. Prints & Photographs Division

Even a sculpted gila monster appears to be into reading near a Little Free Library in the Dunbar Spring neighborhood of Tucson, Arizona. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2018. Prints & Photographs Division
Handley Library, Winchester, Virginia. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2011. Prints & Photographs Division
Reading room for the blind, Library of Congress, Washington, DC. By National Photo Co., 1919 or 1920. Prints & Photographs Division
Main public library building, Detroit, Michigan. Cass Gilbert, architect. Postcard by Albertype Co., 1921-1930. Prints & Photographs Division
Mother Marianne Library, Moloka'i Island, Kalaupapa, Kalawao County, Hawaii. Photo by Jack Boucher, 1991. Historic American Buildings Survey. Prints & Photographs Division
Curb service, 10,000 current books, convenient, free, time saving : Chicago Public Library, Randolph St. corridor. Illinois WPA Art Project, 1936-1941. Prints & Photographs Division
Reading Room, Billings Memorial Library, University of Vermont, Burlington, Vermont. H.H. Richardson, architect. Photo, approx. 1890. Prints & Photographs Division
Library. Herbert Hoover Federal Building in Washington, D.C. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2018. Prints & Photographs Division
Paola Free Library, Paola, Kansas. Photo by Dan Collins, 1984. Historic American Buildings Survey. Prints & Photographs Division
The Guernsey Branch Library, in Guernsey, Wyoming. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2015. Prints & Photographs Division
Library of Congress when it was located in the U.S. Capitol. Copy of watercolor by William Bengough, 1897. Prints & Photographs Division
Library of Congress, Washington. By Detroit Publishing Co., 1902. Prints & Photographs Division
Hubbard Free Library, Hallowell, Kennebec County, Maine. Copy of photo from approx. 1880. Historic American Buildings Survey. Prints & Photographs Division
Modernist stairway and bookstacks inside the Allen County Public Library, Fort Wayne, Indiana. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2016. Prints & Photographs Division
Cossitt Library, Memphis, Tennessee. Photo by Detroit Publishing Co., 1906. Prints & Photographs Division
Main entrance. Boston Public Library. Massachusetts. 1895. Prints & Photographs Division

Interior view of library reading room with male and female students sitting at tables, reading, at the Tuskegee Institute, Alabama. Photo by Frances B. Johnston, approx. 1902. Prints & Photographs Division
George Peabody Library, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Maryland. Photo by Carol M.  Highsmith, 2012. Prints & Photographs Division
Map of Libraries, Washington, D.C. Library of Congress, 1926. Geography & Map Division
"Open Free to All" is carved over the door of the Carnegie Public Library in Taunton, Massachusetts. Drawing by Albert R. Ross, approx. 1903. Prints & Photographs Division
Paxton Carnegie Library, Paxton, Illinois. Drawing, 2011. Historic American Buildings Survey. Prints & Photographs Division
Carnegie Library, Guthrie, Oklahoma. Cross section drawing, 1973. Historic American Buildings Survey. Prints & Photographs Division
Carnegie Free Library, Union, South Carolina. Photo by Jack Boucher, 1987. Historic American Buildings Survey. Prints & Photographs Division
Princeton University, Library, Princeton, New Jersey. Photo by Jack Boucher, 1964. Historic American Buildings Survey. Prints & Photographs Division
Public library in Shepherdstown, West Virginia. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2015. Prints & Photographs Division
Redwood Library, Newport, Rhode Island. Photo by Cervin Robinson, 1970. Historic American Buildings Survey. Prints & Photographs Division
Cook Memorial Library, the public library of Tamworth, New Hampshire. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2017. Prints & Photographs Division
Little Rock Public Library, Little Rock, Arkansas. Photo by Detroit Publishing Co., approx. 1910. Prints & Photographs Division
Public Library, Salt Lake City, Utah. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2007. Prints & Photographs Division
Riggs Library, Georgetown University, Washington, DC. Historic American Buildings Survey. 1969. Prints & Photographs Division
The People's Library, set up by the Occupy Wall Street protest movement in Zuccotti Park, New York City. Photo by Teri Sierra, 2011. Prints & Photographs Division
Newspaper reading room of public library. Omaha, Nebraska. Photo by John Vachon, 1938. Prints & Photographs Division
Dusk view, Rawlings Public Library, Pueblo, Colorado. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2015. Prints & Photographs Division
Library tent at the Farm Security Administration mobile camp for migratory farm workers, Odell, Oregon. Photo by Russell Lee, 1941. Prints & Photographs Division
Parmly Billings Library (Western Heritage Center), Billings, Montana. Photo by John Margolies, 2004. Prints & Photographs Division
Juneau Public Library, Juneau, Alaska. Photo by Jet Lowe, 1991. Historic American Buildings Survey. Prints & Photographs Division
Historic library in the North Carolina Capitol in Raleigh. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2017. Prints & Photographs Division
An upright polar bear in Cincinnati, Ohio, not at the zoo, since it's stuffed, but at Cincinnati's main library. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2016. Prints & Photographs Division
Carnegie Library, Sheldon, Iowa. 1909. Prints & Photographs Division
Buffalo, New York, Public library. Children's room. Photo by Levin C. Handy, approx. 1900. Prints & Photographs Division
Tower of the Central Library, Los Angeles, California. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2013. Prints & Photographs Division
Library, Dickason Street, Columbus, Wisconsin. Photo by John Margolies, 2008. Prints & Photographs Division
Norfolk Library, Norfolk, Connecticut. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2011. Prints & Photographs Division
Carnegie Library, Cordele, Georgia. Photo, approx. 1916. Prints & Photographs Division
Nampa Public Library, Nampa, Idaho. Photo by John Margolies, 2004. Prints & Photographs Division
Louisiana Industrial Institute and College Library with students reading, Ruston, Louisiana. Photo, 1900-1920. Prints & Photographs Division
The public library, with a creative book-themed facade, in Houston, Minnesota. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2019. Prints & Photographs Division
Book room, Carnegie library, St. Joseph, Missouri. Photo, 1900-1905. Prints & Photographs Division
You wouldn't guess that this is a public library, but it is, in Skynomish, Washington. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2018. Prints & Photographs Division

Library (C425), looking SW - Hawthorne Naval Ammunition Depot, Babbitt Housing Area, Hawthorne, Nevada. Photo by Joe C. Freeman, 1992. Historic American Buildings Survey. Prints & Photographs Division
Interior of the Hutzler Reading room located in Gilman Hall, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Maryland. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2012. Prints & Photographs Division

content.title: Free to Use and Reuse: Libraries

description: Free to Use and Reuse Archive

This set of images for American lighthouses primarily from the 1800s and 1900s can help you pick out landmarks that you'd like to learn more about. Lighthouses can tell many storiesâthe lives of their keepers, the engineering feats involved in their construction, and their roles in rescues and preventing disasters. All pictures are from the Prints & Photographs Division unless otherwise credited.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: Color photo shows a white tower and black lantern attached to a low building with a red roof and surrounded by green grass.
items.title: Heceta Head Lighthouse, Pacific Ocean, Oregon

items.alt: Color photo shows a  very tall tower with spiral bands in black and white. The base is red and surrounded by green grass.
items.title: Cape Hatteras Lighthouse, Outer Banks, North Carolina

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows details of the lighting mechanism inside the glass lens.
items.title: Bodie Island Lighthouse, Outer Banks, North Carolina. Lamp inside the lens

items.alt: Color photo shows a red-painted square tower at the end of a pier.
items.title: Holland Harbor Light,  Lake Michigan, Michigan. Also known as Big Red

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows a  white-painted tower on the beach. It is leaning over about seven degrees.
items.title: Cape St. George Light, Gulf of Mexico, Florida

items.alt: Map with a brown background for both land and water has a red starburst atop a vertical black bar to show lighthouse locations along the Atlantic Ocean coastline. The names of the lighthouses as well as cities, rivers, islands, and  bays, are printed in black.
items.title: A chart exhibiting the light houses and light vessels on the coast of the United States of America : from Maine to Virginia inclusive, 1848. Geography & Map Division

items.alt: Map with a brown tone for land and beige for the lakes has red symbols to show lighthouse locations. The names of the lakes, rivers, islands, bays, and channels are printed in black.
items.title: A chart exhibiting the lighthouses of the lake coast of the United States of America. Great Lakes, 1848. Geography & Map Division

items.alt: Black-and-white architectural drawing shows two elevations of a tall tower with windows and a black-and-white diamond pattern.
items.title: Cape Lookout Lighthouse, Outer Banks, North Carolina

items.alt: Color photo shows from a distance a white tower on a rocky shoreline with red-roof buildings nearby.
items.title: Portland Head Light, Casco Bay, Maine

items.alt: Color photo shows a tower with bands of red and white and a black lantern at the top.
items.title: West Quoddy Head Lighthouse, Lubec, Maine

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows a tower with bands of black and white standing behind the keeper's house. A small boy is in the foreground
items.title: Fire Island Lighthouse, Atlantic Ocean, New York

items.alt: Color photo shows a  tower with white on the bottom and red on the top, at the shore's edge.
items.title: Barnegat Lighthouse, Atlantic Ocean, New Jersey

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows an octagonal tower with windows standing next to a keeper's house.
items.title: Lynde Point Lighthouse, Long Island Sound, Connecticut

items.alt: Color photo shows a short tower, painted white, with houses in the background.
items.title: Biloxi Light, Gulf of Mexico, Mississippi

items.alt: Black-and-white architectural drawing shows two vertical sections through the three-story keeper's house that surrounds the tower with a lantern on top.
items.title: Old Point Loma Lighthouse, San Diego Bay, California

items.alt: Black-and-white architectural drawing shows the exterior and interior of a tower with seven small plans for comparison to other lighthouses.
items.title: Minot's Ledge Light, Cohasset Harbor, Massachusetts

items.alt: Color photo shows a short white tower placed on a rocky point with a covered walkway to the keeper's house.
items.title: Isles of Shoals Light, Atlantic Ocean, New Hampshire

items.alt: Black-and-white architectural drawing shows the tower and several details of the entrance door.
items.title: Erie Land Light,  Lake Erie, Pennsylvania. Also known as Old Presque Isle Light

items.alt: Color photo shows a white tower with a black lantern, adjacent to a two-story keeper's house. Snow covers the ground.
items.title: Point Iroquois Lighthouse, Lake Superior, Michigan

items.alt: Color photo shows, at night, a short white tower above a house at the shoreline.
items.title: Rose Island Lighthouse, Narragansett Bay, Rhode Island

items.alt: Black-and-white architectural drawing shows a vertical section through the tower and the two-story keeper's house. The circular staircase is prominent in the tower.
items.title: Au Sable Light Station, Lake Superior, Michigan

items.alt: Color photo shows a short, square, white tower above a  large two-story house behind a fence and flower border.
items.title: Point Fermin Light, San Pedro Bay, California

items.alt: Color photo looks up the spiral staircase and shows the perforated, red-painted treads.
items.title: Spiral staircase at Thirty Mile Point Light, Lake Ontario, New York

items.alt: A brown-toned pair of photos shows a short, pyramid-shaped  lighthouse with windows and a lantern. Buoys in different shapes and sizes are on the ground.
items.title: Light house and buoys, on display at the International Exhibition, Philadelphia, 1876

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows three men in a boat in the foreground with the short, square-tower lighthouse on a reef in the distance.
items.title: Stepping Stones Light, Long Island Sound, New York

items.alt: Book illustration shows a skeletal tower on a platform anchored in the water offshore. Includes a keeper's house and a lantern at the top.
items.title: Fowey Rocks Light, Key Biscayne, Florida

items.alt: Aerial color photo shows a cylindrical white tower and the keeper's house on a small rocky island
items.title: Cape Neddick Light, Nubble Island, Maine

items.alt: Color photo shows a short white tower with black lantern in a harbor setting.
items.title: Edgartown Harbor Light, Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts

items.alt: Color photo shows two towers. The older lighthouse is brick with a green lantern. The newer tower has vertical bands in black and white.
items.title: Cape Henry lighthouses, Virginia Beach, Virginia

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows a spark-plug shaped, short tower with dark and light bands and surrounded by water.
items.title: Robbins Reef Light, Bayonne, New Jersey

items.alt: Color photo shows a hexagonal-shaped building on a screw pile surrounded by water with a motor boat underneath.
items.title: Middle Bay Light,  Mobile Bay, Alabama

items.alt: Color print shows a full rigged sailing ship moving across ocean waves. The lighthouse is on shore in the background with a schooner on the left and a sloop on the right
items.title: "Outward Bound," 1886

items.alt: Color print shows a lighthouse at night with its bright light shining in a stormy sea and a sailing ship in the background.
items.title: "The Lighthouse by the Sea," Sheet music cover, 1886. Music Division

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows a small lighthouse at the base of a suspension bridge tower.
items.title: Little Red Lighthouse, under the George Washington Bridge, New York City

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows a bell with a clapper suspended from a wooden beam with water in the background.
items.title: Fort Point Light Station, Penobscot Bay, Maine. Fog bell

items.alt: Color photo shows a skeletal black tower with a central cylinder and a lantern with weather vane. Tall grass is at the base and white painted buildings in the background.
items.title: Mona Island Light, Puerto Rico

items.alt: Black-and-white architectural drawing shows the service floor level and the lantern and weather vane at the top of the light.
items.title: Devils Island Light, Lake Superior, Wisconsin

items.alt: Color photo shows the white lantern above a red-painted band on a spark plug style lighthouse. Displayed on land.
items.title: Sabine Bank Light, Gulf of Mexico, Texas. Lantern, on display in a museum park

items.alt: Color photo shows a pier in the foreground with a red-roofed house and short tower in the background, surrounded on two sides by blue water.
items.title: The Mukilteo Light, Possession Sound, Washington

items.alt: Color photo shows a white octagonal tower and mountains in the distance with flat brown turf in the foreground.
items.title: Moloka'i Light, Hawaii

items.alt: Color photo shows the glass lens and glass windows in the lantern with two foghorns atop the building below and the blue lake water beyond.
items.title: Split Rock Lighthouse, Lake Superior, Minnesota. Fresnel lens in lantern

items.alt: Color photo shows a short, octagonal lighthouse, made of beige bricks with a black lantern, adjacent to a building with two foghorns in the foreground.
items.title: Split Rock Lighthouse, Lake Superior, Minnesota

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows a short, octagonal lighthouse that stands next to another tower with a large steamboat going by and the city across the body of water.
items.title: "Harbor Entrance and Lights, Buffalo, N.Y."

items.alt: Color photo shows a white-painted tower with small red-roofed buildings and palm trees nearby and blue ocean water in the distance.
items.title: Point Vicente Light, Rancho Palos Verdes, California

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows in the distance a square tower and lantern located on the mainland and attached to a low building, with water in the foreground.
items.title: Tree Point Light, Revillagigedo Channel, Alaska

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows a man looking closely at the lens of a lighthouse.
items.title: Frank Schubert polishes the station's lens once a week

items.alt: Color photo shows a tower with bands of red and white. Several boats are moored in the harbor in front of the tower, which is reflected in the water.
items.title: Harbour Town Lighthouse, Hilton Head, South Carolina

items.alt: Color photo shows the top of a  miniature white tower with a blue base and lantern. A green turf putting area is in the foreground.
items.title: Lighthouse, Lackland Road Putt-Putt miniature golf course, Fort Worth, Texas

items.alt: Color photo shows a  small white tower with bands of black and white at a miniature golf course.
items.title: Lighthouse, Mulligan's miniature Golf and Games, Ogden, Utah

items.alt: Color photo shows a small tower with walls made from stones and a short lantern on top. Stands in a pond of green water.
items.title: A decorative lighthouse, Falls Park pond, Pendleton, Indiana

options.searchIn: partof:library of congress free to use and reuse

description:
Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) continues to inspire people throughout the world through his words and life.

Learn more about these highlights from the Library's collections on Abraham Lincoln.

Browse more content that is free to use and reuse.

items.title: Antietam, Md. Allan Pinkerton, President Lincoln, and Maj. Gen. John A. McClernand
Abraham Lincoln, [November 1863] (Gettysburg Address: Nicolay Copy)
Abraham Lincoln, seated and holding a book, with his son Tad (Thomas) leaning on a table
Abraham Lincoln, Tuesday, July 22, 1862 (Preliminary Draft of Emancipation Proclamation)
A Bill to Abolish Slavery in the District of Columbia
President Lincoln's second inauguration, March 1865
Abraham Lincoln, three-quarter length portrait, seated and holding his spectacles and a pencil
Abraham Lincoln, head-and-shoulders portrait, called "last photograph of Lincoln from life"
President Abraham Lincoln, seated, with his left hand on his face
Abraham Lincoln, [March 1861] (First Inaugural Address, Final Version)
Second Inaugural Address; endorsed by Lincoln, April 10, 1865
The inauguration of Abraham Lincoln, 1865
Lincoln's second inaugural

description:
Large and small, printed and handwritten—all kinds of signs advertise food. The shape of a building, a display of cans, and the smile of a street vendor also encourage food choices. description:
Balloons, gliders, blimps, dirigibles, airplanes, fighter jets, helicopters, and space shuttlesâall these aircraft make it possible for people to fly. Learn more about this rich area of the Library of Congress collections in the online bookÂ Aeronautical and Astronautical Resources of the Library of Congress: a Comprehensive Guide. (Washington, DC: Library of Congress, 2007.)Â Unless otherwise noted, the selected images are all from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

description:
The maps selected for this set represent cities, battles, and symbols involved in the founding of the United States. For more maps from the Revolutionary War period, see the digital collection "American Revolution and Its Era: Maps and Charts of North America and the West Indies, 1750 to 1789."

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.title: 1752. Pre-Revolutionary view of the Statehouse in Philadelphia, which became Independence Hall. Engraved map. Geography & Map Division
1791. Known as âThe LâEnfant Plan,â this map serves as the blueprint for where the United States government would be permanently situated. Manuscript map. Geography & Map Division
1833. Eagle map of the United States created for âRudiments of National Knowledge.â Engraved map. Geography & Map Division
1870. Boston on Independence morning. Panoramic map. Geography & Map Division
1775. Boston during the Revolutionary War showing the location of His Majestyâs army and the rebels. Published in London in 1776. Engraved map. Geography & Map Division
1775. Boston with the entrenchments of His Majestyâs forces during the Revolutionary War. Published in London in 1777. Engraved map. Geography & Map Division
1775. Boston environs and Boston Harbor map showing rebel troop movements during the Revolutionary War. Geography & Map Division
1776. Rough draft of Boston and Boston Harbor. Manuscript map. Geography & Map Division
1777-1778. Defenses in Philadelphia during the Revolutionary War. Depicting the siege of Mud Island on the River Delaware. Manuscript map. Geography & Map Division
1777. Philadelphia on the border of the state of Delaware during the Revolution. Manuscript map. Geography & Map Division
1777. Philadelphia showing the names of land owners and the boundaries of their properties. Engraved map. Geography & Map Division
1777. Battle of Brandywine, Pennsylvania, during the Revolutionary War. Unfinished watercolor sketch map. Geography & Map Division

1778. Line of defense and troops between the Schuylkill and Delaware Rivers north of the city, and other fortifications. Also shows names of suburban land owners. Manuscript map. Geography & Map Division
1781. Military actions resulting in the American victory at Yorktown, Virginia. Drawn by the aide-de-camp to the Marquis de Lafayette. Manuscript map. Geography & Map Division
1794. Washington, D.C., in its infancy. Among the earliest printed maps of the United States capital city. Geography & Map Division
1800. The "x" on a pre-1790 map captures the boundaries and owners of land that would become the Library of Congress in 1800. Geography & Map Division

description:
Selected images represent the historical experiences and achievements of Arab Americans, primarily during the early 1900s when many people immigrated from Lebanon and the region known as Syria. A formal celebration of Arab American heritage occurs each year in the United States in April. Unless otherwise noted, the images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: A sculpted bust of Kahlil Gibran rests atop a fountain in a parklike setting.
items.title: Kahlil Gibran, a Lebanese American poet and author. Memorial in Washington, D.C. Photo by Carol Highsmith, around 2000.

items.alt: Elderly woman plays the piano in her living room and sings from a piece of sheet music.
items.title: Josephine Wehby Sharbel playing and singing the Lebanese national anthem. Photo by Brenda McCallum, 1982. Source: American Folklife Center, Ethnic Heritage and Language Schools in America Project collection

items.alt: A group of 32 children sits or stands for a group portrait outdoors. An adult stands on the right side. One person holds a U.S. flag above the group.
items.title: Arabic class at St. Elias Maronite Catholic Church in Birmingham, Alabama, taught by Khattar Wehby, around 1915. Source: American Folklife Center, Ethnic Heritage and Language Schools in America Project collection

items.alt: Four books in Arabic and English are displayed on a desk, including the "Abcarius' Abridged English and Arabic Dictionary."
items.title: Early Arabic language books used at St. Elias school by Josephine Sharbel's father, Khattar Wehby, in Birmingham, Alabama, around 1915. Source: American Folklife Center, Ethnic Heritage and Language Schools in America Project collection

items.alt: Front view of the museum with a turquoise color wall mosaic bearing the museum name.
items.title: The Arab American National Museum in Dearborn, Michigan. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2019.

items.alt: Donna Shalala sits in her office and smiles at the camera. She is wearing an olive-green suit with dark trim.
items.title: Donna Shalala, Lebanese American and Secretary of Health and Human Services. Photo by Michael Geissinger, 1998.

items.alt: Four boys sit on a sidewalk playing a game. A girl looks on with two young children in a carriage.
items.title: Children of immigrants from Greater Syria playing a game on a sidewalk in New York City. Photo by Bain News Service, around 1915.

items.alt: Two women stand on a city sidewalk by the steps of a building while a child watches from the doorway. Both women are wearing long dresses and headscarves.
items.title: Women chatting in New York Cityâs Syrian neighborhood. Photo by Bain News Service, 1916.

items.alt: Boy stands with his hands on his waist and smiles. He is wearing a cap and a jacket with large buttons.
items.title: 12 year old Joe Hajjar, of Syrian descent, in Boston. Red Cross photo, 1920

items.alt: Ralph Nader looks at the camera and gestures while speaking. He is wearing a dark suit with a long tie.
items.title: Ralph Nader, a Lebanese-American and consumer advocate. Photo by Thomas O'Halloran, 1975.

items.alt: Page of text laid out in three columns: name, enlistment date, and how left the army. Badeen enlisted on January 1, 1776, and died on May 23, 1776.
items.title: Revolutionary War muster roll for the Continental Army lists Private Nathan Badeen, a Syrian immigrant. In "History of Colonel Edmund Phinney's Eighteenth Continental Regiment ...," 1898,  p. 60. Source: General Collections

items.alt: A row of newspaper photos shows each  brother, ages 29 to 18. Wearing military  or civilian clothing.
items.title: âFive Haddad Brothers on Various Fighting Fronts.â Syrian American family featured in the Waterbury Democrat newspaper, May 24, 1945, during World War II. Source: Chronicling America.

items.alt: A young woman looks at the camera while  resting her chin on her hands and wearing a dress with a full skirt and off-the-shoulder sleeves.
items.title: Zaida Ben Yusuf, an Algerian-German-American photographer. Self-portrait, 1901.

items.alt: Cover image includes text in Arabic and English.
items.title: Afifa Karam, a Lebanese American author, published "The New World: A Ladies Monthly Arabic Magazine," 1912.

items.alt: The round label of a black 78rpm record with a the Victor logo and name.
items.title: Alexander Maloof, a Lebanese American composer and producer published âA Trip to Syriaâ in 1913. Source: National Jukebox

items.alt: Marie El-Khoury sits for a portrait, looking to the left of the camera. She is wearing a white top with a round brooch.
items.title: Marie El-Khoury, a Syrian American and jewelry designer. Photo by Arnold Genthe, 1921.

items.alt: The wood dining table has six chairs. Many wooden decorations are displayed on the table and kitchen counters with photos and other pictures on the walls.
items.title: Sam Maloof, a Lebanese American furniture designer, created the dining room pieces for his home in Rancho Cucamonga, California. Photo by Tavo Olmos, 1999.

items.alt: Girl is walking across a dirt lot towards a fence on which several men are sitting. Her hair is braided, and she is wearing a dress.
items.title: Eight year old Syrian girl, Phoebe Thomas, going to work at 6 a.m., August 14, with great butcher knife, to cut sardines in Seacoast Canning Co. Factory #4, Eastport Me. Photo by Lewis Hine, 1911.

items.alt: A man behind the counter of a restaurant hands a plate of food to a man on the other side of the counter.
items.title: A restaurant in New York Cityâs Syrian neighborhood. Photo by Bain News Service, 1916.

items.alt: Three men stand at the pushcart. Two are wearing aprons, and two are wearing hats. A horse in a harness stands nearby.
items.title: Syrian food seller with a pushcart on New York City street. Photo by Bain News Service, 1916.

items.alt: Paul Anka sings while holding a microphone. He is wearing a tuxedo with a multicolored pocket square.
items.title: Paul Anka, a Canadian American of Lebanese and Syrian descent. Photo by Bernard Gotfryd, 1960s

items.alt: The cover of a book by Ameen Rihani, translator of âThe Quatrains of Abuâl-Ala,â shows an image of a person operating a printing press. Below it are the words âArti et Veritati.â
items.title: Ameen Rihani, a Lebanese American and writer, published Myrtle and Myrrh in 1905. Source: General Collections

items.alt: The front of a white clapboard church with a cross on the roof and two stained-glass windows.
items.title: Our Lady of Mercy Syrian Roman Catholic church in Shenandoah, Pennsylvania. Photo by Dick Sheldon, around 1938.

items.alt: Sculpture above a doorway shows an armored knight on a horse plunging a spear into the mouth of a dragon on the ground.
items.title: Relief sculpture of St. George slaying a dragon at St. George's Syrian Catholic Church, New York City. Photo by Angelo Rizzuto, 1953

items.alt: The cover of a book by Abraham Mitrie Rihbany features an illustration of two men digging next to a tree.
items.title: Abraham Mitrie Rihbany, a Lebanese American, theologian, and historian, published "The Hidden Treasure" in 1920. General Collections

description:
Books are deceivingly complicated objects. From cover to cover, the design of a book reflects the prevailing desires and demands of a particular time and place. To provide a rich overview of the Art of the Book, the following selections are examples of illustration, binding, and typography from a variety of locations and historical moments. Some are manuscripts (hand drawn and illustrated books) while others are printed. All represent a complex, often global, network of artists, craftspeople, and book lovers. Unless otherwise noted, the selected images are all from the Rare Book and Special Collections Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

description:
This set of copyright free pictures features activities and scenery from late September through early November. You'll see images related to Halloween and DÃ­a de Muertos, the harvesting of crops and leaves changing colors across the United States, and other portrayals of the autumn season from the 1870s to the present day. The selected items are from the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, unless otherwise noted.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.title: October's bright blue weather. A good time to read! Poster by Albert M. Bender. Chicago: Illinois WPA Art Project, [between 1936 and 1940].

Children gathering potatoes on a large farm, vicinity of Caribou, Aroostook County, Maine. Schools do not open until the potatoes are harvested. Photo by Jack Delano, Oct. 1940.

description:
How do you like to celebrate your own birthday or the anniversary of an organization? You can find inspiration here. Cakes and candles turn up most often. You'll also find gift ideas, festive parties, music, and fireworks. Unless otherwise noted, the selected images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

description: Each spring, festive celebrations welcome the arrival of cherry blossoms in Japan, while in Washington, DC, more than one and a half million people attend the National Cherry Blossom Festival. The Library has published a book about this annual tradition with original art works from the collections, Cherry Blossoms: Sakura Collections from the Library of Congress. Browse more content that is free to use and reuse.

items.title: Cherry Blossoms around the Tidal Basin in Washington, DC. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2006 or 2007
Jefferson Memorial with Cherry Blossoms, Washington, DC. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2006 or 2007

Cherry trees along the Tidal Basin with Japanese Lantern placed in the park in 1954. Washington, DC. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2006 or 2007
Japanese lantern on the Potomac River Tidal Basin during spring cherry blossom season, Washington, DC. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, ca. 1990

ASomei Yoshino. Watercolor drawing by KÅkichi Tsunoi, 1921. The gift of trees to Washington in 1912 included 1,800 trees of this variety.

Kwan-zan (Barrier Mountain) cherry blossom. Watercolor drawing by KÅkichi Tsunoi, 1921. Kwan-zan was one of only three varieties of cherry blossom trees to survive after frequent floods around the Tidal Basin in the 1930s.
Ariake (Daybreak) cherry blossom. Watercolor drawing by KÅkichi Tsunoi, 1921. The gift of trees to Washington in 1912 included 100 trees of this variety.
Shirayuki (White Snow) cherry blossom. Watercolor drawing by KÅkichi Tsunoi, 1921. The gift of trees to Washington in 1912 included 130 trees of this variety
Fukurokuju (God of Longevity) cherry blossom. Watercolor drawing by KÅkichi Tsunoi, 1921. The gift of trees to Washington in 1912 included 50 trees of this variety

[Hanging poems on a cherry tree]. Color woodblock print by Toyonobu Ishikawa, 1741, printed later

description:
The colorful pictures in this set can add delight to any day or help us visualize historical data. Ranging from the 1500s to the present day, these images make their mark through a single tint or a rainbow palette. Unless otherwise noted, the images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: African American woman with a red kerchief head cover holds her drill against a shiny area of the plane that reflects her image.
items.title: Woman working with a hand drill on a "Vengeance" dive bomber, Nashville, Tennessee. Color transparency photo by Alfred Palmer, 1943.

items.alt: Multi-color painted horses on a carousel.
items.title: Carousel, Asbury Park, New Jersey. Color slide photo by John Margolies, 1978.

items.alt: View looking up at the domed ceiling made of alternating blue, red, and yellow glass pieces.
items.title: Stained glass ceiling, Old State Capitol, Baton Rouge, Louisiana. Digital photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2021.

items.alt: View from inside a sea cavern looking across the flat blue water and arched cave walls towards the light-filled entrance.
items.title: Blue Grotto, Capri Island, Italy.  Photochrom print by Photoglob Zurich around 1890.

items.alt: Display includes a bright pink robe, green and white vest, and orange cloth in front of a red patterned rug.
items.title: Clothing display, Russian Empire. Color photo by Sergeii M. Prokudin-Gorskii, around 1910.

items.alt: Three-wheel, open front orange car with three red seats inside it.
items.title: Small taxi, Havana, Cuba. Digital photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2010.

items.alt: The Emir is seated, facing the camera. He wears a bright blue robe and holds a sword
items.title: Emir of Bukhara. Color photo by Sergeii M. Prokudin-Gorskii, 1911.

items.alt: Green garden scene with clusters of small blue and purple flowers in the middle
items.title: Woodland pathway.  Hand-colored lantern slide by Frances B. Johnston, around 1920.

items.alt: On a bright yellow background, the top border has red downward triangles ornamented with gold fringe and blue tassels. The lower border has star and palm ornaments, also in red.
items.title: Wallpaper sample. Designed by Virchaux & Co., 1815.

items.alt: The lower arcs of two rainbows appear side-by-side against a dark sky. A series of mural paintings cover the levee wall.
items.title: Double rainbow appears over the levee along the Arkansas River in Pueblo, Colorado. Digital photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2015.

items.alt: A yellow logo for the club and a book with the words "At Your Local Public Library" on its cover appear against a blue background with scattered white dots.
items.title: Vacation Reading Club. WPA poster, 1936-1939.

items.alt: Close up view of the toes and surrounding robe in green copper sheathing.
items.title: Left foot of the Statue of Liberty, New York City. Photo by Jet Lowe, 1984.

items.alt: Standing figure of a bearded man wearing a full-length robe and carrying a book in his left hand.
items.title: Apostle with a book. Red ink chiaroscuro woodcut by Domenico Beccafumi, around the 1540s.

items.alt: Interior view across the conversation pit lined with red pillows looking towards a floor to ceiling window.
items.title: Living area, Miller house, Columbus, Indiana. Color transparency photo by Balthazar Korab, around 1957.

items.alt: Silhouette of the silver arch appears tinged with pink against a deep blue sky.
items.title: Saint Louis Gateway Arch, Saint Louis, Missouri. Color slide photo by Balthazar Korab, around 1965.

items.alt: Wall is painted pink with bands of red at top and bottom. In yellow, two archways reach half-way up the wall separated by yellow columns decorated with gold-dotted semicircles.
items.title: Wall design for unidentified restaurant, New York City. Tempera drawing by Winold Reiss, around 1944.

items.alt: Yellow chick emerging from egg shell surrounded by pink flowers and greenery.
items.title: An Easter offering. Chromolithograph by Obpacher Bros., 1884.

items.alt: Bright blue, rectangular pool stretches from the viewer towards a pergola in the distance. Surrounded by purple flowers, stone urns, columns, and statues.
items.title: Blue Garden at Beacon Hill House, Newport, Rhode Island. Hand-colored lantern slide by Frances B. Johnston, 1914.

items.alt: Three young women dressed in red, purple, blue, and brown patterned clothing stand in front of a wooden building holding plates of colored berries.
items.title: Peasant girls, Russia.  Color photo by Sergeii M. Prokudin-Gorskii, 1909.

items.alt: Slices of cherry pie fill the river that men in a boat are trying to row across. Washington and an American flag are prominent in the middle of the boat.
items.title: Lloyd J. Harriss: Pies. Chromolithograph advertisement by A.C. Schulz, 1947. (Spoof on Leutze's painting of George Washington crossing the Delaware River.)

items.alt: Chart with concentric rings of black, blue, yellow, beige, and red. Arrows with dollar amounts note the increase from 5.3 million in the year 1875 to 13.4 milion in 1899.
items.title: "Assessed valuation of all taxable property owned by Georgia Negroes." Hand-drawn chart prepared for W.E.B. Du Bois for display at the Paris Exposition Universelle in 1900 to show the economic and social progress of African Americans since emancipation.

items.alt: Map of Georgia with different colors for each county and annotations that indicate the number of acres of land owned in each county.
items.title: "Land owned by Negroes in Georgia, U.S.A. 1870-1900."

items.alt: Night view of sign with orange bulbs filling a horse that rears up  on two hind legs. Green lights outline the rider, who is waving with a raised hand.
items.title: Hacienda horse and rider, historic neon sign, Las Vegas, Nevada. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, around 2000

items.alt: Uncle Sam stands with his arm around a farmer next to a printed text that begins "An alarming shortage exists. The quality is poor."
items.title: Save Seed Corn Now! World War I poster, 1917.

items.alt: Inside view of rainbow-colored balloon while its flame heats up the air.
items.title: Hot Air Balloon Jubilee Festival Decatur, Alabama. Digital photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2010.

items.alt: A float with a large jester figure wearing a purple, yellow, and green hat.
items.title: Mardi Gras Parade, New Orleans, Louisiana. Digital photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2011.

items.alt: Red and green fireworks appear as a huge burst of color above monuments lighted in white and a river in the foreground.
items.title: July 4th fireworks, Washington, DC. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2007.

items.alt: Stained glass window with images of Las Vegas hotels and man holding the comedy and tragedy masks.
items.title: Stained glass window in the Guardian Angel Cathedral, Las Vegas, Nevada. Color transparency photo by Carol M. Highsmith, around 2000.

items.alt: Illustration showing the external textures and cross sections of 14 round and oval sea squirts in different colors.
items.title: Ascidiae (Sea squirt marine animals). Color lithograph by Adolf Giltsch from  sketch by Ernst Haeckel. Color plate in: Kunstformen der Natur, 1904.

items.title: Red house, Rich's Miniature Golf, Wyoming, Pennsylvania. Color slide photo by John Margolies, 1984.

items.alt: Poster showing lots of people walking along the boardwalk with a yellow beach at the right and a blue sky above.
items.title: Atlantic City, the playground of the world: Travel by train. Poster by Latham Litho., 1932.

items.title: Preliminary survey of burned areas, Yellowstone National Park and adjoining national forests. Map, 1988. Geography & Map Division

items.alt: Children in brightly patterned red and green traditional clothing are waiting to see the pope. One child holds up a small banner with the Pope's portrait.
items.title: Pope John Paul II trip to Krakow, Poland. Color slide photo by Bernard Gotfryd, 1983.

items.alt: Red and gold interior of the terminal, shown without people.
items.title: Trans World Airlines Terminal, John F. Kennedy Airport, New York, New York. Color transparency photo by Balthazar Korab around 1962.

items.alt: Chart shows Bootes as a bare-chested man holding a spear, a sickle, and two dogs on leashes.
items.title: Astronomical chart: Bootes, Canes Venatici, Coma Berenices, and Quadrans Muralis. Hand-colored etching book illustration by Sidney Hall, 1825.

items.alt: Woman with long red hair leans on her elbows and faces the viewer. Green peacock feathers are in a circle behind her.
items.title: Summer Reading for Men. Cover for Puck magazine, from painting by T.V. Kelly, 1914.

items.alt: A line of eleven kittens sits on straw. in different positions. Most have black and white or gray fur. One kitten has orange and white fur.
items.title: Yard of cats. Chromolithograph, 1893.

items.alt: Man wearing an orange hat and white face paint surrounded by a horizontal wave shape of yellow and orange feathers.
items.title: Mummers Parade on New Year's day, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Digital photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2011.

items.alt: The figure of Minerva features blue, pink, green, and gold colors.
items.title: Mosaic of Minerva by Elihu Vedder, with restorer at work. Library of Congress, Washington, DC. Color transparency photo by Carol M. Highsmith, around 1990.

items.alt: Statue of Liberty is melting away as red flames engulf her and New York City, which is in the background.
items.title: Lest Liberty Perish from the Face of the Earth - Buy Bonds. Watercolor by Joseph Pennell for a World War I poster, 1918.

items.alt: Large eagle with fiery yellow feathers flies above large ships in a harbor.
items.title: The Ships are Coming. World War I poster by James H. Daugherty, 1917

items.alt: Map shows the Union troop locations in purple and the Confederate fortifications and troops in red on both sides of the blue Mississippi River.

description:
Federal and county courthouses, inside and out, from the 18th to 21st centuries. All pictures are from the Prints & Photographs Division unless otherwise credited.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: Upper stories of a reddish stone building with a clock tower, several turrets, multi-color roof, and many arch-top windows.
items.title: Old Red Courthouse, Dallas County, Texas. (Romanesque style) Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2014.

items.alt: Two-story, wood frame building with five windows and two chimneys.

items.title: Pratt County Courthouse, Kansas.  (Dedication) Real photo postcard, copyright 1910 by F.A. Withers.

items.alt: Empty courtroom with group of seven wood chairs facing in different directions.

items.alt: Elaborate five-story brick building with a tall central tower, elaborate white moldings, and statuary along the roof edge

description:

items.alt: Two women wearing long dresses and an apron standing outside a building with a sign that reads âTwo Girls Waffle House.â
items.title: Two Girls Waffle House, Anchorage, Alaska, about 1910.

items.alt: A small white building next to a larger brick structure in a parking lot. The building has a takeout window with a red awning and painted on the exterior are red, yellow, and green stripes, pictures of ice cream and the word dairy.
items.title: K & J Dairy, 11600 Livernois, Detroit, Michigan. Photo by John Margolies,1986.

items.alt: A restaurant counter, with one man behind the counter and two in front of it. Signs behind the counter advertise food and cigarettes.
items.title: Restaurant sidewalk counter, New York City, New York. Photo by Angelo Rizzuto, 1953.

items.alt: The diner's orange and blue sign illustrated with a Hi-boy, meal in one hamburger and a carhop delivering a drink.
items.title: Nan Denton's Drive-in sign, Knoxville, Tennessee. With curb service. Photo by John Margolies, 1979.

items.alt: A small tan building in the shape of an ice cream cone. Its roof is white and looks like soft-serve vanilla ice cream. Above three small square sliding windows are large red letters that read Twistee Treat.
items.title: Twistee Treat Ice Cream Stand, Saint Joseph, Missouri. Photo by John Margolies,1996.

items.alt: A large room with three men and two women holding raised hands together while dancing. At a nearby table, one man is watching the dancers and another man is playing an instrument.
items.title: Zorba's Greek restaurant, Missoula, Montana. Photo by Carl Fleischhauer, 1979. American Folklife Center.

items.alt: A silver railway-car style classic diner. Its sign reads Melâs Diner and by the entrance a large chef figure gives a thumbs up and holds a sign shaped like a menu that displays the business hours. The parking lot in front is empty and wet with a cloudy sky behind the diner.
items.title: Mel's, a classic American diner, in Grandy, North Carolina. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2017.

items.alt: This red and green sign advertises the Parkette Drive In. The sign advertises chicken, shrimp, and fish boxes.
items.title: The Parkette, a nostalgic, 1950s-era drive-in restaurant in Lexington, Kentucky. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2020.

items.alt: A round, silver, corrugated metal building with a triangular "spout" added to make it look like a coffee pot. A brown sign over the door advertises James River Canoe Livery Limited River Trips.
items.title: Coffee Pot Restaurant, Lexington, Virginia. Photo by John Margolies, 1982.

items.alt: A one-story brick building with a red door with a sign reading âWashington Street Diner.â
items.title: Washington Street Diner, downtown Athens, Alabama. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2010.

items.alt: A free-standing building with a striped awning. It features a sign shaped like a large ice cream cone with the word âBaileyâsâ under it in capital letters.
items.title: Bailey's Dairy Treat Stand, built in 1952 as Butchie's Drive-In, Hot Springs, Arkansas. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2020.

items.alt: Red, blue, and yellow neon lights on a single-story building at night
items.title: Neon-rich night time view of the Snow Cap diner, near Seligman, Arizona. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2016.

items.alt: A man wearing white clothes and a chef's hat stirs one of several silver pots on a black stove.
items.title: Chef in North Beach Italian restaurant. San Francisco, California. Photo by John Collier, 1941.

items.alt: A restaurant interior shows yellow, blue, red, green, and orange rectangles alternating on the wall above a table with chairs around it. A small cat figure sits on the counter at lower right.
items.title: Interior of the Sushi Rama Japanese restaurant in Denver, Colorado, whose modernism is not limited to its decor. Meals are served on a conveyor belt. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2016.

items.alt: A single-story chrome and glass  building with a sign that reads Diner on the top line in capital letters and Peter Pan on the second line. A figure of Peter Pan is on the left side of the sign.
items.title: Peter Pan Diner, Danbury, Connecticut. Photo by John Margolies, 1978.

items.alt: A single-story white building with a small airplane attached to the roof, as if it has crashed into it. The sign on the side of the building reads Wm. Penn Diner and the sign over the door reads Wm. Penn Dining Room. Trucks and a trailer are in the parking lot.
items.title: William Penn Diner on Route 40, Delaware. Photo by Arthur Rothstein, 1939.

items.alt: A man in a three-piece suit leaning over a table, while two men, wearing suits and hats, sit at the table.
items.title: Elder Michaux, Happy News Cafe, 1727 7th St., Washington, DC. Photo by Harris & Ewing, about 1937.

items.alt: A large colorful mural on the outside wall of a Cuban restaurant during daytime hours. A few customers wait to be served at its walk-up takeout counter on the street corner, and a palm tree is nearby.
items.title: Colorful art on a restaurant wall in the historic Little Havana neighborhood of Miami, Florida. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2020.

items.alt: People dressed casually in jeans or shorts and t-shirts studying a menu over the counter while they wait in  line.
items.title: Customer line at the Varsity Grill, Atlanta, Georgia. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2017.

items.alt: A large room with a high ceiling held up by posts and beams filled with many dining tables with chairs and a cafeteria-style counter. No food is pictured. One person is seated at a table toward the back of the room.
items.title: U.S. Naval Base, Pearl Harbor, Yard Restaurant, Seventh Street at Avenue D, Pearl City, Honolulu County, Hawaii. Photo by David Franzen, 2001.

items.alt: A single-story, red-and-white-striped building with an awning and large windows. Its large hand-painted sign reads Bangâs with pictures of a burger and fountain drink.
items.title: Bang's Drive-In, Route 34, Chariton, Iowa. Photo by John Margolies,1980.

items.alt: A one-story white building with a red roof and large sign reading Tip Top. A station wagon is parked in the lot beneath the buildingâs large white overhang next to its drive-through window. The buildingâs front window displays a Closed sign.
items.title: Tip Top Drive In, Lewiston, Idaho. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2005.

items.alt: A red building featuring a windmill with white blades on one end.
items.title: The Mill, once a classic roadhouse diner in Lincoln, Illinois. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2019.

items.alt: A woman wearing a white apron over a dark blouse. She leans on a diner counter, smiling at a man sitting on a stool. He's wearing a uniform, including a cap.
items.title: Truck driver in diner. Clinton, Indiana. Photo by Arthur Rothstein, 1940.

items.alt: A single-story, brown-and-tan building with two sets of double windows and a pair of doors with a sign that reads Sweet Creek Diner Bakery Route 66, and is decorated with an American flag, red, white and blue bunting. A black buggy harnessed to a large, colorful rooster sculpture is parked out front off to one side.
items.title: This diner in Galena, Kansas, is called the Sweet Creek Diner and Bakery on Route 66. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2021.

items.alt: A large, faded red, blue and yellow sign. At the top of the sign, a cartoon-like waiter holding a tray of food stands beside a classic convertible car.
items.title: Ko-Ko-Mo, Dine In Your Car sign, Routes 79 & 80, Bossier City, Louisiana. Photo by John Margolies, 1979.

items.alt: A woman holding two dishes of food. She is standing in a commercial-style kitchen with many pots and pans in use on the surfaces surrounding her.
items.title: Southeast Asian Restaurant and Market, Lowell, Massachusetts. Photo by John Lueders-Booth, 1987. American Folklife Center.

items.alt: A 1950s diner-style room with a black-and-white checkered tile floor, white walls displaying many framed images, a jukebox, and two red circular tables with four empty chairs at each table.
items.title: Bert's 50's Diner in rural Mechanicsville, Maryland. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2017.

items.alt: A large black-and-white outdoor sign that reads Charlieâs Diner with an outline of a waitress. Smaller text above in white reads Charlie is a girl! Attached to the sign is a large lifelike horse with a man wearing a cowboy hat riding the horse as it kicks up its hind legs. A blue sky with clouds and a large street light are also pictured.
items.title: Charlie's Diner sign, Route 11, Leeds, Maine. Photo by John Margolies, 1984.

items.alt: A sign in the shape of a large mug of Frostop root beer in front of a drive-in restaurant.
items.title: The Frostop root beer mug advertising sign outside "The Drive In" restaurant in Taylors Falls, Minnesota. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2019.

items.alt: Three men sitting in chairs at a round table with burgers, fries, and large styrofoam drink cups in front of them. The room also has empty tables and chairs and many framed items displayed on its walls.
items.title: Diners at Abe's Bar B-Q restaurant in Clarksdale, a prominent home to old-time blues music in the Mississippi (River) Delta region. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2016.

items.alt: A large sign attached to the top corner of a brick building. The sign reads Continental Restaurant on a blue-and-white-striped background with a big red arrow pointing to the building. Below the arrow it reads Roasted Chicken and at the top of the sign are a large pizza with the face of a mustached man in a chefâs hat.
items.title: Continental Family Restaurant sign, Routes 5 & 281, Jamestown, North Dakota. Photo by John Margolies, 1987.

items.alt: Design drawings show interior and exterior details of a building, plus a map of the surrounding area.
items.title: Monowi Tavern, Intersection of Broad Street and Grant Street (State Highway 12), Monowi, Nebraska. Architectural drawing, 2017.

items.alt: A gray building with a three-tiered, red-and-green tiled pagoda in between two dormers, each featuring a large red circle with a Chinese character. A parking lot in front of the building is empty.
items.title: Jade Island Chinese Restaurant, Meredith, New Hampshire. Photo by John Margolies, 1984.

items.alt: A pink and green building with Eats written in capital letters over the door.
items.title: Old Nevada abandoned restaurant. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, approximately 1995.

items.alt: A woman in a cap and apron handing a mug across a counter. Three men stand on the other side of the counter. A large silver coffee urn is next to the woman.
items.title: Hot coffee for steel workers at the company restaurant, Youngstown Ohio. Photo by Alfred T. Palmer, 1941.

items.alt: A low brick building with a single red booth on a patio in front. Distances to various cities are painted on the side of the building. A sign rising from the back of the building advertises tires.
items.title: The venerable Meltdown Diner, where varieties of toasted-cheese sandwiches were the specialty along historic U.S. Route 66, Tulsa, Oklahoma. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2020.

items.alt: A large silver airplane adjacent to a building shaped like a tower. The airplane is labeled U.S. Air Force and Restaurant. A black-and-yellow sign in front advertises the restaurant.
items.title: Flight G7 Restaurant, McMinnville, Oregon. Photo by John Margolies, 1987.

items.alt: A square chrome diner with red and yellow stripes next to a sidewalk and parking lot. Signs on the building include the business name and advertise foods to take home and seafood.
items.title: Melrose Diner, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, approximately 1995.

items.alt: The interior of a diner with a long counter and stools on one side and red booths with white tables on the other. The floor is red and white tile squares.
items.title: Modern diner, Pawtucket, Rhode Island. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, approximately 1995.

items.alt: A red-brick building with a bright yellow awning topped by a large cut-out of a hotdog. The sign reads hot dog corner - thatâs my dog!
items.title: The Hot Dog Corner restaurant in Seneca, South Carolina. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2017.

items.alt: A rectangular white building with red trim in front of a larger red brick building.
items.title: Chris's Diner, Center Street, Vermillion, South Dakota. Photo by John Margolies, 1987.

items.alt: Small groups of people standing or sitting on benches at picnic tables outside a wooden building with colorful, metal signs and menus. Five men with guitars sit in front of a few large, bare trees between the restaurant and the picnic tables.
items.title: Tourists at a barbecue place in Luckenbach, Texas. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2014.

items.alt: A red building with two large tan angular shapes on the exterior reaching up from the ground to the buildingâs roof line. A large blue and red sign hanging high above the door reads Broiler Cafe in white lettering and in smaller print Steak, Breakfast, Dinners, Special Chefâs Chinese Foods.
items.title: Broiler Cafe, N. Temple Street, Salt Lake City, Utah. Photo by John Margolies, 1980.

items.alt: A cream and chrome building with red trim, which resembles a railroad car. The sign on the side reads Ross Diner and advertises booth service.
items.title: Ross Diner, Quechee, Vermont. Photo by John Margolies, 1995.

items.alt: A teal and fuschia house trailer with a person standing in the service window. Menus are beside and beneath the window. Signs painted on the left side of the trailer include a waitress holding a tray, and the words Flo to Go and '59er Diner.
items.title: A house trailer becomes a diner of sorts, Wenatchee National Forest, Washington State. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2018.

items.alt: A building with a red, trapezoidal roof that resembles a big top circus tent. In front is a cutout of a circus wagon featuring pictures of elephants. The sign on top reads Red Wagon.
items.title: Red Wagon Restaurant, Route 12, Lake Delton, Wisconsin. Photo by John Margolies, 1988.

items.alt: A very small building with a silver SUV stopped at the drive-up service window. The building is mahogany colored, has a small front porch, and features a large sign with the business name on it. Mountains rise in the background.
items.title: The Great Western Espresso Coffee Co., Route 20, Cody, Wyoming. Photo by John Margolies, 2004.

items.alt: A yellow building with brown trim and two dormers. Mountains are in the background, and bushes obscure part of the front porch. A sign in front includes the business name and the hours.
items.title: KÃ¼tte Swiss Restaurant in tiny Helvetia, once a Swiss colony in Randolph County, West Virginia. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2015.

$children.title: Free to Use and Reuse: Diners, Drive-Ins and Restaurants

description:
This Free to Use set features people with disabilities throughout U.S. historyâat work, at play, at school, and advocating for change. Note that these items were created during many different eras. Historical terminology on older collection items can include words considered offensive, but the original terminology also helps in understanding the context for the itemsâ creation.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: People walk among colorful quilt panels under a blue sky.
items.title: AIDS quilt on display in Washington, D.C., with the U.S. Capitol in the background. 1996.

items.alt: Grayscale, bird's-eye view showing crowds of people watching from both sides of the street as the marchers pass by. Most people wear casual summer clothing including jeans, shorts, and t-shirts.
items.title: Marchers, some holding banners reading "Fighting for our lives" and "NY AIDS Network" during a gay rights march dedicated to the victims of AIDS, New York City, June 26, 1983

items.alt: While a man speaks at a podium, women, men, and children hold up signs including "Seniors Pay More & Get Less."
items.title: Rally to protest Medicare and Medicaid funding cuts at the U.S. Capitol, Washington, DC, 1995. Disability activist Justin Dart is in the front row, far left.

items.alt: Illustration shows two arms folded over one another, holding a military dog tag. Printed at the bottom are the words: "Disabled Veterans as Workers: Dependable, Competent, Hard Working, an Asset."
items.title: "For the disabled veteran, his biggest disability is the inability to find a job." Poster, around 1970.

items.alt: Illustration in gray, white and aqua shows a nurse tending to a man in a wheelchair. He is wearing pajamas and a bathrobe and a bed is in the background.
items.title: "Disability benefits." Poster by Department of Health, Education, and Welfare, 1962.

items.alt: Illustrated flying shows four male veterans holding a sign that says "We demand compensation! $2,500 or Fight!" The flyer includes a list of demands starting with "Decent jobs for decent pay."
items.title: Join the March on Washington for Veterans' Rights, Saturday, May 19. Poster by American Servicemen's Union, 1973-1979.

items.alt: A group of six women and one man sit at tables to create books in braille from transcription to binding.
items.title: American Red Cross volunteer group transcribing books into braille, 1934

items.alt: Congressional leaders are seated at a table smiling while they sign the bill and a group of about 7 children look on. One girl is in an electric wheelchair.
items.title: Senate President Strom Thurmond and House Speaker Newt Gingrich sign the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) while Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott and a group of disabled children look on.

items.alt: Senator Daschle is at a podium with multiple microphones, surrounded by five senators and other people. A large sign in the background encourages passage of the bill, and a hand-held sign in the foreground reads "Patients rights now."
items.title: "Pass the Patients' Bill of Rights Now!" Senate Minority Leader Tom Daschle speaks during a rally while several senators and health care professionals look on, 1999.

items.alt: Poster shows a uniformed soldier with a leg amputated at the knee supporting himself on crutches while standing in front of a row house with steps. The bottom of the poster reads: "Stop the crippling. Stop the killing. Stop the war. Write, wire or call your congressman today."
items.title: "When Johnny comes marching home again, hurrah, hurrah." Anti-Vietnam War poster by Committee to Help Unsell the War shows John Diakoyani of Hoboken, NJ, around 1970.

items.alt: Illustration shows a large group of emaciated and ragged children, one with crutches, gathered around the seated president. A sign in the background reads "Child Laborers."
items.title: "Mr. President, we don't want anything - We just want to grow up," 1913. (Child laborers crowd around Woodrow Wilson)

items.alt: Print shows the head and shoulders of an older man with a friendly expression wearing glasses.
items.title: Dr. Thomas Gallaudet, founder of the first free school for deaf persons in the United Statesâthe  American School for the Deaf in Hartford, Connecticut, around 1850.

items.alt: More than 30 hand-made protest signs with messages supporting the Black Lives Matter movement hang from a wire and fence in a sunny tree-filled square. The signs include "Black Trans Lives Matter", "We're Taking Back Our Air!" and "Smash Racism".
items.title: Fence in Lafayette Square across from the White House a few days after the Black Lives Matter Protest in Washington, D.C. 2020. Several posters name disabled Black people killed by the police, including George Floyd, Sandra Bland, and Freddie Gray.

items.alt: Helen Keller in a dress suit and pill cap around age 70. She is standing with her arm around a young boy and helping him balance while he sits on a railing. Both are smiling.
items.title: Helen Keller advocated for disability rights through lectures and books and was herself deafblind. Shown here in 1956.

items.alt: Several children and youth standing in a row in a front of a large U.S. flag. They are using sign language, and most are smiling.
items.title: Students performing "The Star Spangled Banner" in sign language at the St. Rita School for the Deaf, 1918.

items.alt: Representative Barbara Jordan sitting at a table or podium. She is speaking into two microphones. There is a large sign behind her.
items.title: Representative Barbara Jordan was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis while serving in the U.S. Congress in the 1970s.

items.alt: The cover to a piece of sheet music shows a drawing of a man in a uniform and a woman in a dress. One of the man's legs is shorter than the other. The woman is looking away while holding a handkerchief to her face. A title at the top of the page reads "The Crippled Soldier."
items.title: In this song from 1919, a World War I soldier accepts rejection by one woman because "your crippled soldier loves a lass across the sea" who saw past his injuries.

items.alt: Several people sitting at desks and tables. The room is lined with books.
items.title: The Library of Congress opened a reading room for blind persons in 1897, shown here around 1920.

items.alt: A woman sitting at a table using a laptop. A device is resting on the table next to the laptop. A dog is sitting on the floor nearby.
items.title: The National Library Service for the Blind and Print Disabled was established in 1931 at the Library of Congress to provide braille and recorded materials to people who cannot see or handle print materials.

items.alt: Harriet Tubman standing next to a chair. There is a side table behind her with a book resting on it.
items.title: Harriet Tubman lived with a brain injury and seizures caused by an overseer who hit her in the head before she escaped enslavement. 1870s.

items.alt: John Clarke standing over a piece of partially carved wood. He is holding a mallet and a chisel. There are carvings and pieces of sculpture on shelves behind him.
items.title: John Louis Clarke, a noted Blackfeet wood carver, became deaf from scarlet fever. 1920s.

items.alt: A man in a suit standing in front of a dark backdrop. He is using sign language.
items.title: "Preservation of the Sign Language." Educational film, 1913.

items.alt: A man in a suit using an electric wheelchair. He is in on a sidewalk in front of the U.S. Capitol building.
items.title: Tony Young, a disability rights advocate with quadriplegia, at the U.S. Capitol in 1999.

items.alt: A man in winter clothes skating on a frozen pond. The Washington Monument is in the background behind him.
items.title: An artificial limb recipient ice skating near the Washington Monument, around 1890.

items.alt: A man bowling. The man is in the background and the bowling ball is in the foreground. The man is holding onto a guide rail with one hand.
items.title: Bowling at the Lighthouse, an institution for the blind, in 1944.

items.alt: A printed page advertising a "Grand Exhibition of Left-Handed Penmanship by Soldiers and Sailors Who Have Lost Their Rights Arms During the War."
items.title: "Left-hand penmanship by Civil War veterans who lost their right arms," 1866-1867.

items.alt: A man in a suit sitting on a chair. He does not have a right arm. At the bottom is a signature that reads, "W.A. MacNulty."
items.title: Sergeant William A. MacNulty, 10th New York Infantry, with amputated right arm, in1864.

items.alt: A drawing of three men in Civil War uniforms. One man is standing with one hand in his pocket. Another man is sitting on a chest. He does not appear to have a left leg. One of the men is using a crutch and holding a book. He does not appear to have a left leg. At the bottom is a handwritten title that reads, "A street contrast."
items.title: Disabled Civil War soldiers, 1860s.

items.alt: Two men in uniforms stand in front of a hospital building. One man is using crutches and does not have a left foot. He is lighting the other man's cigarette. The other man does not have hands.
items.title: Soldiers who have amputated limbs are at Walter Reed Hospital in 1918.

items.alt: A colorful poster shows a man standing on a doorway facing a sunny hillside. He is using a crutch and does not have a left leg. Above the image a title reads, "Facing the Future."
items.title: In this World War I poster "Uncle Sam offers training to every man disabled in the service."

items.alt: John McCain in shirtsleeves, in his late 30s. He is sitting in a chair speaking.
items.title: Lt. Commander John McCain, shown here during a 1973 interview about his prisoner of war experience in Vietnam, received a disabled veteran designation.

items.alt: Thomas Edison in a suit and tie around age 60. He is standing in a laboratory, leaning towards another man in a suit. The other man is speaking to him.
items.title: Thomas Edison, who described himself as deaf, is shown standing close to a reporter during an interview in 1906.

items.alt: Around thirty women wearing dresses, standing or sitting in a group in front of a large building.
items.title: Alumni reunion, Indiana State School for the Deaf in 1908.

items.alt: Around 25 men standing in two rows. Most of the men are wearing athletic uniforms and equipment.
items.title: Gallaudet University athletes in 1923.

items.alt: A large red building. A sign in front of the building reads, "College Hall."
items.title: College Hall, Gallaudet University in 2010.

items.alt: Laura Bridgman helping Oliver Caswell read a book. She is holding the book and guiding his finger over embossed letters.
items.title: Laura Bridgman, considered the first deaf-blind child with language education in the United States, is shown with Oliver Caswell reading embossed letters in a book. 1844.

items.alt: Printed page with pie charts that show the blind population of different states in 1870.
items.title: Population of blind persons in the 1870 U.S. census. Chart in the "Statistical Atlas of the United States," 1874.

items.alt: A woman in a dress sits at a desk. She is reading a braille document on the desk in front of her.
items.title: Braille text being read by a woman in an office setting, around 1931

items.alt: Thomas Wiggins in a suit and tie around age 30. A caption below reads, "Blind Tom."
items.title: Thomas Wiggins, a musical prodigy composer and piano player, was blind at birth. 1880.

items.alt: A typewritten poem with a title at the top that reads, "Autumn." At the top right, a handwritten inscription reads, "For Dr. Bell. With dearest Love, From the Author." At the bottom is Helen Keller's signature and "Hulton, Penn., Oct 27th, 1893."
items.title: "Autumn," poem by Helen Keller, 27 October 1893.

items.alt: Two men in suits sitting on a bench. They are each holding playing cards and there is a card on the bench between them. One man is touching the corner of the card with his finger.
items.title: Playing cards in a rooftop garden that opened for  blind persons in 1915.

items.alt: Blind Willie McTell holding a guitar in a furnished room.
items.title: William Samuel McTier became well known as Blind Willie McTell--a blues singer and guitarist. 1940.

items.alt: A panel of elevator buttons. Each button has a braille numeral or letter and a raised character next to it.
items.title: Elevator buttons with braille numerals to assist blind persons. 1981.

items.alt: Lavinia Warren in a dress. She is standing next to an armchair.
items.title: Lavinia Warren, a theatrical performer with dwarfism, was one of the most famous people in the U.S. at the height of her career. 1855-1865.

items.alt: A man in a shirt with rolled up sleeves on a stool. He is operating a band saw.
items.title: Robert Hudson, a little person, made valuable contributions to World War II by processing parts for airplane motor assemblies in 1942.

items.alt: Justin Dart, Jr., in a suit and a hat, and Jesse Jackson in a suit. They are shaking hands. Justin Dart., Jr., is using a wheelchair.
items.title: Disability advocate Justin Dart., Jr., and Jesse Jackson during a 1989 hearing for the Americans with Disabilities Act.

items.alt: A wheelchair sitting next to a table. The wheelchair is made of wood and metal.
items.title: Franklin Roosevelt's wheelchair at the "Little White House," Warm Springs, Georgia in 2017.

items.alt: A man in office clothing entering a Metro car. He is using a wheelchair.
items.title: Metro station, Washington, DC, with wheelchair access in 1977.

items.alt: A wheelchair ramp outside a building.
items.title: Wheelchair ramp at Minneapolis Federal Building, Minneapolis, Minnesota, in 2012.

items.alt: A large building. In front of the building, people are walking past or riding in horse-drawn buggies. At the bottom, a caption reads, "Hospital for the insane of the Army and Navy and the District of Columbia."
items.title: The Hospital for the Insane of the Army and Navy and the District of Columbia, 1860-1861, known later as St. Elizabeth's Hospital.

items.alt: A man in pants and a jacket sitting in an armchair.
items.title: J.E. Hanger Co. promoted the success of its artificial limbs in such photos as this portrait of an unidentified African American man. Around 1905.

items.alt: A man in shirtsleeves and a young girl in a dress with a bow in her hair. The man is bent over a croquet ball. He is using a prosthetic arm to hold the mallet.
items.title: Judge Quentin D. Corley, Sr., playing croquet with a prosthetic arm in the 1910s.

$children.title: Free to Use and Reuse: Disability Awareness

description:
Zoom in on maps that shaped our view of the world throughout history including the first document to name America from 1507 and a 1650 map showing California as an island.

The Library has thousands of maps available online and many more can be viewed in person when you visit the Geography & Map Reading Room.

Browse more content that is free to use and reuse.

items.title: Universalis cosmographia...First known map to name America
Carte de la Louisiane et du cours du Mississippi ...
Novi Belgii Novaeque Angliae : nec non partis Virginiae tabula multis in locis emendata
A new map of Virginia, Mary-Land, and the improved parts of Pennsylvania & New Jersey.
La Floride
A mapp of Virginia discovered to ye hills...
A map exhibiting all the new discoveries in the interior parts of North America
Americae sive qvartae orbis partis nova et exactissima descriptio
Manatvs gelegen op de Noot [sic] Riuier.
Map of California shown as an island
Map of the islands of Hispaniola and Puerto Rico
A correct map of the world drawn from the best discoveries
An accurate chart of the world with the new discoveries...
Mappa totius mundi...
Mappe monde nouvelle
The world from the discoveries & observations made in the latest voyages & travels
Map of the world with the most recent discoveries.
Missionary map of the world showing prevailing religions...
Nova delineatio totius orbis terrarum
A new and correct map of the world projected upon the plane of the horizon...
Chart of the Mediterranean, Black Sea, and the coasts of western Europe and northwest Africa
Chart of the Mediterranean, the coast of Portugal, and the northwest coast of Africa
Map of the Far East and adjacent Pacific
Lewis and Clark map, with annotations in brown ink by Meriwether Lewis, tracing showing the Mississippi...

$children.title: Free to Use and Reuse: Discovery and Exploration

description:
This set features photos of Billie Holiday with her dog Mister and more pictures of canines and their humans.

Browse more content that is free to use and reuse.

items.title: Portrait of Billie Holiday and Mister, Downbeat(?), New York, N.Y., ca. June 1946
Sousa with dogs
Dogs - motoring
Portrait of Billie Holiday and Mister, Downbeat, New York, N.Y., ca. Feb. 1947
Dogs pulling pupmobile
Milksellers, Brussels, Belgium
Laitiere Bruxelloise
Some women prefer dogs
Carrying wounded on COMFORT
Unidentified soldier in Union uniform with dog
Unidentified soldier in Confederate uniform with shotgun sitting next to dog
Portrait of Lilyann Carol, New York, N.Y., ca. Oct. 1946
Gracie, Miss Edith. Dog Show.
