description:
Here there be Dragons! You'll find friendly as well as threatening dragonsâsome with wings and some as serpents. The dragons appear as heroes or villains in book illustrations; mythical figures in dramatic carved shapes; and symbols in posters and cartoons. The original items date from more than 2,000 years ago to recent times. Unless otherwise noted, the selected images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: A siege tower in the shape of a dragon has a basket on its head, a cannon protruding from its mouth, a ladder behind its raised wing leading into its head, and a platform emerging from its chest.
items.title: De re militari. Italy, around 1460 (Rare Book & Special Collections Division)

items.alt: A cartoonish dragon statue perched on a rooftop leans over the buildingâs side.
items.title: Nori, a benevolent dragon at the Providence Children's Museum in  Rhode Island. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2018

items.alt: A yellow, Chinese-style dragon circles and faces the viewer with an open mouth in the middle of the cover.
items.title: Dragon's Wishbone. Federal Theatre program cover, 1939 (Music Division)

items.alt: Print illustration of a dragon emerging from a cloud of smoke.
items.title: Dragon materializing out of a cloud of smoke. Japanese woodcut by Tsurana Morizumi, 1870-1920

items.alt: A red dragon wearing glasses sits reading a book that it holds in front of its face with its tail.
items.title: Poster advertisement for The Bookman magazine. 1896

items.alt: A statue of a dragon's head embellishes putting greens at a miniature golf course.
items.title: A friendly blow-up dragon at a town fair in Pontotoc, Mississippi. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2016
Siegfried bathes in the dragon's blood. Film still for the motion picture Die Nibelungen: Siegfried, 1924

items.alt: A gold bracelet adorned with gemstones and a decorative dragon with three heads.
items.title: Dragon-headed bracelet with jewels, Sikkim. Photo by Alice S. Kandell, 1968

items.alt: A woman dressed as a knight, holding a shield and sword, stands with one foot on the back of another person dressed as a dragon and lying on the ground.
items.title: Constance Hall in St. Geo. and Dragon, Bryn Mawr. Photo by Bain News Service, 1910-1915

items.alt: A smiling dragon statue undulates atop a sign advertising a golf course.
items.title: Golden Dragon Golf, North Myrtle Beach, South Carolina. Photo by John Margolies,1985

items.alt: Print illustration of St. Michael and other angels battling dragons above a castle.
items.title: St. Michael fighting the dragon. Woodcut by Albrecht DÃ¼rer, around 1511

items.alt: Print illustration of a dragon ascending Mt. Fuji after creating rough waters for a group of boats.
items.title: Fuji morigoe no ryÅ«. Japanese woodcut, 1890-1920

items.alt: A painted dragon statue holds a mailbox between its claws.
items.title: An elaborate, dragon-themed mailbox outside a home in East Haven, Vermont. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2017

items.alt: An ornamental iron dragon grips a fence rail in its mouth.
items.title: Cast iron fence railing, 1000 North Dearborn Street, Chicago, Cook County, Illinois. Photo by Joseph Hill, 1936

items.alt: The head and claws of a dragon emerge from the upper right corner, its jaws open and colored red. The dragon appears to be roaring at a small rabbit in the lower left corner, with only its ears and tail visible.
items.title: The Dragon of Wantley: His Tale. Book cover by John Stewardson, 1890-99

items.alt: An illuminated bulb crowns a decorative dragon light fixture.
items.title: Dragon light fixture in the Death Valley Ranch, Main House, Death Valley Junction, California.  Photo by Jack Boucher, 1987-1989

items.alt: A statue of a cartoonish green dragon with several white horns, its red tongue lolling from its mouth, straddles a miniature golf putting green.
items.title: Dragon, Magic Carpet Golf, Key West, Florida. Photo by John Margolies,1985

items.alt: Illustrated Puck magazine cover of a dragon emerging from clouds near an airship.
items.title: The air-serpent. Illustration by Frank A. Nankivell for Puck, 1909 July 14

items.alt: Print illustration of a dragon and a bear representing the constellations Draco and Ursa Minor.
items.title: Draco and Ursa minor. Illustration by Sidney Hall in Urania's mirror, 1825

items.alt: Poster illustration for the play âThe Evil Eyeâ of two men frightened by a large sea monster.
items.title: Chas. H. Yale's fantastic spectacle, The Evil Eye. Theatrical poster by Sidney R. Allen, 1900

items.alt: A stained glass window in the design of a crouching dragon.
items.title: Stained glass window with Dragon. Design drawing by J. & R. Lamb Studios, early 1900s

items.alt: Illustration on an atlas map of a sea monster swimming in the ocean.
items.title: Sea serpents fill the Map of the Sea. By Olaus Magnus, published in Rome in 1572. (Geography & Map Division)

items.alt: A man in a sailor's uniform poses beneath a dragon statue.
items.title: Sailor from HURON in Peking. Photo by Bain News Service,1924

items.alt: Stereograph card photographs of a Viking boat's bow decorated with a dragon figurehead.
items.title: Viking ship, Lincoln Park, Chicago. Stereo photo by Keystone View Co., 1930

items.alt: A circular stone gateway arches over a stone path, with rocks and plants beyond. Two serpentine dragon sculptures rest atop the gateway, balancing a small sphere between them.
items.title: The "Moongate" at the Riverside International Friendship Gardens, La Crosse, Wisconsin. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2016

items.alt: A knight points his lance at the mouth of a dragon lying on the ground. The article below describes Judge Ben B. Lindsay defending suffragists from false statements.
items.title: Saint George and the Dragon. Illustration by Martha Bryn in the Votes For Women Broadside. Broadside. Published by the Women's Political Union, 1911 (Rare Book & Special Collections Division)

items.alt: A statue of a dragon's head embellishes putting greens at a miniature golf course.
items.title: Serpent head, Jockey's Ridge Mini-Golf, Nags Head, North Carolina. Photo by John Margolies,1985

items.alt: A serpentine dragon emerges from dark clouds in the foreground, toward a single snow-capped mountain in the background.
items.title: RyÅ« shÅten. Japanese woodcut by GekkÅ Ogata, 1897

items.alt: A large stone vase, shaped like a flower bud sits on a hexagonal pedestal. A serpentine stone dragon wraps around the far side and rises above the vase with its claws on the edge and its mouth wide. A garden and buildings are in the background.
items.title: Travel views of Japan and Korea. Photo by Arnold Genthe, 1908

items.alt: Illustrated product label of a dragon with its tongue out and one foot in the air.
items.title: Trademark registration by Bell, Conrad & Co. for First Steamer Red Dragon Chop brand Japan Tea. 1887

items.alt: Eight men dressed in black, blue, red, and yellow hold up a green and red serpentine dragon with sticks for the dragon dance.
items.title: Tojin ja-odori no zu. Japanese woodcut, 1850-1900

items.alt: Nine men pose with a long sea serpent made of driftwood on a rocky beach.
items.title: Sea Serpent #3, Seattle, Washington. Photo of a driftwood sculpture, 1906

items.alt: A decorative stone handle in the shape of a dragon.
items.title: Stone serpent handle. Sculpture from the Cotzumalhuapa civilization. BCE 200-CE 200 (Geography and Map Division)

items.alt: A wall of murals in Havana's Chinatown depicts two dragons.
items.title: Murals painted on a building on Dragones Street, in the Chinatown section of Havana, Cuba. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2010

items.alt: Book illustration of a dragon with a curved tail and an outstretched tongue.
items.title: Draconis Alarifigura ex Pareo. Illustration in Serpentum et draconum historiÃ¦ (Natural History of Serpents and Dragons) by Ulysses Aldrovandi. Bologna (Italy), 1640 (Rare Book & Special Collections Division)

items.alt: A small statue of a dragon with a shield atop a reproduction City of London boundary marker.
items.title: Heraldic dragon monument in Lake Havasu City, Arizona. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2018

items.alt: An alligator-like dragon, wearing a crown, stands at the foot of a bed containing a man surrounded by pillows and covers.
items.title: "At last the emperor began to dream. He heard the awful voice, the voice of the Golden Dragon. ..." Frontispiece in the book Chop-Chin and the Golden Dragon, 1899 (General Collections)'

items.alt: Print illustration of a dragon carrying off a man intently reading a book.
items.title: Illustration by John R. Neill for the book The Prince and the Dragons, by Tudor Jenks, 1906 (General Collections)

items.alt: Book illustration of a crouching dragon blowing a plume of smoke from its nostril.
items.title: Frontispiece for the book The Dragon and Juggernaut of Speculation ... by James H. Howe, 1916 (General Collections)

items.alt: In this political cartoon, a transparent dragon with the words âThird Termâ on its side sits on top of two men lying in bed. The men glare at the dragon.
items.title: Their nightmare. Color illustration by Charles J. Taylor in Puck magazine, 1895

items.alt: A row of carved and painted dragon heads protrudes from an ornate wall painted primarily red, green, and gold.
items.title: Dragon head carvings above the Tsuklakhang Main Temple (Palace Temple) door, Gangtok, Sikkim. Photo by Alice S. Kandell, 1965-1979

items.alt: Newsprint photograph of a man touching a massive papier-mÃ¢chÃ© dragon.
items.title: The Chinese Dragon. Illustration in the Eureka Sentinel, Nov. 16, 1912. See: Chronicling America

items.alt: A dragon marionette rests slumped on a flat surface.
items.title: Production still photo from Dragon Snee Zee, a marionette show made for the Federal Theatre Project, around 1935 (Music Division)

items.alt: Book illustration of a dragon wearing medieval armor and carrying a spear.
items.title: "They thought I was one of those fire belching dragons." Drawing by Daniel B. Carter. Illustration for A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court by Mark Twain, 1889

$children.title: Free to Use and Reuse: Dragons

description:
This selection of serious and humorous family portraits and activities concentrates on the 1800s to the 1940sâthe time period when most of the Library's free to use and reuse images were created. All pictures are from the Prints & Photographs Division unless otherwise credited.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: Formal studio portrait of six young men in suits. Three are seated and hold (from left to right) a mandolin, violin, and cello. Three are standing with instruments less visible. The photographer's five sons are African American.
items.title: Summit Avenue Ensemble, Atlanta, Georgia. Photo by Thomas Askew, 1899. (The photographer's five sons and a neighbor)

items.alt: Formal studio portrait of a Native American family in traditional clothing. An older woman sits center front. A  younger woman sits next to her holds a baby in a cradleboard with two young children standing nearby. The man stands behind them.
items.title: Sauk family. Photo by F.A. Rinehart, Omaha, 1899.

items.alt: Photo shows a white father sitting on a wooden porch with an arm around his young son (at the left) and his daughter (at the right). All three are looking at the comic book in his hand. Their clothing is casual, and the children are smiling.
items.title: Montgomery, Alabama. Marvin Johnson, truck driver, reading "funnies" to his two children. Photo by John Vachon, 1943

items.alt: Formal studio portrait of a white woman wearing a dress with a lace color while holding in her lap her baby girl in a long gown. Both face the camera. A decorative brass mat surrounds the photo.
items.title: Lucy Stone holding her daughter Alice Stone Blackwell. Daguerreotype photo, 1857 or 1858

items.alt: Photo shows a teenage girl standing outdoors while holding in her arms a barefoot toddler in a long dress. Each sister has a ribbon bow in her hair and is looking directly into the camera.
items.title: Mexican baby with sister, San Antonio, Texas. Photo by Russell Lee, 1939

items.alt: Color photo shows a family of three sitting outdoors on a green and brown field under a blue sky. The father (at left) and the mother (at right) carry belongings on their backs. A young boy sits between them in a green jacket.
items.title: Nomadic Kirghiz on the Golodnaia Steppe (present-day Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan). Photo by Sergei M. Prokudin-Gorskii, 1905-1915

items.alt: Photo shows two Japanese men and two Japanese women standing under the blooming branches of a cherry tree. Debuchi's daughter is wearing traditional Japanese clothing, and the others are in western clothing. All are smiling.
items.title: Ambassador Katsuji Debuchi and his daughter Takako Debuchi (at right) visit the cherry blossoms in Washington, DC. Photo by National Photo Co, 1929

items.alt: Photo shows a mother and four children seated outdoors in a tent pitched on bare dirt and open on one side. The mother, seated at right, is frowning, while holding the baby to her chest. In front of the tent, the oldest daughter sits in a rocking chair and a trunk is open with a partially raised lid.
items.title: Migrant agricultural worker's family. Seven hungry children. Nipomo, California. Photo by Dorothea Lange, 1936 (Part of the "Migrant Mother" series)

items.alt: Color photo shows a father kneeling on the ground with one knee raised to hold his barefoot, blond-haired young daughter. He raises to her mouth a piece of what might be cake. Both people are white. A tall brimmed hat hides most of his face.
items.title: Homesteader feeding his daughter at the Pie Town, New Mexico, Fair free barbeque. Photo by Russell Lee, 1940

items.alt: Photo shows a man who is smiling widely as he holds his happy-looking baby on his shoulder. The man has a long mustache. The baby is sucking a pacifier and wears a cap. A young girl's eyes and hair are visible in the foreground.
items.title: The happiest refugee. Baby gets his sunny disposition from his father who is happy to reach the American Red Cross relief station.  Finland News Service, 1919-1929

items.alt: Color poster shows a smiling man in a U.S. army uniform and cap with a well used metal helmet at his belt. He is holding his son, who has arms wrapped around his neck. His wife (at right) looks at a medal on his blouse. The people look white.
items.title: For Home and Country - Victory Liberty Loan. War poster by Alfred Orr, 1919

items.alt: A family of four has their backs to the camera as they walk into a small, mobile trailer. The youngest of two small boys is entering the trailer door with his brother, mother, and father standing in a line behind him, each with a paper bag of shopping. Palm tree fronds are visible in the background.
items.title: Family moving into trailer at the Farm Security Administration camp for defense workers, San Diego, California. Photo by Russell Lee, 1941

items.alt: Colored print shows (from left to right) a grandson, who is standing with one hand on a globe. George Washington in his military uniform has one arm on the boy's shoulder and is seated at a table covered by a map. A granddaughter stands behind the table near her seated grandmother, who is wearing a large lace cap. An enslaved African American man in livery stands behind them.
items.title: The Washington family--George Washington, his lady, and her two grandchildren by the name of Custis. Painted and engraved by Edward Savage, 1798

items.alt: Photo shows at least eight formerly enslaved African Americans in front of a wood cabin. Left to right: two children sit on the cabin steps; a woman holds a baby; an old man and an old woman sit in chairs; two young boys sit on the ground in front of them; and a woman stands at the right.
items.title: Five generations on Smith's Plantation, Beaufort, South Carolina. Photo by Timothy O'Sullivan, 1862

items.alt: Formal studio portrait of an African American family. The father, in uniform, sits next to the mother who is wearing a dark dress and bonnet. The two daughters wear matching hats and coats and are each leaning against a parent. A decorative brass mat and black frame surround the photo.
items.title: African American soldier in Union uniform with wife and two daughters. Civil War tintype photo, 1863-1865

items.alt: Color print shows nine blank oval spaces in the middle where photographs could be added. The eight vignettes around the margins show scenes from African American history: "Forced from home to increase the stranger's wealth" portrays enslaved people on an African shore with a sailing ship in the distance. "American Slavery, Southern Scenes" shows enslaved people picking cotton and a slave auction. "In Liberty we now rejoice" shows people walking towards churches and a well-to-do family in front of their two-story house. "Not slaves but American Citizens" shows men in front of a building with sign "Polls" and U.S. Capitol.
items.title: Freedman's National and Family Record. Print by Strobridge & Co., 1873

items.alt: Color print shows ten blank ovals where photographs can be added. The apples on the tree are labeled with such words as Faith, Truth, and piety. Scenes from the lives of white families are in the corners of the prints: a young mother and father with a baby and young daughter; a couple in a rowboat; four children playing with toys; and an old man and woman sitting on a porch.
items.title: Family record of [blank]. Color print by Chapman Bros. Lith. Chicago, 1888

items.alt: Formal studio portrait of an African American mother seated and surrounded by her five childrenâtwo sons on the left and three daughters on the right. Each person is well dressed.
items.title: Mrs. Frazer Baker and children. Family of the murdered postmaster at Lake City, So. Carolina. Photograph by J.E. Purdy, 1899

items.alt: Photo shows a  family of 22 white people formally posed in three rows--a mix of men, women, children, and babies.  All are wearing dark clothing and have serious looks on their faces. Three men and one child hold guns. In front of the group sits a hound dog. In the background is a wood cabin.
items.title: Group of Hatfields-McCoy feudist with women & children, Welch, W. Va. Photo by T.F. Hunt, 1899

items.alt: Image shows a typed document with the heading:  "Western Union Telegraph" sent to Bishop M. Wright from Kitty Hawk, North Carolina. Message says: "Success four flights Thursday morning all against twenty one mile wind started from level with engine power alone average speed through the air thirty one miles longest 57 seconds  inform Press  home Christmas.  Orevelle (sic) Wright"
items.title: Telegram, Orville Wright to Bishop Milton Wright announcing the first successful powered flight, 17 December [1903].

items.alt: Photo shows a Native American man, woman, and young girl sitting on the ground in front of rows of teepees with mountains in the background. The man holds a pipe to his mouth. The woman smiles and looks at the child.
items.title: Starting Supper: Flathead Reservation. Stereograph photo by Norman A. Forsyth, 1908

items.alt: Photo shows a white woman and nine children standing in a single row in front of an old house with white siding. The woman stands on the right. The woman and girls wear dresses; the boys wear shorts. The children are arranged from tallest to shortest, and most are barefoot.
items.title: A family working in the Tifton (Ga.) Cotton Mill. Mrs. A.J. Young works in mill and at home. Photo by Lewis Hine, 1909

items.alt: Photo shows a woman and two children who are sewing garments inside a cramped looking room. The woman looks at the camera, while the children look at the garments. Behind them a stove is in the corner with several pots and pans, and a cat sits on top of the sink watching.
items.title: High up on the top floor of a rickety tenement, 214 Elizabeth St., N.Y., this mother and her two children were living in a tiny one room and were finishing garments. Photo by Lewis Hine, 1912

items.alt: Photo shows four people standing on a wooden dock with their backs to the camera as they look out over the water. The two men are dressed in dark pants, overcoats, and caps.  The two women wear long dresses. The man on left points to something unseen in the distance.  In the foreground, suitcases, bundles and baskets lay on the dock.
items.title: Four immigrants and their belongings, on a dock at Ellis Island. Photograph, 1912

items.alt: Book illustration tinted in green shows four people seated around a breakfast table. The mother, son, father, and daughter are pushing away from the table in surprise as dishes and utensils fly off the table cloth. A rocket has cut a hole in the table, and its light trail continues upward to the next floor.
items.title: The Rocket Book. By Newell Peter, 1912

items.alt: Poster in black and orange shows an old man in a hat and overcoat who is holding one young girl while another girl stands next to them. The poster has a lot of text that describes how the refugee office offers free service to help reunite families.
items.title: Office de renseignements pour les Familles disperses. World War I poster by ThÃ©ophile Alexandre Steinlen, 1915

items.alt: Sheet music cover in red, white, and blue shows a man in uniform who is holding a rifle by his leg and pointing his hat towards his mother. She stands at a gate in front of a small house with a porch and waves at her son.
items.title: A Promise to Mother. World War I sheet music by Emma Myers Masters, 1918. Music Division

items.alt: Cheerful sheet music cover has figures with the shapes of states. Clockwise: An Army soldier (Georgia) salutes an older woman (Mississippi). A woman (Virginia) reads a letter. A nurse (Missouri) has a bandage. A woman (South Carolina) collects money. A woman (Missouri) sews seeds. A young girl (Idaho) holds a hoe. A woman (Minnesota) has a pail of milk and a cow (New Jersey).
items.title: That Family Called the U.S.A. World War I sheet music with words and music by Billy Downs, 1919. Music Division

items.alt: Handwritten letter with heading "Yellowstone Park, Wyoming." The text begins "Blessed Quenty-quee,  I love you very much. Here is a picture of the mule that carries, among other things, my bag of clothes. There are about twenty mules in the pack train. They all follow."  A drawing of a mule with a pack on its back is in the middle of the page.
items.title: Teddy Roosevelt's letter to his son Quentin. April 16th, 1903. (First page) Manuscript Division

items.alt: Poster printed primarily in blue and green shows a cartoon-like drawing of a white family standing in a row without expressions holding their arms out at their sides. From left to right, the youngest child has curly red hair and socks falling around her ankles. Her brother, mother, and father stand next to her.
items.title: The Job of Being a Parent. Federal Art Project, WPA poster by Kreger, 1936-1939

items.alt: Photo shows a family of twelve people of different ages seated at a large table and eating dinner. In the back of the room are a dresser with plates and canned food and a curtained window.
items.title: Spanish-American family eating dinner. Chamisal, New Mexico. Photo by Russell Lee, 1940

items.alt: Color photo shows a white family posed in a room with cardboard lining the walls. The mother and father are in the back row with three girls and two young boys in front of them. The children wear clean clothes, including patterned dresses.
items.title: Jack Whinery and his family, homesteaders, Pie Town, New Mexico. Photo by Russell Lee, 1940

items.alt: Photo shows a white family walking down a sidewalk towards the camera. The mother is wearing a dress and holding her purse while the father, in shirtsleeves and a tie, pushes the baby in a stroller. Grass is on both sides of the walkway.
items.title: Greenbelt, Maryland. Family strolling on Sunday. Photo by Marjory Collins, 1942

items.alt: Photo shows six people in a Japanese American family sitting inside a room with a small Christmas tree in the window behind them. The father is smiling while looking at his daughter. The three sons sit on a patterned sofa.
items.title: TÅyÅ Miyatake Family at the "Manzanar Relocation Center" (incarceration camp). Photo by Ansel Adams, 1943

items.alt: Photo shows three white girls and one boy in a kitchen doing housework. Two girls in the foreground are washing and drying dishes in large bowls. In the background next to the stove, a boy is at a trash can, and a girl stands on a chair to put plates in a cupboard.
items.title: Buffalo, New York. Patsy Grimm helping to do all the housework. Their mother, a twenty-six year old widow, is a crane operator at Pratt and Letchworth. Photo by Marjory Collins, 1943

items.alt: Photo shows two white boys in matching zip-up jackets and knitted ski masks. The boys have their arms around each others' shoulders.  Behind them is a house and leafless trees.
items.title: Lititz, Pennsylvania. Brothers. Photo by Marjory Collins, 1942

items.alt: Photo shows two smiling white girls with their arms around each other. One girl stands on the ground with her left hand on her hip.  The younger girl stands on something so that she is slightly taller than her older sister. A house is in the background.
items.title: Carol M. Highsmith, age 4, with her sister Sara  at her grandmother's farm in Madison, North Carolina. Photo, 1949

items.alt: Color print shows a white family inside a room with a fireplace. In the foreground a man is kneeling on the floor with his arms on the seat of a chair. He has a beard, a bald head, and a pained expression on his face. An angry-looking cat with an arched back sits on the mans back and swats its paw at a dog crouching on the floor. Two boys point and laugh at the man. Meanwhile, a woman points at the boys with an angry look on her face. The house looks run-down with cracks on the walls and mirror.
items.title: Two children enjoying the commotion caused at meal time. Chromolithograph by Archibald Willard Published by J.F. Ryder, 1874

items.alt: Color poster shows ten white women and two men doing various acrobatics, including foot juggling.  Each woman wears a yellow leotard, red shoes, and a red ribbon tied around her waist. Some of the women lay on the ground with their feet in the air.  Others are shown performing flips above the women on the ground. Yellow text, against a red background, says:  "Famous Nelson Family. Miracles of Action and Infallible Calculations, Prodigious Champions, seen only with Cole Bros. Circus."
items.title: Cole Bros. Circus. Nelson Family. Poster by Erie Lithographic Co., 1935 or later

items.alt: Color poster shows head-and-shoulder photographic portraits of five white men, arranged in a diagonal row.  Each man has a large mustache and wears a dark suit jacket, white shirt, and black tie,  The portraits are inside a vignette border with elaborate curves set against a grey background.  A red banner has the following names, from top to bottom:  "Alf T, Al, Otto, John, Chas."
items.title: Ringling Bros. Circus poster by Courier Litho. Co., 1900

items.alt: Stereograph photo shows a posed scene inside a house. A man wearing an apron kneels on the floor to help a woman adjust her boots. She is wearing plaid pants and a man's hat. In front, two young children are playing with toys.
items.title: "Mind the children, finish the washing, and have dinner at 12." Stereograph by Whiting View Company, 1900

items.alt: A glamour photo shows two white vaudeville performers. Their heads are touching, and their bare arms are resting on an unseen piece of furniture while they look directly into the camera with an engaging expression.
items.title: Duncan Sisters. Photo by Bain News Service, 1920s

items.alt: A comical photo shows four white men arranged so that their heads and shoulders look stacked on top of each other. The man on top holds his right arm up in the air.
items.title: The Marx Brothers, top to bottom, Chico, Harpo, Groucho, and Zeppo. Photo 1931

items.alt: Color photo shows a small building with white siding .  A sign in red lettering reads:  "Grandpa's Family Restaurant." A single door on the front of the building has the words "Memory Lane" above it. To the right of the door is a picture of a car with the words:  "Profits/Image." To the left is a blue drum can. Leafless trees are nearby.
items.title: Grandpa's Family Restaurant near U.S. Route 66 in Crawford County, Missouri. Photograph by Carol Highsmith, 2021

items.alt: Print shows the drawing of an adult black-and-tan dog surrounded by five very young puppies. Four puppies sit or lie in front of their mother, while one climbs on her back. The floor is covered in straw.
items.title: A Promising Family: Black and Tan. Lithograph by Currier & Ives, 1868

items.alt: Color print shows a black-and-white cat and three kittens. Two kittens are licking a green bowl. Straw is in a basket and on the floor.
items.title: Cat and Kittens. Chromolithograph by William Schaus after a painting by Henrietta Ronner,1867

$children.title: Free to Use and Reuse: Families

description:
This selection of images from the 19th and 20th centuries display aspects of life on American farms: landscapes, work, play, and everyday moments from dinner to doctor visits. All pictures are from the Prints & Photographs Division unless otherwise credited.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: A barefoot boy in ragged clothes is facing the camera and smiling as he sits in a tire swing and holds the halter of a cow standing next to him.
items.title: Boy in tire swing holds a cow on a tether. Photo from U.S. Extension Service,  1925-1930

items.alt: African American woman fills a glass at an outdoor water well pump.
items.title: Wife of resettled farmer, Roanoke Farms, North Carolina. Photo by John Vachon, 1938

items.alt: Colorful poster, with the title across the top, features a horse race underway in its center with vignettes at each corner, including people looking at cattle and other exhibits.
items.title: Maine State Agricultural Society. Poster, 1894

items.alt: A one-story house with plain sides and a flat roof has a door and three windows on the front and one window on the left side. Low bushes sit in front of the house on the right, and a partial picket fence tips over in the front left corner
items.title: Home of Spanish-American farm family. Taos County, New Mexico. Photo by Russell Lee, 1939

items.alt: Two men on a mule-drawn wagon are fertilizing a plowed field
items.title: Spreading fertilizer from 4-mule team wagon, Georgia. Photo by Marion Post Wolcott, around 1940

items.alt: A farmer and children, with their backs to the camera, walk along a wooden fence on the left and trees and bushes on the right.
items.title: The day's end. Photograph, 1905

items.alt: The left half of the poster shows a red-roof barn next to fields separated by rows of green trees. The right half shows a dust-filled  landscape and almost buried building.
items.title: Plains farms need trees. Poster by Joseph Dusek, 1936-1940

items.alt: An older man and woman sit in rocking chairs on either side of a fireplace, in a room with a wooden floor, two oval rugs, sheer curtained windows and a desk on the left.
items.title: Man and woman in rockers by fireplace. Photo from USDA Extension Service, 1925-1930

items.alt: An African American woman sits on the den front porch with a small child in her lap. Three other children, two wearing hats, stand on the stair.  All are facing toward the camera and are surrounded by pieces of furniture.
items.title: Southeast Missouri Farms. Family of FSA (Farm Security Administration) client before moving from old house. Photo by Russell Lee, 1938

items.alt: A young boy, wearing a hat leans against the end of a wooden cart.  He holds the handle of a white canister, painted with red flowers, resting on his knee.
items.title: Son of one of the FSA farmers on the Rio Piedras project who brought lunch to his father, working in the sugar cane field. Photo by Jack Delano, 1942

items.alt: A woman wearing a checked apron, facing left, stands outside an open doorway with a feed pan in her right hand. Many chickens around her feet peck at the ground. A black dog stands to the left of the chickens, and a white cat sits in the doorway behind.
items.title: Barnyard. Lithograph by Mabel Dwight, 1939

items.alt: The April 1, 1948, issue of the Montana Farmer-Stockman, has the headline, "Spring Mechanization." The left and center columns contain text. Four pictures of tractors and farm machinery are in the right-hand column.
items.title: The Montana Farmer-Stockman, newspaper

items.alt: The end of a red barn with a smaller, windowed addition jutting from the end dominates the picture.  Three round gray silos and another barn stand further back on the right side. A blue pickup truck is parked in front of the van with a jeep to the left.
items.title: Schultz Family dairy barn with the cheese room addition, early morning. Photo by Martha Cooper, 2013. American Folklife Center.

items.alt: On the left, a woman wearing a head scarf and apron sits on a stool facing a counter and cabinets. In the back center, two windows shine light on a floor with a geometric design, and an iron stove is on the right in shadow.
items.title: Woman peeling potatoes in modern farm kitchen. Photo by Photo from USDA Extension Service, 1920s

items.alt: A tilted stand holds melons and baskets. Two women and a man face each other in front of the platform, another man and a boy are in the background. Melons are lined up on the ground across the picture and a T-shaped utility pole stands on the left.
items.title: Roadside melon and vegetable stand with cornfield in background. Photo from USDA Extension Service, about 1930

items.alt: A child wearing black pants, a gold-embroidered black jacket, and a wide-brimmed hat tied under his chin with a gold ribbon, stands facing the camera, and holds a coil of red rope in his left hand.
items.title: Marco Pena is about to delight the passing crowd with his lasso wizardry at the annual Iowa State Fair in the capital city of Des Moines, color photo, 2016

items.alt: Two men, a woman, a boy, and a young girl sit around a table with a plaid tablecloth and dishes of food. All are focused on the food, except the girl, who looks at the camera.  On the wall at the back, there is a door on the left with a window looking outside, two calendars showing October hang on the wall in the center, and lace-trimmed cloths hang on the right.
items.title: Farm family eating dinner. Photo by Russell Lee, 1939

items.alt: A young girl with a bow in her hair, a white apron over a dark dress, and brown tights stands outside, facing the camera, next to an open wooden door. A white chicken stands in the doorway, with its tail still in shadow.
items.title: Girl next to barn with chicken, possibly holding eggs in her folded apron. Unidentified photographer, 1941 or 1942.

items.alt: A green landscape stretches across the picture, a farm field in the center with rows curving slightly along the hills.  Trees surround the field, and a red barn stand on the right side with two other buildings near the barn. More trees and fields stretch in the background, with another set of buildings on the far left.
items.title: View from the bluffs of Sherrill, Iowa, of the rich agricultural valley, near the Mississippi River, far below, color photo, 2016

items.alt: A boy wearing a white t-shirt, black and red shorts, and dark gray cowboy boots bends over a white sheep with a black face and feet. The sheep is tethered to a ring in a brick wall; a red bucket containing a plastic bottle sits on the ground nearby.
items.title: Already carefully groomed, a sheep gets a good washing prior to its appearance in the show ring at the annual Iowa State Fair in the capital city of Des Moines. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2016

items.alt: A group of women holding plates stand around a cylindrical ice cream freezer, four women on the left and six on the right.  Three of the women in the foreground and two in the background are wearing white smocks.
items.title: Group of farm women holding plates of cake and ice cream and spooning homemade ice cream out of freezers. Photo by USDA, early 1930s

items.alt: A man wearing a hat and suspenders over a long-sleeved shirt, stands on the right, his back to the camera, and holds a pitchfork across a log-beam on the left.  A second man wearing a hat and long-sleeved shirt stands behind the pile of hay on the left side of the beam and appears to be moving some of the hay.
items.title: Threshing. Caledonia County, Vermont. Photo by Arthur Rothstein, 1937

items.alt: Farmer sits astride a roll of wire, with a sack of cotton seed and fence posts, on a wagon ready to be pulled by a horse or mule.
items.title: Farmer with cotton seed, fence posts and wire ... Roanoke Farms, North Carolina. Photo by John Vachon, 1938

items.alt: Young boy facing the camera and holding the halter of a mule in a field.
items.title: Farm boy, Guilford County, North Carolina. Photo by John Vachon, 1938

items.alt: Posed in a plowed field are a young man sitting on the seat of a disc harrow with two mules ready to pull it.
items.title: Son of farmsteader at Roanoke Farms, North Carolina.  Photo by John Vachon, 1938

items.alt: Reproduction of the Mona Lisa is painted on the side of a barn, with two silos to the left. Mona Lisa wears a t-shirt with the words "the big cheesy Super Bowl."
items.title: Mona Lisa barn art, Wisconsin. Phone by Carol Highsmith, 1990

items.alt: A man, wearing overalls and reading a newspaper, and a woman, wearing a light, print dress, sit on stools facing each other. The woman watches a toddler walking toward the camera. A baby sits in a highchair, next to the man, on the left.  A curtained window and cabinet with a radio are in the background.
items.title: Owner of 120-acre farm with family. Meeker County, Minnesota. Photo by John Vachon, 1940

items.alt: A man wearing light clothing stands in the right foreground. He looks at a stack of cut sugar cane, almost as tall as he is, on the left, with the cut ends facing the camera. A V-shaped metal scaffold, with several cables hanging from it rises from behind the sugar cane beyond the top of the picture.
items.title: Crane at a "central" sugar cane gathering place, San Sebastian vicinity, Puerto Rico. Photo by Jack Delano, 1942

items.alt: A mural painted on a three story brick wall with glass block windows shows a woman with a yellow dress and blue jacket, wearing a hat and holding a long red tool handle standing over two-stories tall, with a taller drawing of a corn stalk on the left.  The faded remains of a painted ad is partially obscured by the mural on the right.
items.title: Farmer Annie Glidden, detail from historical mural in DeKalb, Illinois, that recalls the area's agricultural roots, color photo, 2020

items.alt: A white sign, with whispy clouds in the sky behind it, reads "U.S.D.A FARM FAMILY LABOR CAMP AT CALDWELL." In the bottom left corner of the sign is an arrow pointing left, with the notation "1 1/4 MI."
items.title: Sign of FSA (Farm Security Administration) labor camp, Caldwell, Idaho. Photo by Russell Lee, 1941

items.alt: A table with a white table cloth sits under a sheer-curtained window, in an otherwise dark room. Three framed photos, a glass bottle, and a white planter with daffodils stand on the table.
items.title: Image 14 of Jarvis farm, Ennice, Alleghany County, North Carolina. Photo by Lyntha Scott Eiler, 1978. American Folklife Center

items.alt: A large white house, in the left middle ground dominates the picture, with trees beyond it. A man with a wheelbarrow and a number of farm animals including a cow, pig, and chickens, stand in the foreground.
items.title: Farm scene showing house, animals, people working. Woodcut by John Aiken,  1818

items.alt: Print shows a bird's-eye view of fairgrounds with a steamboat "Osceola" on the river in the foreground. Includes seven vignettes showing livestock, agricultural machinery, and, at top center, two female figures representing "Liberty and Prosperity." Also shown on the sides are examples of agricultural produce. Text at the top includes the title of the image, along with blank lines on which to write the name of the awardee and the date, and signatures.
items.title: Diploma awarded by the People's Agricultural Society of West Jersey. Lithograph by P.S. Duval, around 1862

items.alt: A landscape shows a woman and child walking away from the viewer on a wide dirt road toward a large white house and red barn surrounded by trees. A pond on the right side of the road has two people in boats in the background.
items.title: Farmstead scene with woman and child on the road and men fishing in boats nearby. Chromolithograph by Paul R. Koehler, 1905

items.alt: Two women sit, facing the camera, on a wooden bench, holding a round rug with a pattern of concentric circles.  Other rugs lie at their feet, with a potted plant on a pedestal on the right next to a window into the house.
items.title: Two women making braided rugs on porch. Photo from U.S. Department of Agriculture, Extension Service,1925-1930

items.alt: Poster shows a woman sitting in a rocking chair while sewing by hand near a table with a lamp. A red stripe across a yellow background at the top reads "Now I'm Satisfied."  Red letters across the bottom read, "RURAL ELECTRIFICATION ADMINISTRATION, U.S. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE"
items.title: Now I'm satisfied. Rural Electrification Administration, U.S. Department of Agriculture. Poster by Lester Beall, 1930s

items.alt: A crowd of people, most wearing hats, sit on tiered seating, facing left, under a canvas roof. A wooden plank barricade stands at the bottom of the tiers.
items.title: Farm people at livestock auction. Central Iowa Fair, Marshalltown, Iowa. Photo by Arthur Rothstein, 1939

items.alt: Two men wearing hats stand behind a square wooden structure over a well.  A pully hangs from the top, wrapped with a chain connected to a small bucket.
items.title: Negro farm owner and brother leaning on well top on their farm, near Jefferson, Texas. Photo by Russell Lee, 1939

items.alt: Bean plants frame the left and right sides of the picture. Two people stand in between the rows and pick beans. The person on the right, wears a hat; the person on the left, their back to the camera, is partially bent over.
items.title: Migrant pickers harvesting beans. Farm people came from South Dakota. Photo by Dorothea Lange, 1939

items.alt: A woman holding a small black dog sits in front of a wooden wall, with a sheer curtain on the right. Two oval framed photographs of men hang on the wall above her, with a small calendar and other items directly behind her.
items.title: Daughter of Mexican farm family at home. Photo by Russell Lee, 1939

items.alt: Two women stand behind wooden bins with wrapped green tomatoes. More bins with tomatoes stand behind them.
items.title: Sorting and packing tomatoes at the Yauco Cooperative Tomato Growers Association, Puerto Rico. Photo by Jack Delano, 1942

items.alt: A man and woman sit on a bench with five small children. A man in a suit sits in a chair facing them, with a black case on the floor by his feet.
items.title: Country doctor visiting farm family. Photo by John Vachon, 1942

items.alt: A woman sits on the ground, with a young girl on each side of her. The woman and girl on the right look at something off camera toward the left, while the girl on the left looks at the woman. Plants obscure them from the waist down. Farm buildings stand in the background.
items.title: Agriculture. Women on farms. Like many another U.S. farmer's wife, Mrs. Harold Sontag of Maple Park, Illinois, takes an active part in the management of her farm but at the end of a long and active day, she still finds time to entertain her tow-headed youngsters with tales of farm life "when I was a little girl." Photo, by Ann Rosener, 1942

items.alt: A woman faces the camera while bending over and holding the oven door partially open with her right hand. She holds a pie in her left hand.
items.title: Vernon County, Wisconsin. Mrs. Saugstad about to bake a pie in her electric oven. Photo by Arthur Rothstein, 1942

items.alt: A man wearing a hat, glasses, and overalls, talks to a man on the right, wearing a tie. The man on the right holds a small metal box connected to an apparatus on the left by a cord. The apparatus is labeled, "CO-OP Electric Fence Controllers."
items.title: Westby, Vernon County, Wisconsin. Saugstad discussing an electric fence with the manager of the consumer's cooperative. Photo by Arthur Rothstein, 1942

items.alt: Two boys watch a man who is squatting down and pointing to a calf in a stall. Two other boys watch from over the stall wall on the left.
items.title: Vernon County, Wisconsin. Robert Saugstad and other boys in a Future Farmers of America (FFA) group examining a calf in the Saugstad farm. Photo by Arthur Rothstein, 1942

items.alt: A young boy wearing overalls stands next to a table, facing the camera with his hands in front of him. The table holds two buckets, a towel, and several jars. A picture tacked to the wall behind him shows a drawing of a farm yard with many animals.
items.title: Penasco, New Mexico. A boy standing in front of a picture representing "balanced" farm life, such as does not exist in this part of the country. Photo by John Collier, Jr., 1943

items.alt: Cross section drawing of a three story round barn with a cupola.
items.title: Hofherr Round Barn, County Road 650 West, Yorktown, Delaware County, Indiana. Historic American Buildings Survey

items.alt: A four-story stone and wood barn with hex sign decorations.
items.title: Decorated Red Barn, Between Limeport & Steinberg, Limeport, Lehigh County, Pennsylvania. Historic American Buildings Survey, 1941

items.alt: A green harvester rolls along the edge of a field of golden grain, under a cloudy sky. A dirt road runs along the edge of the field.
items.title: A harvesting combine kicks up dust during its work in a field near the tiny town of Carpenter in southeast Wyoming's Laramie County. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2015

items.alt: Dark clouds, with shafts of light shining through, hover over a road lined by utility poles with grain elevators in the background.
items.title: Ominous clouds above Pine Bluffs, a small farming community on the Nebraska border in Laramie County, Wyoming. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2015

$children.title: Free to Use and Reuse: Farm Life

description:
Traditional, scientific, nostalgic, commercial, and humorous views of fish and fishing fill this set of fifty photographs and prints from the 16th to 21st centuries. The pictures are from the Prints & Photographs Division collections unless otherwise noted.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: Smiling  woman sitting on the ground with a fishing pole and her bare feet dangling over the water.
items.title: African American woman fishing at the Tidal Basin, Washington, D.C. Photo by Toni Frissell, 1957.

items.alt: Pairs of men in several canoes that face into the water rapids.
items.title: Native Americans fishing at the "Soo," St. Mary's Rapids, Sault Ste. Marie. Color print, 1901.

items.alt: Boy leaning over water fishing with a home-made fishing pole.
items.title: Boy fishing. Photo, 1936.

items.alt: Naked men dive off single-mast sail boats (several with American flags) and retrieve sponges from the sea floor. A numbered key identifies 47 activities shown above and below the water.
items.title: Sponge Fishing. Color print, 1897.

items.alt: Four brown fish swimming near each other, with Japanese characters in the background.
items.title: River trout. Color woodcut by Hiroshige AndÅ, 1841-1844.

items.alt: Large building shaped like a fish with its mouth open.
items.title: Big Fish Supper Club, Bena, Minnesota. Color photo by John Margolies, 1980.

items.alt: A long row of men and women hold a net full of small fish. Sail boats are in the background.
items.title: Shad Fishing.  Fishers and Catch. Photo by Bain News Service, 1915.

items.alt: Seven men standing in a circle in knee-deep water are holding a net under the water.
items.title: Net Fishing. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1909-1923.

items.alt: Two white cats sticking their paws inside a small round fishbowl, where two goldfish swim.
items.title: Little White Kitties:  Fishing. Color print by Currier & Ives, 1871.

items.alt: Woman in a dress and hat sitting on a dock with a fishing pole.
items.title: Fishing. Color print, 1905.

items.alt: A small boy sits underwater and watches two large fish who are approaching him.
items.title: Oh, don't hurt me! cried Tom. I only want to look at you; you are so handsome. Watercolor by Jessie Willcox Smith, 1916, for The Water-Babies book.

items.alt: A 5 x 6 color grid illustrating a variety of reptiles and fish.
items.title: School and Family Charts ... Fishes. Color poster, 1890.

items.alt: Man with hat, suspenders and fishing pole poses next to a large fish.  The fish is upright with its tail on the ground and is several feet taller and wider than the man.
items.title: Edward Llewellen with the World's Record Black Sea Bass, which he caught, (425 lbs.), time 41 min., at Catalina Island, California. Photo by  Ironmonger, 1903.

items.alt: Color drawing of a large fish hanging from a string.  50 miniature fish drawings can be seen both on the large fish and elsewhere on the page.
items.title: Allen & Ginter, Richmond, Virginia. 50 fish from American waters. You will catch one in each package of Virginia Bright, ... cigarettes. Color poster by Lindner, Eddy & Clauss, lith., N.Y., late-1800s.

items.alt: Hand-drawn scene shows different types of fish swimming among underwater vegetation.  Beneath the drawing are the words:  "Visit the Aquarium in Fairmont Park."
items.title: Visit the Aquarium in Fairmount Park, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Poster by Robert Muchley, 1936 or 1937.

items.alt: Smiling, seated woman, fishing through a hole in the ice, with buildings in the distant background.
items.title: "Tom Kod Peluk," Inuit woman ice fishing for tomcod, Nome, Alaska. Photo by Lomen Bros., 1903-1907.

items.alt: Man sitting on a bucket and fishing through a hole in the ice.
items.title: Fishing thru ice. Photo by Bain News Service, 1910-1915.

items.alt: Shirtless man standing high on a cliff, sticking a large spear into the water below.
items.title: Wishram fisherman, Columbia River. Photo by Edward Curtis, 1910.

items.alt: Man in white shirt, bow tie, and hat stands next to the ocean with a fish dangling from his hook.  Two similarly dressed youths look on.
items.title: Japanese man surf fishing, Belmar, New Jersey. Photo by Bain News Service, about 1908.

items.alt: Large sign on the beach has the words:  "Galilee's Annual Events and Tournaments" along with numerous details regarding the activities.'
items.title: Tuna Derby, Galilee, Rhode Island. Color photo by Thomas Burns, 1979. American Folklife Center

items.alt: Barefoot boy in overalls fishes with a long bamboo rod while an adult man in suspenders watches him.
items.title: Man and boy fishing by shore. Photo by Detroit Publishing Co. 1910-1920.

items.alt: Young white girl in overalls and a big, floppy hat is sitting on a wood fence and holding a home made fishing pole with two small fish hanging from a hook.
items.title: Doris Gottscho, holding fish and fishing pole, sitting on a fence. Photo by Samuel Gottscho, 1919 or 1920.

items.alt: Smiling white, blonde-haired boy, wearing a striped shirt and standing next to the water with a fishing pole.
items.title: Kid fishing, Bonnet Shores, Rhode Island. Photo by Henry Horenstein, 1979. American Folklife Center

items.alt: Two youths crouch on their knees and extend fishing poles over a narrow water-filled ditch lined with tall grasses at the edge of a field.
items.title: African American girl fishing in a ditch, Louisiana Delta Project, Louisiana. Photo by Marion Post Wolcott, 1940.

items.alt: Three young boys cut fish on a table while an adult man looks on.
items.title: Three young cutters who work in Seacoast Canning Co., Factory #4. Ages 10 to 12. Work regularly, Eastport, Maine. (Sardines) Photo by Lewis Hine, 1911.

items.alt: Close-up view of fish hooks, line, and hook container.
items.title: George Washington's Fishing Tackle. Photo by J.A. Anderson, 1906.

items.alt: Bearded man in rain jacket smokes a pipe while fixing a fishing net.  An anchor attached to the net rests against building behind the man.
items.title: A Cape Ann fisherman mending his nets, Gloucester, Massachusetts. Photo by Detroit Publishing Co., 1900-1906.

items.alt: Man in orange overalls prepares to throw a fish at a fish market.
items.title: "Fish thrower" at the Pike Place Fish Company, Seattle, Washington. Color photo by Carol Highsmith, about 2000.

items.alt: Two boys hold large, round fruits in front of a roadside stand advertising the sale of fish and "Honest Weights, Square Dealings."
items.title: Roadside stand near Birmingham, Alabama. Photo by Walker Evans, 1943.

items.alt: Fishing trawler with American flag painted on the side, floating on the water.
items.title: Fishing Boat. Astoria, Oregon. Photo by Russell Lee, 1941.

items.alt: A fleet of fishing boats moored on the water with mountains in the background.
items.title: Herring Fishing, Norway. Color stereo photograph, about 1900.

items.alt: Drawing of three people on a boat.  The man talks and holds his hands apart as if indicating the length of a fish while the two women smoke cigarettes and listen.
items.title: Fishing.  Fish Story. Photo by Theodor Horydczak, 1935.

items.alt: Two men and one woman pose together with each holding up a fish they have caught.
items.title: Fishing.  Three fish. Photo by Theodor Horydczak, 1935.

items.alt: Several fish hang from a string, which has been nailed into a wooden wall.
items.title: Fish. Color print, 1898.

items.alt: Statue of large black catfish standing upright, wearing a shirt with an "S" on the front of it like "Superman."
items.title: A catfish figure in Belzoni, Mississippi, the farm-raised Catfish Capital. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2017.

items.alt: Man in tie and white apron displays a large fish, which possesses a long bill and tall dorsal fin.
items.title: Sailfish specimen. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1936

items.alt: Profile drawing of an entire fish and a separate close-up image of the top of the fish's head.
items.title: Tetraodon angusticeps (narrow-headed puffer fish). Plate 28 in  volume 4 of "The Zoology of the voyage of H.M.S. Beagle." Book illustration, 1839-1843. Rare Book Division

items.alt: Color page of book showing two groups of fish. The top illustration shows fish with black stripes on a yellow body. The bottom illustration shows fish with pinkish orange fines.
items.title: Sergeant major or Cow pilot (top) and Rainbow parrot fish (bottom). Color illustration by Hashimein Murayama in The Book of Fishes, 1924. General Collections.

items.alt: Two orange fish swim near the water's surface next to blooming lily pads.
items.title: Mission San Juan Capistrano, Southern California. Color photo by Carol Highsmith, 2012.

items.alt: Two women in long dresses throw food to fish in a pool. The fish have gathered near the women.
items.title: Feeding the carp, Park at Fontainebleau, Paris, France. Print after the painting by P.C. Comte, 1878.

items.alt: Portrait of  a woman wearing a fish-shaped object on her head and holding a fish-shaped object in her lap.
items.title: Woman wearing a hat shaped like a fish. Photo by Theodore Marceau, 1914.

items.alt: A smiling woman in a dress and cowboy hat holds up a bundle of fish she has caught to a smiling man in a vest and cowboy hat.
items.title: The Lost Trail: a comedy drama of western life by Anthony E. Wills. Color theater poster, 1907.

items.alt: Two boys and a girl stand ankle deep in a pond with fishing poles. The boys taunt a police officer who has confronted them from the shore; the girl looks worried.  Behind them a sign reads:  "Fishing and Trespassing Prohibited by Law."
items.title: What are you going to do about it? Color print, 1879.

items.alt: Man with hat and pipe sits on a crate on a dock fishing while a large dog removes a bottle from his back pocket.
items.title: The "Hooch hound" in action. Photo by National Photo Co., 1922. (Dog trained to detect liquor during prohibition.)

items.alt: Man stands on the end of a boat with his fishing pole line in the water.  In the background are pine trees and snow-capped mountains.
items.title: Mt. Hood (11,225 ft.) one of America's famous mountains, from Lost Lake, Oregon. Stereograph photo by Underwood & Underwood, 1902.

items.alt: Silhouette of a person casting into a large body of water with mountains in the background.
items.title: The Adventures of today are the memories of tomorrow: National parks. Color poster by Dorothy Waugh, 1930s.

items.alt: Page of book showing several people crowded into a boat holding spears while a giant creature, many times the size of their boat, swims nearby on top of the water.  The creature has a body and bill like a duck with fins like a fish.
items.title: A Monstrous Fish. Illustration in Thevet, La Cosmographie universelle ... (Paris, 1575). Rare Book Division

items.alt: Two couples are anchored in rowboats near each other.  The woman in one boat has hooked a fish that the man is bringing up towards the boat.
items.title: Black bass fishing. Color print, 1907.

items.alt: Color drawing of two men in a canoe; one man has hooked a fish that is being pulled up out of the water.
items.title: Field and Stream. Cover illustration by Osborne Mayer, Volume 20, Number 1 (May 1915). General Collections

items.alt: Print showing a trout with a hook in its mouth jumping out of the water. The text above the trout reads: "A good Trout Stream without any trout is like the play of Hamlet with Hamlet left out."
items.title: Paradise Brook Trout Co.  Henryville, Pennsylvania. (Trout farm) Color advertisement, mid-1900s.

$children.title: Free to Use and Reuse: Fish & Fishing

description:
In recognition of American Independence Day, also known as the Fourth of July, this selection of rights-free images showcases a variety of national symbols and flags from ancient times to the present day. Representing the rich cultures and diverse landscapes of the United States, all images are from the Prints & Photographs Division unless otherwise noted.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: Spotlight shines on a person wearing a black cowboy hat sits astride a dark horse holding a very large U.S. flag.
items.title: African-American Heritage Rodeo of Champions, Denver, Colorado. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2016.

items.alt: A bald eagle is perched on what appears to be a piece of wood. The bird's head is turned with its beak in profile.
items.title: "Old Abe, the live war eagle of Wisconsin, from the Centennial." Photo,1876.

items.alt: The banner resembles a  U.S. flag. Its top-left blue square has 33 stars around a sideways portrait of a beardless Abraham Lincoln. Text on white stripes in between red stripes reads, "For President, Abram Lincoln. For Vice President Hannibal Hamlin."
items.title: "For president, Abram Lincoln." Campaign banner,1860.

items.alt: The dome topped by a statue is shown against a blue sky and a white cloud.
items.title: Dome of the United States Capitol, Washington, DC. Photo by Carol Highsmith, around 2000.

items.alt: A yellow diamond-shaped street sign with a black bison symbol in its center is pictured in front of thin tall trees.
items.title: Bison crossing sign, Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2016.

items.alt: Photo shows the ruins of stone dwellings against the red-color walls of the canyon.
items.title: Ancient cliff dwellers in Canyon de Chelly, Arizona. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2018.

items.alt: A pair of tear-drop shaped earrings has the word "Union" in gold letters across a U.S. flag.
items.title: Civil War earrings decorated with Union banner, shield and American flag.1860s.

items.alt: A woman wearing a jacket and collared shirt sits at a table sewing a star onto a large U.S. flag. In the background, other women are sewing more flags.
items.title: "Mrs. Yoshiye Abe, an American of Japanese ancestry, helps to make American flags in a Denver factory." Photo from Office of War Information,1942-1945.

items.alt: The words "Votes for Women" are printed in large red text over two yellow pennant flags, the Liberty Bell, and a U.S. flag against a white background. Additional text reads "Price 10 cents."
items.title: "Votes for Women: Suffrage Rallying Song." Sheet music, with words by Edw.  M. Zimmerman and music by Marie Zimmerman, 1915. (Music Division)

items.alt: A close-up of the Liberty Bell shows the large crack at the center and the words above the crack.
items.title: Liberty Bell, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2013.

items.alt: A female figure wearing a silver breastplate over pink and blue robes  stands in the center of a colorful drawing with a vine border. She holds a staff in her right hand and looks at a scroll in her left. In the foreground are a shield, helmet, winged statue, and owl. In the background the sun shines above white clouds in a blue sky.
items.title: Design for the mosaic of Minerva (the Roman goddess who symbolizes learning and knowledge) at the Library of Congress. Study drawing by Elihu Vedder, around1896.

items.alt: A head-and-shoulders portrait of a smiling Black man is in the center of a red background wearing a blue baseball cap with the letter "B" on it.  A photo inset at bottom right shows two baseball players in action.
items.title: Baseball, Americaâs favorite pastime

items.alt: A large red, black, and yellow outdoor sign reads "Bowling, Tornado Alley Lanes" with a cut-out of a bowling ball and two bowling pins. A smaller white sign has black moveable letters advertising the restaurant and hours.
items.title: Sign for the Tornado Alley Lanes bowling alley in Abilene, Kansas. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2021.

items.alt: A corner building's exterior is covered with signs, each with text about hot dogs for sale at the walk-up counters below. Dozens of people are at the counters or walking by.
items.title: Nathan's Hot Dogs from boardwalk, New York City. Photo by Al Ravenna, 1954.

items.alt: A black four-door sedan spray-painted with "Delta Blues Alley Cafe Bluestand" and fire-like graphics is parked on the street in front of a small gray building. The building's sign also reads "Delta Blues Alley Cafe."
items.title: Clarksdale Juke Joint Festival, Mississippi. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2017.

items.alt: A group of seven children of different ages and heights stand in front of a very large U.S. flag. Several of the children are smiling and signing with their hands.
items.title: Deaf children of St. Rita's School, Cincinnati, OH, singing the Star Spangled Banner.Photo by J.R. Schmidt,1918.

items.alt: A large outdoor sign has a cut-out of a bear wearing a hat and blue pants with a shovel next to the words âFire Danger High Today!â Behind the sign are trees and shrubs.
items.title: Smokey the Bear fire hazard sign along the Appalachian Trail in Maine. Photo by Carol Highsmith, around 2000.

items.alt: A large black column topped by a world globe stands in the center of seven flags fluttering on poles and benches in a park setting.
items.title: A war memorial in Niles, Michigan, that features the flags of all U.S. armed services. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2020.

items.alt: A group of six soldiers wearing battle gear work together to raise a U.S. flag by placing its pole in the ground. In the background, a dark blue sky is above yellow light on the horizon.
items.title: "7th war loan. Now--all together." World War II poster by C.C. Beall,  1945

items.alt: An illustration shows a snake cut into eight separate pieces labeled with the  initials of eight areas from "S.C." to "N.E." Newsprint text columns printed below, above and to the right of the illustration's rectangular black frame.
items.title: "Join, or Die."  Illustration in the Pennsylvania Gazette, 1754. (Serial Division)

items.alt: On an ivory background with a couple of brown splotches from left to right are three graphic images. On the left is a woman in a red robe with a flag and a shield to her right, both in red, white and blue. At center left is what appears to be a brown, three-cent stamp with a portrait of a man in profile. On the right is a white house on a blue and green background. An address written in cursive below the white house image.
items.title: Civil War envelope showing Columbia with shield and American flag and White House. By Charles Magnus, 1862.

items.alt: A white man with a white beard and hair wearing a blue coat, white-and-red-striped pants and a top hat with a star in its blue band is holding a piece of paper in his left hand and a girl with his right arm. A boy stands in front looking at the man and the girl. Text at the bottom reads "Save your Quarters Buy War Savings Stamps."
items.title: "Boys and girls! You can help your Uncle Sam win the war." World War I poster by James Montgomery Flagg, 1917.

items.alt: The circular seal shows a bald eagle with outspread wings and a shield with 13 red and white stripes. In the eagle's right talon is an olive branch and in the left are 13 arrows. A blue circle with 13 white stars is above the eagle. Surrounding its head is a yellow scroll that reads "E Pluribus Unum."
items.title: Great Seal of the United States. United States Post Office and Courthouse, Athens, Georgia. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2017.

items.alt: A tall white stone monument in the shape of an obelisk. Surrounding it are green grass and a blue sky with a few white clouds.
items.title: Washington Monument.  Photo by Detroit Publishing Co.,1903.

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows a massive stainless steel arch at a moment of sunlight that brightens its left side and darkens its right side. In the background is a truss bridge with three arches.
items.title: Gateway Arch, St. Louis, Missouri. Photo by Balthazar Korab, 1960s.

items.alt: A flying saucer shape tops a tall steel tower that rises above green grass. A few trees with green leaves, and a clear dark blue sky are also visible.
items.title: Space Needle, Seattle, Washington. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2018.

items.alt: A long, two-story brick building reads "Jefferson General Store" in white and green paint near its roofline. Red, white and blue bunting drapes the entire front of the building. An antique, powder-blue truck is parked in front of the building.
items.title: Main street, Jefferson, Texas. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2014.

items.alt: Photo shows the Empire State Building towering over all the other buildings in the city skyline. In the foreground are the rooftops of even shorter buildings.
items.title: Empire State Building, New York City. Photo by Irving Underhill, 1931.

items.alt: Two people wearing Statue of Liberty costumes and sunglasses are raising fake torches while standing on pedestals. One costume is gold and the other is green with a license plate that reads "I heart NY." People are walking by, and the jumbotron screens are brightly lit in this night scene.
items.title: Statue of Liberty characters, Times Square, New York City. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2018

items.alt: A white road sign in the shape of a shield reads "Arizona Route 66" in black font. Above the sign, a wooden arrow points the direction to "Los Angeles."
items.title: Souvenir store on Route 66, Seligman, Arizona. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2006.

items.alt: A clenched fist held high is blue with white stars. Red and white horizontal stripes are in the background.
items.title: Clenched fist with stars and stripes. Protest poster, Gemini Enterprises, 1971.

items.alt: Side-by-side similar images each show a wooden roller coaster with two 360-degree loops.
items.title: Loop the Loop, Coney Island Island, New York. Photo by H.C. White, 1904.

items.alt: A building designed to resemble a huge red cowboy hat and equally large white cowboy boot is in the middle of a parking lot. Utility wire poles and a sign that reads "Texaco" are in the background.
items.title: Hat n' Boots gas station, Route 99, Seattle Washington. Photo by John Margolies, 1977.

items.alt: In the distance, a large white lettered signs reads "HOLLYWOOD" near the top of a hill that is brown with some shrubs. In the foreground is a palm tree and other greenery.
items.title: Hollywood sign, Los Angeles, California. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2012.

items.alt: A window display shows umbrellas, masks, feathers, and ribbons in the traditional Mardi Gras colors of purple, green, and gold.
items.title: Mardi Gras store window, Mobile, Alabama. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2010.

items.alt: A U.S. flag waving on a pole has 13 red and white stripes. Its blue rectangle in the upper-left corner has one large white star surrounded by a circle of 12 smaller white stars. A drawing of a small red building and text that reads "public school" with the same flag drawn above it is in a circle in the center of the flag.
items.title: "Little Red School House." Print by Dunn & Bro., 1897.

items.alt: A red frame surrounds the blue title words, which are printed above and below a waving U.S. flag.
items.title: "I pledge allegiance and silence about the war." World War II poster by Thomas Byrne, 1941-1943.

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows a U.S. flag waving in the wind.  Wispy, white clouds are visible above the flag.
items.title: Fort Knox flag. Photo by U.S. Office of War Information, 1942.

items.alt: A U.S. flag with 13 alternating red and white stripes and 36 stars evenly distributed in six rows in the dark blue rectangle at upper-left.
items.title: Thirty-six star flag. Woodcut,1860s.

items.alt: An astronaut's space suit is standing on green grass and holding onto the pole of a U.S. flag as it flies in the breeze. A white wall, green trees and blue sky are in the background.
items.title: Spaceman and American flag, Annawan, Illinois. Photo by Carol Highsmith,  2019.

$children.title: Free to Use and Reuse: Flags & Symbols

description:
Explore how friendships are depicted through images from the Library of Congress.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: Three seated men pose facing the camera with hands touching and arms on each other's shoulders.
items.title: Three soldiers in Union Uniforms during the Civil War, 1861-1865.

items.alt: Eight children holding hands and skipping in a circle on the sidewalk outside of an apartment building.
items.title: African American children playing "Ring Around the Rosie," Chicago, Illinois. Photo by Edwin Rosskam, 1941.

items.alt: Four women in long skirts, long-sleeve blouses, and straw boat and straw boater hats.
items.title: African American women seated on steps of building at Atlanta University, Georgia. Photo by Thomas Askew, 1899 or 1900.

items.alt: Man and woman sitting on a log with feet dangling in water. Woman is holding a wet dog and balancing the picnic basket.
items.title: "Sidney and Friends," Long Island, New York. Photo by Toni Frissell, 1958.

items.alt: Four young boys making funny faces outdoors for the photographer.
items.title: Prince Palden (second from left) making silly faces with friends, Sikkim. By Alice Kandell, 1971.

items.alt: Two men look into the camera. One is standing with his arm on the shoulder of the seated man.
items.title: Two unidentified African American soldiers in Union sergeants' uniforms during the Civil War, 1863-1865.

items.alt: Illustration shows two women in conversation. They wear kimonos with cherry blossom trees on each side.
items.title: Cherry blossom viewing month. Woodcut by Torii Kiyonaga, 1780s.

items.alt: Eight women in dungaree overalls and head scarves eat lunch and talk together at a long table.
items.title: "Women workers employed as wipers in the roundhouse having lunch in their rest room, Clinton, Iowa." Photo by Jack Delano, 1943.

items.alt: White man in hat with arm around a Native American man.
items.title: "Anglo-American and Indian friends, Taos, New Mexico." By Russell Lee, 1940.

items.alt: Four women seated at a table and holding playing cards; the two facing the camera are smiling.
items.title: "Bridge game, Nurse Hamaguchi and friends, Manzanar Relocation Center, California." By Ansel Adams, 1943,

items.alt: Three women talk and smile by a car parked in a field. Three children are with them, including a boy sulking at the front tire.
items.title: "Friends meeting at the Pie Town, New Mexico, fair." By Russell Lee, 1940.

items.alt: In a group of women standing outdoors, an older woman with serious expressions is listening to another woman.
items.title: "Funeral of a merchant seaman. Mourning neighbors and friends," Baltimore, Maryland. By Jack Delano, 1943.

items.alt: Seven men seated and standing at a table are toasting the groom who looks downcast.
items.title: "Farewell to His Bachelor Friends." By International Photo Co., 1905.

items.alt: Smiling boy in cap cuddles his black-and-white dog.
items.title: "Pals amid the ruins," Fresnes, France, after World War I. Red Cross photo, 1920.

items.alt: Two little girls, one Black and one white, are staring into the distance.
items.title: "Interracial activities at Camp Christmas Seals ... Camp Buddies." Haverstraw, New York. By Gordon Parks, 1943.

items.alt: Illustration shows three men smiling and clasping hands in the middle of their table at a bar.
items.title: "Three Friends." Movie poster, 1913.

items.alt: Illustration shows a young woman wearing a large hat, scarf, and muff walking with two small tigers on a leash following behind her and a college pennant with the initial "C" in the background.
items.title: College girl walking cats who look like tigers. By O. Jones, 1905.

items.alt: Seven seated women pose along two edges of a quilt. Several are smiling.
items.title: Ladies of the Helping Hand Society working on quilt, Gage county, Nebraska. By John Vachon, 1938.

items.alt: Three Native American women pose together, standing outdoors.
items.title: "Three friends,"  Wasco County, Oregon, 1902.

items.alt: Illustration shows two women standing and talking at the beach. One wears a long dress and has a closed parasol; the other is in a swim suit.
items.title: "Just Between Friends." By John Held for Puck magazine, 1914.

items.alt: Man in a uniform comforts a crying toddler held in his arms.
items.title: "First steps toward an Entente Cordiale ... American Red Cross Canteen at the Gare de l'Est," Paris, France. By Lewis Hine, 1918.

items.alt: Young girl looks up at the camera while sitting on a curb feeding a chicken from her hand and surrounded by other chickens.
items.title: "Her Feathered Friends." By Berry, Kelley & Chadwick, 1906.

items.alt: Little girl standing with her arm around the neck of a sheep who is almost as tall as the child.
items.title: "The Little Friends." By Melander 1877.

items.alt: Young boy lying on the ground reading a book with his head raised on one elbow.
items.title: "Make Friends with Books." By Elizabeth Wolcott, 1949.

items.alt: A woman and two men sit smiling and talking at a table surrounded by other people.
items.title: Between numbers, jazz drummer "Red" Saunders sits down to chat with friends at the Club DeLisa, Chicago, Illinois. By Jack Delano, 1942.

items.alt: Two men in military uniforms sit in chairs next to each other. One man has his arm around his colleague who has been severely injured.
items.title: The horrible disfigured man of war can not cool the warmth of the friendship of his old comrade. World War I photo by Red Cross, 1918.

items.alt: Two women sit close together, each reading a letter.
items.title: Two women reading letters together, 1860-1870.

items.alt: Five children are on a see-saw made of a ladder balanced on a barrel.
items.title: "Now we're up, now we're down, we can see all over town." By Berry, Kelley & Chadwick, 1906.

items.alt: Two girls in kimonos with parasols pose below blooming cherry trees.
items.title: Sumi and Sada Tamura, Tidal Basin, Washington, D.C. By National photo Co., 1925.

items.alt: Two women wearing kimonos whisper to each other while standing in a garden full of blooming chrysanthemums.
items.title: "A chrysanthemum secret." By Standard Scenic Company, 1906.

items.alt: A young boy and girl pat the nose of a mule.
items.title: Johnny and Kitty McLelland making friends with the farm mule ...., Escambia Farms, Florida. By John Collier, 1942.

items.alt: Two men look solemnly at each other and shake hands. The man in overalls holds a sledge hammer and the man man in uniform holds a rifle.
items.title: "The past is behind us, the future is ahead." World War I poster by Gerrit A. Beneker, 1918.

items.alt: Several men in military uniforms are gathered at a piano, smiling and laughing. The man playing the piano is concentrating hard.
items.title: "Sergeant George Camblair trying hard to provide an accompaniment for his friends' singing," Fort Belvoir, Virginia. By Jack Delano, 1942.

items.alt: Two men in military uniforms are shaking hands. The word "American" is on a banner in the background.
items.title: "Italian Front. New Found Friends." World War I photo by Red Cross, 1917-1919.

items.alt: Five women wearing lacy wide-sleeve blouses are smiling as they pose gracefully in a column at different heights.
items.title: Bessie Brewer and friends. By C.M. Bell, 1891-1894.

items.alt: Illustration shows Uncle Sam in blue coat and red-and-white striped pants holding hands with John Bull in red coat. Above them two women hold the country flags. Below are images from notable military battles.
items.title: "A union in the interest of humanity, civilization, freedom ..." Poster, 1898. (Symbols of United States and Great Britain kinship)

items.alt: Family members, 4 women and 4 young children, laugh while sitting on a front step.
items.title: Family gathering in New Orleans, Louisiana. By Carol M. Highsmith, 1995.

items.alt: Group of men gathered around a table in the "Cowboy Bar" with beverages in glasses.
items.title: In Denver, Colorado, good friends enjoy a drink and a laugh inside the arena at the National Western Stock Show. By Carol M. Highsmith, 2016.
