description:
This sampler of games from the 18th to 21st centuries features card games, board games, and such outdoor games as penny pitching and jumping rope. You'll also find bingo, chess, hopscotch, marbles, and singing games. Sometimes, the picture is the gameâa printed sheet of paper intended to be cut apart and played.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.title: Go. Color woodcut by Kiyonaga Torii, 1781-1789. Prints & Photographs Division
The donkey party game of putting the tail on the donkey. Woodcut and engraving copyright by Charles Zimmerling, 1889. Prints & Photographs Division
Sassony Arcade located on Broadway, Los Angeles, California. Digital photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2012. Prints & Photographs Division
The Ring Toss. Platinum photo by Clarence H. White, 1899. Prints & Photographs Division
Chinese-American girl playing hopscotch with American friends outside her home in Flatbush, New York, New York. Photo by Marjory Collins, 1942. Prints & Photographs Division
Juego de loterÃ­a. Relief etching by JosÃ© Guadalupe Posada. Mexico City: Antonio Vanegas Arroyo, 1909-1920. Prints & Photographs Division

William Howard Taft seated at table playing cards with his wife and two men on boat enroute to Philippines. Photo, 1900. Prints & Photographs Division
Mistakes will happen, written by Grant Stewart. Theater poster. Cincinnati: Strobridge Lith. Co., 1898. Prints & Photographs Division
Charlotte Amalie, Saint Thomas Island, Virgin Islands. Playing dominoes in a small candy store. Film negative by Jack Delano, 1941. Prints & Photographs Division
Playing Poker at the Ninety-Six Ranch, Paradise Valley, Nevada. Photo by Suzi Jones, 1978. American Folklife Center
Penny-pitching at the fiesta, Taos, New Mexico. Photo by Russell Lee, 1940. Prints & Photographs Division
Paper doll fashions issued by the Sunday Times-Herald Chicago.  Chicago: Shober & Carqueville, Chicago, 1895. Prints & Photographs Division
"Bingo." Sarasota trailer park, Sarasota, Florida. Photo by Marion Post Wolcott, 1941. Prints & Photographs Division
Snake game rules. Gameboard, 1840-1860. Prints & Photographs Division
Old age versus the cross word puzzle. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1925. Prints & Photographs Division
The Game of Fifteen, solved by the very merry mariner. Woodcut theatrical poster, 1880. Prints & Photographs Division
Children's singing game, Cat Island, Bahamas. Photo by Alan Lomax, 1935. Prints & Photographs Division
Singing games in the school yard, homestead school. Dailey, West Virginia. Photo by Arthur Rothstein, 1941. Prints & Photographs Division
Jawor's Fun Golf, dice, p.m., Roseville, Michigan. Photo by John Margolies, 1986. Prints & Photographs Division

Yorktown, Va., vicinity. Duc de Chartres, Comte de Paris, Prince de Joinville, and friends playing dominoes at a mess table during the Civil War. Photo by James F. Gibson, 1862. Prints & Photographs Division

Soldiers gambling during a game of cards. Shoulder patches identify them as members of the 42nd Infantry Division, the "Rainbow Division," World War I. Photo by Bain News Service, 1915-1919. Prints & Photographs Division
Will you make a fourth? World War I poster. Dublin: Department of Recruiting for Ireland, 1915. Prints & Photographs Division
Tuskegee airmen playing cards in the officers' club in the evening. Photo by Toni Frissell, 1945. Prints & Photographs Division
Washington, D.C. Soldiers waiting between trains playing cards in the game room at the United Nations service center. Photo by Esther Bubley, 1943. Prints & Photographs Division
Chess players on Market Street in San Francisco, California. Digital photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2012. Prints & Photographs Division
The Mansion of Happiness, an instructive, moral & entertaining amusement. Lithograph published by B. W. Thayer & Co., 1843. Prints & Photographs Division
Children of Mormon farmer playing marbles in the living room. Santa Clara, Utah. Photo by Russell Lee, 1940. Prints & Photographs Division
A quiet game of marbles. All the boys work in the Salisbury (N.C.) cotton mill. Photo by Lewis Hine, 1908. Prints & Photographs Division
Will Rogers [plays horse-shoes]. Photo by Bain News Service, 1910? Prints & Photographs Division
Jumping rope on sidewalk in one of the better neighborhoods of the Black Belt, Chicago, Illinois. Photo by Edwin Rosskam, 1941. Prints & Photographs Division.
Men playing cards in restaurant, Shellpile, New Jersey. Photo by Arthur Rothstein, 1938. Prints & Photographs Division
Family group playing cards in one of the new homes on the Hightstown Project, New Jersey. Photo by Carl Mydans, 1936. Prints & Photographs Division
Une expÃ©dition aÃ©rienne jeu instructif et amusant pour la jeunesse. Chromolithograph, around 1895. Prints & Photographs Division

New York, New York. Playing cards, using Braille playing cards, at the Lighthouse, an institution for the blind, at 111 East Fifty-ninth Street. Photo by Richard Boyer, 1944. Prints & Photographs Division
A chair and checkers set (in which bottle caps are the checkers) outside the general store, Jackson, Mississippi. Digital photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2017. Prints & Photographs Division

description:
Many different kinds of flower and vegetable gardens fill this set of international scenes from the 1800s to the present day. Unless otherwise noted, the images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: Blooming cactus plant and several smaller flowering plants nearby.
items.title: Flowers, including a blooming cactus, at the Desert Botanical Garden, Phoenix, Arizona. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, around 2000.

items.alt: Illustration of the fountain's center jet and tiered, color-lit basins. Chicago skyline in background.
items.title: Buckingham Fountain on Chicago's lake front. Poster by John Buczak, 1939.

items.alt: Overview of a walled flower garden with coastal landscape in background.
items.title: Gray Gardens, East Hampton, New York. Lantern slide by Frances B. Johnston and Mattie E. Hewitt, around 1914.

items.alt: Roses in several colors grow next to and around a lamp post.
items.title: Creative planting at the International Rose Test Garden in Portland, Oregon. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2018.

items.alt: A white boy wearing shorts and a tie uses a watering can to moisten several rows of vegetables.
items.title: Children's school victory gardens, New York City. Photo by Edward Meyer, 1944.

items.alt: Four African American children pose while standing in front of flowers by a fence.
items.title: Henry Truvillion's children (4 of the 5), in his flower garden, Newton, Texas. Photo by Ruby Lomax, 1940.

items.alt: Smiling scarecrow stands among vegetables in a small fenced garden.
items.title: Worker vegetable garden with scarecrow at the National Cash Register Company, Dayton, Ohio.  Lantern slide, around 1905.

items.alt: Blooming flowers flank a gravel path with stone steps leading to a wooden gate and arbor.
items.title: Flower garden gate at Beechgate, Englewood, New Jersey.  Lantern slide by Frances B. Johnston, 1918.

items.alt: Woman wearing a flower-patterned dress, is stretched out on a bench with her shoes off.
items.title: Government employee taking a nap on a bench in the Botanical Garden, Washington, DC. Photo by John Ferrell, 1942.

items.alt: Low dirt walls surround sunken rows of plants with a  desert landscape in background.
items.title: Gardens surrounding the Zuni Pueblo, in which are raised a variety of vegetables.  Stereograph by Timothy O'Sullivan, 1873.

items.alt: Corner of stone house with blooming yellow and purple plants in foreground.
items.title: Bartram's Garden, America's oldest botanical garden, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, around 2000.

items.alt: Crescent-shaped pool with garden park at left and skyscrapers in background.
items.title: Reflecting pool, Yerba Buena Gardens, atop Moscone Convention Center, San Francisco, California. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, around 2000.

items.alt: Stone pathway and low-growing flowers lead into a wooded area.
items.title: Pathway at Reef Point, Beatrix Farrand house, Bar Harbor, Maine. Lantern slide by Frances B. Johnston, 1920.

items.alt: A row of four men wearing aprons stand by potted plants; two are smiling.
items.title: Japanese American men work in a greenhouse operated by the Issei-owned Ozone Park Nursery, New York City. Photo by Stone S. Ishimaru, 1945.

items.alt: Site plan identifies trees, plants, and two houses.
items.title: Adams Garden, Quincy, Massachusetts. Delineated by Margaret M. Webster, 1936.

items.alt: Bird's-eye view illustration of the courtyard, gardens, and large fountain surrounded on three sides by the palace.
items.title: Paris. Jardin du Palais Royal. Lithograph by Lemercier from drawing by Philippe Benoist, around 1850.

items.alt: Frozen fountain in front of the monument with a sculpture of Washington on a horse.
items.title: George Washington Monument and frozen fountain, Richmond, Virginia. Stereograph by David H. Anderson, 1860-1870.

items.alt: Many children and adults (seen from behind) are looking at the two-tier fountain with multiple water jets.
items.title: Forsyth Park fountain, Savannah, Georgia. Stereograph by J.N. Wilson, 1860-1880.

items.alt: Potted plants flank a walkway inside a greenhouse.
items.title: Botanical Gardens, Washington, DC, approximately 1880.

items.alt: People look across a pond to the three-story museum building.
items.title: Kew Gardens, the museum, England, 1890-1900.

items.alt: A rectangular pool of water leads to the elaborate fountain with sculpture figures.
items.title: Luxembourg Gardens, the Medici fountain, Paris, France, 1890-1900.

items.alt: Plants grow in water with the wooden porch of a building at left.
items.title: Water garden, China. Lantern slide by William Henry Jackson, 1895.

items.alt: Design drawing for a octagonal basin with decorative figures in blue, yellow, red, and green.
items.title: Basin for fountain in the Winter Garden at Biltmore, Asheville, North Carolina. Drawing by Richard M. Hunt, around1895.

items.alt: More than 12 children and a teacher are in a narrow, fenced garden.
items.title: Kindergarten in a vegetable garden, Washington, DC. Photo by Frances B. Johnston, 1899.

items.alt: View across a valley with a few trees and buildings.
items.title: Garden of Gethsemane, Jerusalem. Stereograph, 1900.

items.alt: The heads of two children appear just above the flowers that fill a field.
items.title: A spring day in the Kabota iris gardens--children playing among the tall flower stalks, Omori, Japan. Stereograph by Underwood & Underwood, 1905.

items.alt: Men row in a boat in front of a multi-story, pyramid-shaped pagoda and palm trees.
items.title: Buddhist pagoda in the Burmese style, Eden Gardens, Calcutta (now Kolkata), India. Stereograph by American Stereoscopic Co., 1907.

items.alt: A large statue of a standing man with flowers in the foreground.
items.title: Statue of Linnaeus, Humelgard Park, Stockholm, Sweden. Stereograph by Standard Scenic Co., 1907.

items.alt: A man sits on the porch of a one-story log cabin with a yard filled with flowers and vegetables.
items.title: A cottage & garden, Alaska. Photo by National Photo Co., 1909-1920.

items.alt: Girls and boys pose by plants in wooden boxes on a roof.
items.title: Roof garden, Elizabeth McCormick open air school, Hull House Chicago, 1912.

items.alt: A rectangular blue pool flanked by flowers leads to a pergola in the background.
items.title: The story of the Blue Garden in Newport, Rhode Island, is a great way to learn about reading photographs.

items.alt: Wide grass pathway flanked by blooming flowers.
items.title: Flower garden, Mariemont, Middletown, Rhode Island. Lantern slide, by Frances B. Johnston and Mattie E. Hewitt, 1914.

items.alt: Several doves perch on top of a triangular birdhouse surrounded by a white flowering bush.
items.title: Dovecote, Gray Gardens, East Hampton, New York. Lantern slide by Frances B. Johnston and Mattie E. Hewitt, around 1914.

items.alt: Several people sit and stand in front of thick bamboo stems that tower above them.
items.title: Immense bamboos of the world-famed botanical gardens, Buitenzorg (now Bogor), Java. Stereograph by Underwood & Underwood, 1915.

items.alt: Rooftop garden filled with flower plants and vines.
items.title: Penthouse on a skyscraper, New York City. Photo by Bain News Service, 1919.

description:
This Free to Use set features family registers, family trees and photos, maps that document land ownership and more.

The Library offers many resources for researching your family history including historical newspapers, land ownership maps, tips on researching African American family histories and guides to the Library's genealogy collections. Consult the Local History & Genealogy Reference Services for help getting started.

description:
The William P. Gottlieb Collection consists of jazz photographs taken by the writer-photographer from 1938 to 1948, the "Golden Age of Jazz" when swing reached its peak and modern jazz developed.

Learn more about the William P. Gottlieb Collection.

description:
Selected images represent the historical experiences and achievements of people with Latino and Hispanic roots across the United States. A formal celebration of Hispanic heritage occurs each year in the United States between mid-September and mid-October. Unless otherwise noted, the images here are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

description:
You can visit many historic sites virtually through architectural drawings in the Historic American Buildings Survey, the Historic American Engineering Record, and the Historic American Landscapes Survey Collection. (HABS/HAER/HALS). The drawings provide fascinating perspectives on how a site was designed and can reveal parts of a building not easily visible. The Heritage Documentation Programs at the National Park Service create the documentation, which is made available online and preserved at the Library of Congress through a partnership that dates back to the 1930s. This selection is the tip of an iceberg that represents more than 40,000 sites!

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

description:
American Independence Day, also known as the Fourth of July, became a federal holiday in 1870. This selection of rights-free pictures can be used to reflect on how the holiday has traditionally been celebrated and also to discuss the complex history and symbols surrounding American Independence.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

description:
Selected portraits, events, and sites represent the historical experiences and achievements of Jewish Americans from the 18th to the 20th century. A formal celebration of Jewish American heritage occurs each year in the United States in May. Unless otherwise noted, the images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: Poster shows a group of men and women looking towards the Statue of Liberty with the Manhattan skyline behind it. A rainbow in red, white, and blue stretches over the statue. Yiddish text is beneath the image.
items.title: âFood will win the war. You came here seeking freedom, now you must help to preserve it.â World War I poster by Charles Chambers, in Yiddish, 1917.

items.alt: Two young women wearing protest sashes look at the camera. They hold small American flags with men and boys standing around them.
items.title: Labor parade, New York City. Sashes read âAbolish Child Slavery!â in English and Yiddish. Photo by Bain News Service, 1909.

items.alt: A large, 9-branch menorah is in the foreground with the White House in the background.
items.title: National Hanukkah Menorah in Lafayette Park across from the White House, Washington, D.C. Photo by Warren Leffler, 1979.

items.alt: Two Jewish men and two Black men in suits sit at a table with microphones in front of them. Several men and one woman stand in the background.
items.title: Committee for Jewish-Black relations. Photo by Bernard Gotfryd, 1983.

items.alt: Half-length portrait of a seated woman speaking. She wears a jacket and glasses with her hair pulled back.
items.title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg testifies at the congressional hearing for her Supreme Court nomination. Photo by R. Michael Jenkins, 1993.

items.alt: Large illustration shows women at the factory windows surrounded by flames. The text is in both Yiddish and English.
items.title: âDie Fire Korbunesâ (The Fire Victims). Sheet music cover for an elegy about the Triangle Shirtwaist Company fire, New York City, 1911. (Music Division)

items.alt: Sketch shows a large two-story building with a steeple and many windows, behind a wooden fence.
items.title: Kahal Kadosh Beth Elohim Synagogue (1793-1838), Charleston, South Carolina. Drawing by John Rubens Smith, around 1812.

items.alt: Harry Houdini stands looking at the camera, wearing a loincloth and wrapped in chains with heavy locks.
items.title: Harry Houdini, magician and escape artist. Photo by J.F. Blote, 1903. Rare Book & Special Collections Division.

items.alt: Seven baseball players in their uniforms (New York Yankees, Detroit Tigers, and Boston Red Sox) stand in a row leaning on their bats with people gathering in the stands behind them.
items.title: Hank Greenberg (far right) on the All Star baseball team, Griffith Stadium, Washington, DC. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1937.

items.alt: Man seated at a table, speaking and gesturing with his hands. He's wearing a suit, and an American flag is in the background.
items.title: Elie Wiesel, Nobel Peace Prize winner. Photo by Michael Geissinger, 1988.

items.alt: Poster shows a large matzo in the middle with a small box of matzos at the bottom. The text at the top is in Hebrew letters.
items.title: Kosher for Passover. Goodman's matzos. Poster by Robert Gage, 1963.

items.alt: Young woman wearing a dark sleeveless dress with a cameo broach poses with both hands raised in a gesture like animal claws.
items.title: Barbra Streisand, singer and actress. Photo by Al Ravenna, 1962.

items.alt: A female figure of Liberty stands at the left, and a bald eagle appears above the creators' names. The title appears at the top in Yiddish and English.
items.title: âLong Live the Land of the Free." Sheet music cover by Solomon Smulowitz and J.M. Rumshisky, 1911. (Music Division)

items.alt: Head-and-shoulders portrait shows Emma Lazarus looking to the left wearing a dark outfit with a white collar. Her signature appears below the portrait.
items.title: Emma Lazarus, poet. Photomechanical print after photo by William Kurtz, around 1888.

items.alt: Head-and-shoulders portrait shows Isaac Leeser looking to the left wearing a dark suit with a tie. His signature appears below the portrait.
items.title: Isaac Leeser, religious leader. Lithograph by I. Goldman, 1868.

items.alt: Head-and-shoulders portrait of a young woman. Her dark hair is pulled back from her face with a curl over her forehead.
items.title: Rebecca Gratz, philanthropist. Photo of a portrait painted by Edward Greene Malbone, around 1800.

items.alt: Front view of a two-story building surrounded by a fence. A porch shelters the front entrance. Large windows are on the first and second floors.
items.title: Touro Synagogue, Congregation Jeshuat Israel, Newport, Rhode Island, dedicated in 1763. Historic American Buildings Survey photo, 1971.

items.alt: A text-only title page with a quote from a poem by Byron and an 1871 acquisition stamp for the Library of Congress.
items.title: Fancy's Sketch Book. By Miss Penina Moise, Charleston, South Carolina, 1833. Title page for a book of poetry. (Rare Book & Special Collections Division)

items.alt: The large room has rows of wooden pews and stained glass windows. A pipe organ is on the balcony in the back of the room.
items.title: Interior of Kahal Kadosh Beth Elohim Synagogue (built 1840), Charleston, South Carolina. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2017.

items.alt: Certificate with text and blank spaces in the center for membership information surrounded by eight vignettes showing such religious symbols and scenes as a menorah and Moses with the Ten Commandments.
items.title: Independent Order of B'nai B'rith. Membership certificate by Louis Kurz, 1876.

items.alt: A large group of boys wearing cold-weather clothes and hats stands on the steps of a building. Some of them are holding newspapers under their arms.
items.title: Newsboys waiting for the "Forwards" Jewish paper at 1 a.m. ... New York City. Photo by Lewis Hine, 1913.

items.alt: Photo engraving shows Aleichem writing while wearing a suit and tie. Text above the portrait says âRussia Too Sad for Humorist.â
items.title: "Sholem Aleichem, Yiddish Mark Twain.â Portrait in "The Day Book" newspaper, April 16, 1915. (Chronicling America)

items.alt: Woman seated on a street car, wearing a hat and glasses, looks out at the photographer.
items.title: Emma Goldman, political activist, on a street car. Photo by Bain News Service, 1917.

items.alt: Man sitting in a chair looks directly into the camera. He is wearing a judicial robe and holding a multi-page document.
items.title: Louis Brandeis, Supreme Court Justice. Photo by Harris & Ewing, around 1920.

items.alt: President Calvin Coolidge stands at an outdoor lectern. A large crowd of men and women sit behind him, and a military band sits in front.
items.title: Coolidge at cornerstone laying of Jewish Community Center, Washington, DC. Photo by National Photo Co., 1925.

items.alt: Flier has a mix of typewritten and hand-drawn text. The information, including title, creators, location, dates, and prices, is in English and Yiddish.
items.title: "It Can't Happen Here." Jewish Theatre Project, New York City, 1930s. (Music Division)

items.alt: Einstein looks past the camera while holding the certificate in one hand and also shaking the hand of the judge who gave him the document.
items.title: Albert Einstein, physicist, receiving American citizenship certificate. Photo by Al. Aumuller, 1940.

items.alt: The poster includes information in English and Yiddish, including dates, location, and prices. A drawing at the bottom of the poster shows three people talking or singing while one of them sews.
items.title: "Dus Groise Gevins." Play by Sholem Aleichem. Poster for performance at Memorial High School, Roxbury, Massachusetts, 1938

items.alt: Shop window displays books with titles in Hebrew letters, candlesticks, and other items. A shield-shaped sign in the middle of the window says âGod Bless America/Itâs Great to Be an American.â
items.title: Window of a Jewish religious shop on Broom Street, New York City. Photo by Marjory Collins, 1942.

items.alt: Two men and two women stand around a scale in a field of beans. One man weighs a basket of beans while the others watch. Two are holding full baskets on their shoulders.
items.title: Jewish family who joined the migrants in harvesting the bean crop, Seabrook Farm, Bridgeton, New Jersey. Photo by John Collier, 1942.

items.alt: Half-length portrait of a middle-aged man wearing a U.S. Army uniform and skull cap looks down at a small book in his hand.
items.title: Chaplain David Rubin, Orthodox Jewish, of Long Island, New York. U.S. Army chaplain school, Fort Benjamin Harrison, Indiana. Photo by Jack Delano, 1942.

items.alt: Front page of a newspaper. In the center, there is a large illustration of a hand writing in âThe Book of Life Year 5716.â Below the book is a shofar (ramâs horn) with a New Yearâs greeting.
items.title: Rosh Hashonah issue of The Southern Jewish Weekly (Jacksonville, Fla.), September 16, 1955. (Chronicling America)

items.alt: Small octagonal building with a gated entrance surrounded by low stone wall and tall palm trees.
items.title: Beth Ha-Chaim, Jewish Cemetery Chapel, Charlotte Amalie, St. Thomas, Virgin Islands. Photo by Historic American Buildings Survey, 1958. (Sign above gate translates as House of Life.)

items.alt: Head-and-shoulders portrait of woman smiling while she looks into the camera. She is wearing a pearl necklace
items.title: Ann Landers (Esther Pauline Lederer), advice columnist. Photo by Fred Palumbo, 1961.

items.alt: Group portrait of eleven men wearing suits. They stand in a half circle preparing for a formal group photo.
items.title: Rabbi Joachim Prinz (center) and other Civil Rights leaders meet with President John F. Kennedy after the March on Washington, DC. Photo by Warren Leffler, 1963,

items.alt: Poster shows Bella Abzug's face--smiling widely and wearing a hat.
items.title: "This woman's place is in the House -- the House of Representatives! Bella Abzug for Congress." Campaign poster, 1971-1976.

items.alt: Two young boys wearing skull caps sit on a sawhorse used as a street barrier. A black and red flag on the barrier says âLet Our People Go.â Behind the boys is a stroller and a banner that says âFREE SOVIET JEWSâ and lists many Jewish American organizations.
items.title: Demonstration to free Russian Jews, New York City. Photo by Bernard Gotfryd, 1980s.

items.alt: Woman faces the camera while standing in front of one of her large, abstract expressionist paintings. She has short grey hair and wears a bright pink robe.
items.title: Lee Krasner, artist. Photo by Bernard Gotfryd, 1983.

items.alt: A sidewalk square shows two hands, two shoes, Douglas' signature, and the date â9/10/97.â
items.title: Michael Douglas' hand and shoe in cement in front of Grauman's Chinese Theatre in 1997 in Hollywood, California. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2012.

items.alt: The Jewish Immigrant. Vol. 2, no. 1. (January 1909). New York: Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, 1909.
items.title: Exhibition "From Haven to Home: 350 Years of Jewish American Life"

description:
This set introduces you to more than 11,000 color photographs of vernacular commercial structures, including restaurants and theaters, along U.S. streets and highways, 1969-2008.

Learn more about the John Margolies Roadside America Photograph Archive.

description:
This set highlights two opposite emotions--joy and sorrow. This collection highlights images from the Library of Congress that shows both. Unless otherwise noted, the images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: African American boy jumps over another boy, while laughing. The two-story public housing is in the background.
items.title: Anacostia, D.C. Frederick Douglass housing project. Boys playing leap frog near the project. Photo by Gordon Parks, 1942.

items.alt: Two girls - one white and one Black - face each other, smiling and clapping their hands.
items.title: Children's rhymes and games, Blue Ridge Elementary School, Ararat, Virginia. Photo by Patrick Mullen, 1978. (American Folklife Center)

items.alt: Young girl poses, facing the camera with a somber expression, while holding a picture of deceased solider in her lap. A brass mat with an oval opening surrounds the photo.
items.title: Civil war, sorrow:  young girl in mourning ribbons.  Photo, 1860s.

items.alt: Man wearing a short-sleeve shirt sits on steps in front of a large building, hunched over, with his hands pressed together as if praying.
items.title: Man sitting with his head in his hands, New York City. Photo by Angelo Rizzuto, 1958.

items.alt: Cover page of sheet music shows American soldier  marching and holding the United States flag, with a globe and people and flags from other nations in the background.
items.title: "Victory Day." World War I Sheet music cover for song by A.L. Gardy and Philip Haims, 1919. (Music Division)

items.alt: Two people dressed in rainbow colors, smiling, and marching in the street.
items.title: 2012 Gay Pride Parade, San Francisco, California. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2012.

items.alt: Men cheering  at a football game with their bodies painted in red with white letters.
items.title: Most of the fans wear crimson and white with the name of the football team on their garments at University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2010.

items.alt: Boys wearing football uniforms, sitting on the ground, looking dejected.
items.title: High school locker room gloom. Photo by Walter Albertin, 1950.

items.alt: Black wall etched with individual names and a single white rose on top.
items.title: National September 11 Memorial & Museum. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2018.

items.alt: Group of  women at the  headquarters entrance wave their arms in celebration while the ratification banner with its thirty-six victory stars hangs from a second-story balcony.
items.title: When Tennessee, the 36th state, ratified suffrage on August 18, 1920, Alice Paul, chair of the National Woman's Party, unfurled the ratification banner at their headquarters in Washington, DC. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1920.

items.alt: A small white girl runs along a sand dune, holding the string of a kite, which trails behind.
items.title: Toni Frissell's daughter Sidney as "The Wind" in A Child's Garden of Verses, Southampton, Long Island, New York. Photo by Toni Frissell, 1944.

items.alt: Book cover shows a beautiful young woman holding a pitcher of water and surrounded by flowering plants.
items.title: "A Child of Sorrow." Cover of book by Zoilo Galang, 1921. (General Collections)

items.alt: Three smiling dancers on stilts, wear colorful green, blue and yellow costumes.
items.title: Cuban dancers on stilts dance around Old Havana, Cuba. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2010.

items.alt: Close-up of a young white girl's face while she is laughing with her  mouth open.
items.title: Childersburg, Alabama. Cousa Court Defense Housing Project. Laughing girl. Photo by John Collier, 1942.

items.alt: White man wearing overalls and sitting at a kitchen table while laughing and drinking a cup of coffee.
items.title: Willis Cooper laughing and drinking coffee in the kitchen of his farmhouse near Radcliffe, Iowa. Photo by Jim Hansen, 1957.

items.alt: Illustration shows the head of dog, with a sad-looking face, looking over the back of a chair draped with part of a U.S. Navy uniform. On the background wall is a banner with a red border and a gold star at center.
items.title: "--Because Somebody Talked!" World War II poster by Wesley Heyman, 1943.

items.alt: Little girl crying while wearing an oversized crown and holding a scepter.
items.title: Jean Hunter crying at a mock coronation at the Madison Square Boys Club, New York City. Photo by Fred Palumbo, 1953.

items.alt: Young boy with curly hair is wearing a straw hat and sailor-suit blouse and holding an open box of the soap powder, which he might have tried to eat.
items.title: Child seated on crate, holding box of Pearline washing compound, and crying. 1898.

items.alt: A circle of eight happy women and men hold hands and move towards each other.
items.title: Square dance at Wyoming Dude Ranch. Photo by Toni Frissell, 1955.

items.alt: Black man and white man sit next to each other outdoors in chairs. Both wear caps. The White man holds an open bottle of drink.
items.title: Two men, seated and laughing, probably in the Washington, DC, area. Photo by National Photo Co., around 1920.

items.alt: Large multi-generational African American family sitting together and laughing, on steps in front of a house.
items.title: Family gathering in New Orleans, Louisiana. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 1995.

items.alt: Lithograph depicting the deathbed scene of Abraham Lincoln, which includes his wife, child and cabinet members.
items.title: "Death of President Lincoln: At Washington, D.C. April 15th 1865. The Nation's Martyr." Print by Currier & Ives, 1865.

items.alt: Graveyard with many long rows of small white headstones.
items.title: Stones River National Cemetery, near Murfreesboro,  Tennessee. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2021.

items.alt: Young white boy smiling broadly while wearing summer clothing and sitting outdoors in a cloth chair.
items.title: Childersburg, Alabama. Cousa Court Defense Housing Project. Laughing boy. Photo by John Collier, 1942.

items.alt: Young African American boy smiles brightly while wearing a yellow shirt and holding on to playground equipment above him.
items.title: Playground Safety. Meme by U.S. Product Safety Commission, 2017. (General Collections)

items.alt: Eight young Black children; two are riding in the cart while three are ready to push and run behind.
items.title: Black children playing outdoors with a toy go-cart. Photo by Harris & Ewing, around 1920.

items.alt: Small child with head covering bends over crying, while a boy and girl sit near him.
items.title: "Crying because he didn't get a fine new suit made out of American Red Cross pajamas. Rumanian children, many of whom have been outfitted with new clothes made of ARC blankets & pajamas." Photo by Red Cross, 1919.

items.alt: A smiling Black bride wearing an elegant gown and long veil tosses her bouquet to a group of six bridesmaids and a flower girl who wear the style of short dress and gloves.
items.title: Wedding with bride on stairs throwing bouquet to bridesmaids below. Photo by Robert H. McNeill, around 1950.

items.alt: Illustration showing  the two masks, one laughing (comedy) and one crying (tragedy).
items.title: "Oceanside High School Masque Society will present 4 one act plays ..." Theater poster by WPA Federal Arts Project, 1939.

items.alt: Before and after illustration. Top half shows man being tortured by tiny demons that cause various physical ailments. Bottom half shows the man destroying the demons with a bottle of Walcott's in his hand.
items.title: "Wolcott's Instant Pain Annihilator." Advertising print by Endicott, 1863.

items.alt: A young woman wearing a long skirt and blouse stands behind a tree trunk and covers her eyes, while her lover swings a golf club to chase away people who were watching them.
items.title: "On vengeance bent, the wrathful lover started, while Fannie hid her face quite broken-hearted." Photo by Keystone View Col, 1906.

items.alt: Man lies in hospital bed while a Red Cross nurse stands beside him with her hand on his shoulder. Another man sits on a chair on the other side of the bed.
items.title: One of the very sick men in Laennec Barracks, a temporary tuberculosis hospital in Paris. Photo by American Red Cross, 1914-1920.

items.alt: Illustration shows a woman in a nightgown and cap lying in bed and holding the hand of a man who sits in a chair beside the bed. The woman looks at the man, whose head is buried in his free hand.
items.title: "The Last Request." Print by J.C. Wild after Charles Fenderich, 1844.

items.alt: Illustration shows shows a black raven sitting on a tree branch.
items.title: Raven. Engraving by R. Havell after drawing by John J. Audubon, 1827-1838. (Rare Book Division)

items.alt: Illustration shows a smiling young woman in a white dress feeding a cherry to a white dove perched on her hand.
items.title: "The Pet Dove." Print by Charles Miller, 1872.

items.alt: Crowd of young women wearing white outfits, smiling and waving scarves above their heads while looking up into the camera.
items.title: Public schools athletic club, Photo by Bain News Service, 1910-1915.

items.alt: A group of young people seated together, many of whom hold instruments, such as guitars and maracas.
items.title: Guanica, Puerto Rico (vicinity). At a Three Kings' eve party in a tenant farmer's home in the sugar country. Photo by Jack Delano, 1942.

items.alt: Head-and-shoulders portrait of a white man laughing heartily while looking into the camera and wearing eyeglasses and a suit with a vest and tie.
items.title: President Theodore Roosevelt laughing. Photo, 1919.

items.alt: Facing pages of the diary have a blank page for February 13th and a black X for February 14th with the words "The light has gone out of my life."
items.title: "The light has gone out of my life." Theodore Roosevelt personal diary entry, February 14, 1884. (Manuscript Division)

items.alt: Collapsed one-story wood building with American flag hung on one side.
items.title: Barber shop located in Ninth Ward, New Orleans, Louisiana, damaged by Hurricane Katrina in 2005. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2006.

items.alt: A smiling older woman stands at a podium wearing a purple cap and gown and speaking.
items.title: Georgiana Farr Sibley, Life: "Great Ladies." Photo by Toni Frissell, 1968,

$children.title: Free to Use and Reuse: Joy & Sorrow

description:
Where do you like to cook or wash? This set covers many different settings for these daily activities from the 1500s through the present day. The pictures are from the Prints & Photographs Division collections unless otherwise noted.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: A modern stove top, refrigerator, ovens, and  microwave are surrounded by light-colored wood cabinets. A long black bar-height table, inset with a sink, holds a computer screen and has chairs and stools are placed around it. A sofa and chair are visible in the background below a wall hung with contemporary art.
items.title: Steinhardt House, Birmingham, Michigan. Kitchen and bar seating. Photo by Balthazar Korab, 2001

items.alt: A woman stands at a stove heating tortillas while a boy sitting in a chair looks on.
items.title: Kitchen scene in Spanish-American home near Taos, New Mexico, Taos County. Making tortillas. Photo by Russell Lee, 1939

items.alt: Three uniformed menâtwo wearing metal helmetsâstand around a wooden platform piled with animal meat. Another uniformed man in a helmet sits in the background with his arm resting on a wood crate that reads âBacon.â
items.title: Army kitchen. Photo by National Photo Co., 1918-1928

items.alt: A small moss-covered wood building has a cutout of a crescent moon in its front door and a sign above it that reads âOuthouse.â A large tree is in the background.
items.title: An outhouse, or outdoor privy, displayed at the Louisiana State Cotton Museum. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2020

items.alt: A sketch illustration shows a tiled room with a toilet, pedestal sink, and bathtub. A vertical mirror is visible on the back of the door. The word âCraneâ is at the bottom of the image.
items.title: Sketch for bathroom for typical U.S. home, about 1927

items.alt: Multiple metal pots and pans hang from a large rack suspended from the ceiling. A large table with a drawer is positioned below. A man in white sits in a chair at the right.
items.title: Kitchen, New White House. Photo by Barnett Clinedienst, 1902

items.alt: A group of uniformed men and women is working in a tight space around countertops and large vats. A man cuts a loaf with a knife as another man stirs with a large paddle. Behind them, a woman wearing a large armband with a cross emblem works at the countertop.
items.title: Kaiserin's Hospital Train â kitchen. Photo by Bain News Service, 1914 or 1915

items.alt: A woman in long sleeves and braided hair sits on the ground and holds a small child in her lap. Around them is an array of bowls and kettles. A cloth-covered shelter is visible in the background.
items.title: An Alaska Native kitchen outdoors, Nome, Alaska. Photo by Lomen Bros., 1916

items.alt: Multiple small angled bathtubs are attached to legs bolted to the floor. A woman reaches out to a baby sitting in one of the tubs. Other women and children are pictured behind her.
items.title: St. John's Guild. Bathroom on floating hospital, New York City. Photo by Bain News Service, around 1911

items.alt: An porcelain bathtub and toilet are in a half-tiled room. Rows of books line shelves across from the tub, and a porcelain sink is behind a dresser. Another room is visible through an open door on the back wall.
items.title: Ernest Hemingway's home in Havana, Cuba. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2010

items.alt: A brick fireplace holds wood to start a fire. A kettle, bucket, and pot hang in the center, and cooking implements hang along the sides.
items.title: Kitchen in the Stephen T. Mather House, Darien, Connecticut, initially built in 1778. Photo by Jack Boucher, 1964

items.alt: A table with a stool is in the center of the room with open drawers revealing baking implements stored inside. A stove, refrigerator, countertops, and cupboards flank the table along the walls. A stand mixer sits between the table and windows at the end of the room.
items.title: Kitchen, 1734 N Street, Washington, DC. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1920s

items.alt: A row of porcelain sinks below large windows and a row of towel hooks face are along walls in a narrow tiled room. Privacy partitions are mounted to the walls and floor in the background.
items.title: Bathrooms at Angel Island Immigration Station on Angel Island in San Francisco Bay, California. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2013

items.alt: A colorful barber chair sits in the foreground of a tiled bathroom. An aqua bathtub is near the chair with a monogrammed bath mat and towels. An open closet door reveals a half-size refrigerator on a wooden shelf.
items.title: Frank Phillips's bathroom, including a barber chair, at the Phillips Home in Bartlesville, Oklahoma. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2020

items.alt: A pink bathtub draped with towels is in a marble-tiled room. In front of the tub is a colorful circular rug with a standing scale. In the rear of the room are a large sink and a vanity stool.
items.title: Jane Phillips's bathroom at the Frank Phillips Home in Bartlesville, Oklahoma. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2020

items.alt: An engraving depicts a room with multiple tables set with various foods and kitchen implements. A basin is filled with water, and astove heats multiple steaming cauldrons. A man sits on a bench next to a roaring hearth fire at the back wall.
items.title: Kitchen scene. Illustration in Opera di m. Bartolomeo Scappi, 1574. Rare Book & Special Collections Division

items.alt: A colorful cartoon depicts a group of people moving chaotically in front of a hearth and mantel in a large room. Two people wearing white jackets appear to fight--one swings a large fish and one holds up a large fork. Four men sit on toy horses and hold shields of turtle shells and wear links of sausages.
items.title: A row in a city kitchen. Cartoon by John Leech, 1840s

items.alt: Six uniformed soldiers wearing caps stand near several barrels and a building made of logs. Another man holds a large ladle. The closest man holds an axe in his hands. Many pieces of wood are laid out in the foreground.
items.title: Camp kitchen during the Civil War. Photo in Brady Handy Collection, 1861-1865

items.alt: A colorful illustration depicts a woman in a long dress and apron rolling dough at a wooden table. A coal or wood-fired range and a rudimentary sink are behind her. Dishes, cups, pitchers, and pantry supplies are visible through an open door.
items.title: Prang's aids for object teaching--The kitchen. Print by L. Prang & Co., 1874

items.alt: An architectural drawing depicts two women in long dresses inside a large interior space. One of the women is bathing a small child in a tub in the corner of the room. The other woman stands near a curtained doorway.
items.title: Nursery bathroom in mansion for William K. and Alva Vanderbilt, 660 Fifth Avenue, New York City.  Architectural drawing by Richard Morris Hunt, about 1880

items.alt: An architectural drawing depicts three  painted murals of plants and a female statue. The room has a table with pitchers, a basin, and a large ornate tub.
items.title: Bathroom wall decoration in mansion for William K. and Alva Vanderbilt, 660 Fifth Avenue, New York City. Architectural drawing by Richard Morris Hunt, about 1880

items.alt: Two slightly different images provide a stereo view of a room with ornate wooden chairs and a table with spiral legs covered with a cloth. The table is set with silverware, scalloped bowls, water glasses, and multiple pitchers. An open cabinet with more pitchers on shelves can be seen in the background.
items.title: Kitchen in the ancient castle at Salzburg, Austria. Photo by J.F. Jarvis, 1898

items.alt: Two slightly different images provide a stereo view of a woman in traditional clothing who is kneeling on the floor and using a cutting board. Behind her, cooking implements hang from wood-paneled walls.
items.title: In a Japanese kitchen. Photo by Griffith & Griffith, 1900

items.alt: Two slightly different images provide a stereo view of men in matching hats, shirts, and aprons in a narrow room working beneath a large metal kitchen hood. A man in the foreground lays out dead poultry while a man behind him stirs a metal pot with a ladle.
items.title: The kitchen, Seroco Restaurant. Photo by Sears Roebuck Co., 1900-1910

items.alt: Two slightly different images provide a stereo view of people in traditional dress standing around two portable tables connected by a wooden rod. Several children are eating.
items.title: A portable kitchen, Java. Photo, 1904

items.alt: A colorful illustration depicts a woman wearing a red dress with a white apron and cap. She is spreading flour from a metal spoon onto a board on a wooden table. A bag of flour, a baking pan, a flour sifter, a handled canister, and a rolling pin sit nearby. A wooden barrel is on the floor.
items.title: A kitchen nymph. Print, 1905

items.alt: A table with drawers, a long ceramic sink with pedestal feet, a coal or wood-fire range, and hutch-style cabinets are in a room with a tiled floor. Another room can be seen through an entryway in the back wall.
items.title: Kitchen. Photo by National Photo Co., 1910-1920

items.alt: A seated woman in a dress and hat holds a glass bottle with a pouring spout labeled "Pyro" denatured alcohol. Another woman in a dress and apron stands behind a 3-burner appliance that can heat toast and other food. A container of sliced bacon sits on the table in front.
items.title: Kitchen appliance. Photo by National Photo Co., 1910-1920

items.alt: A dog in a gingham dress bathes a smaller dog with a washcloth in an angled tub. The tub is positioned on one end of a wooden table with folding legs.
items.title: The bath. Photo by Harry Whittier Frees, 1914

items.alt: A woman in a blouse, skirt, and apron stands stirring a bowl in a high-ceilinged room. A wood or coal burning stove, ceramic sink, and cupboard are visible to her right. Kitchen implements and canned goods sit on multiple shelves, and pans hang from the wall.
items.title: Lucy Gates in kitchen. Photo by Bain News Service, 1915-1920

items.alt: A step stool is positioned next to a refrigerator. The edges of countertops and a porcelain sink are visible in the background. Another countertop with wood drawers is also in the next room with a window.
items.title: Kitchen. Photo by United States Extension Service, 1925-1930.

items.alt: A woman in long sleeves and a head covering sits on the ground at a campfire. A blanket filled with berries is nearby. A frame of sticks over the fire holds pieces of meat.
items.title: A TsuutÊ¼ina kitchen, Alberta, Canada. Photo by Edward Curtis, 1927

items.alt: A large vertical mural of polar bears and penguins is painted above a bathtub in an alcove. Tile walls flank the tub, and a large rug covers the floor.
items.title: Bathroom with penguin decoration. John N. Conyngham, Hayfield Farm, residence in Lehman Township, Pennsylvania. Photo by Samuel Gottscho, 1934

items.alt: A man in a hat and long sleeves stands behind a seated woman in a dress. Three children stand in a line behind a small wood or coal-fired stove with a pot and kettles. A covered table fills the foreground of the cramped room.
items.title: Tenement kitchen, Hamilton Co., Ohio. Photo by Carl Mydans, 1935

items.alt: A woman in a dress and high-heeled shoes leans forward while opening a drawer in a white, metal range. A large open hearth next to the range is filled with  cooking implements. A cauldron, skillet, and flat irons are lined up on the floor
items.title: Kitchen. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1936

items.alt: A metal bathtub leans against the exterior wall of a building made from large logs.  A broom, chair, and basket are around the corner by the front door.
items.title: Bathrooms are scarce. Farm of ex mill-worker. Bonner County, Idaho. Photo by Dorothea Lange, 1939

items.alt: Ten tooth brushes hang on a line of nails in a wooden wall. A basin, bucket, wash cloth, and shelf of glasses are below the tooth brushes.
items.title: Toothbrush corner in the home of Mr. Robert McWhorter, Negro tenant purchase FSA (Farm Security Administration) client. Woodville, Greene County, Georgia. Photo by Jack Delano, 1941

items.alt: A soiled toilet with its lid propped open is in the center of the photo. A personâs arm in tattered clothing points down towards an opening in the nearby wooden wall.
items.title: Bathroom in house which rents for sixteen dollars a month. Norfolk, Virginia. Photo by John Vachon, 1941

items.alt: A man in a uniform holds his hands beneath water flowing from a sinkâs spigot in a wood-paneled room. His face is reflected in a mirror above which are signs printed with the phrase, âIf you talk too much, this man may die!â
items.title: Every man, a poster at Camp Hood. Photo of a poster, 1943

items.alt: An architectural drawing shows the floor plan and elevation for two bathrooms with a tub between them.
items.title: Bathrooms in National Homes Corporation. Experimental house "B" utility core. Architectural drawing by Charles M. Goodman Associates, 1953 or 1954

items.alt: A sink, mirror, wall racks with hand towels, and a countertop are in the foreground of a small tiled room. The edge of a toilet can be seen in the background.
items.title: H.F. Fischbach, residence at Hampshire House. Tile bathroom. Photo by Gottscho-Schleisner, 1954

items.alt: A short black-and-white advertisement film shows the companyâs contemporary kitchen appliances. A woman and her daughter are depicted finding multiple uses for their new refrigerator and freezer.
items.title: A kitchen is a feminine thing. Movie by General Motors, 1960

items.alt: A smiling man and a woman wearing long sleeve shirts sit at a Formica table with inlaid diamond designs and assorted condiment containers on its top. A white metal range is in the background adjacent to a long ceramic double sink. A colander filled with eggs sits on the drying platform.
items.title: Zane and Reinhold "Tex" Bonnet in their Kitchen, Nevada. Photo by Howard Marshall, 1979. American Folklife Center

items.alt: Five chairs are arranged around a table, and an electric stove is in the background. A braided rug is on the floor, clothes hang on the wall, and the windows are covered with light-colored curtains. A couch with a throw blanket sits off to the side.
items.title: Kitchen, Recanzone Ranch, Nevada. Photo by Carl Fleischhauer, 1980. American Folklife Center

items.alt: A woman in short sleeves and an apron stands behind a wooden table set with plates of food and condiment jars. Two white metal wood-burning ranges are side by side, one with a pot on top and one with and glass and plastic bottles above it.
items.title: Carrie Severt in kitchen, Allegheny County, North Carolina. Photo by Terry Eiler, around 1980. American Folklife Center

items.alt: A wooden door with peeling paint is shown slightly ajar and has a hand-lettered warning that reads âNotice V.D. Toilet For Scabies, Etc.â
items.title: The door to the bathroom in the old Ellis Island Hospital, Jersey City, New Jersey. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, around 2000

items.alt: A wooden table is covered with wooden canisters and boxes, two of which read âGarden Seeds.â A cast iron stove pipe connects to a wall above a wood mantel. A wood cupboard with drawers and an armoire flank a window with a wooden pitchfork leaning next to it.
items.title: Kitchen at Shakertown, near Bowling Green, Kentucky. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, about 2000

items.alt: A wooden screw press sits on a table bathed in sunlight from a nearby window. Bowls and trays fill the remaining table surface. Deep-set window sills hold assorted kitchen implements. A whisk broom and other tools hang from wall hooks between the windows.
items.title: Kitchen at Hancock Shaker Village, Pittsfield, Massachusetts. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, about 2000

items.alt: A wrought iron door with bars stands open between two painted brick walls above which the number â25â is visible. Inside the cell, a toilet and a small ceramic sink are attached to the back wall.
items.title: Cell and crude "bathroom" fixtures inside the old Ohio State Reformatory,  Mansfield, Ohio. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2016

items.alt: A long sink with pedestal legs sits across from a white metal range with multiple ovens and a hood. Assorted bowls are out on a countertop. Two open cupboards display food, condiment containers, jars, and canisters. A green and red seasonal wreath hangs from a window.
items.title: Kitchen of the Frank Phillips Home in Bartlesville, Oklahoma. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2020

description:
These portraits of Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Americans represent people who made a difference in many careers and time periods. LGBTQ+ Pride Month is often recognized in June. Unless otherwise noted, the images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: Laptop screen open to the Research Guide
items.title: Research guides can help you explore Library of Congress resources for LGBTQ+ Studies.

items.alt: Jack Baker and Michael McConnell sit together on a couch.
items.title: Jack Baker and Michael McConnell at home, 1970

items.alt: Bayard Rustin sits next to another man at a table.
items.title: Civil rights leader Bayard Rustin, 1963

items.alt: Walt Whitman and Peter Doyle face each other for a photographic portrait while wearing hats.
items.title: Walt Whitman and Peter Doyle, 1865

items.alt: Brightly costumed people parade along an avenue.
items.title: Gay Pride Parade, San Francisco, California, 2012

items.alt: Newsprint image of Pauli Murray accompanied by text.

items.title: Gay rights demonstration, 1976

items.title: AIDS quilt, Washington, D.C., 1990s

items.alt: Mary Edwards Walker stands for a photographic portrait wearing a tuxedo and a top hat.

items.title: Gay rights activist Frank Kameny

items.alt: Edna St. Vincent Millay stands outdoors and grasps the branches of a flowering tree.
items.title: Poet Edna St. Vincent Millay, 1914

items.alt: Newsprint image of Christine Jorgensen and Howard Knox accompanied by text.
items.title: Transgender activist Christine Jorgensen with her fiancÃ©, Howard Knox, 1959 (Chronicling America)

items.alt: Mercedes de Acosta poses for a photographic portrait wearing an ornate necklace.
items.title: Writer Mercedes de Acosta

items.alt: Oliver Sacks poses for a photographic portrait wearing a lab coat and holding a reflex hammer.
items.title: Dr. Oliver Sacks, physician and author, 1985

items.alt: Keith Haring poses for a photographic portrait while holding a paintbrush.
items.title: Artist Keith Haring, 1985

items.alt: Billy Strayhorn sits next to a piano while holding sheet music.
items.title: Jazz composer and pianist Billy Strayhorn, 1946 (Music Division)

items.alt: Christopher Isherwood and W.H. Auden sit together for a photographic portrait.
items.title: Writers Christopher Isherwood and W.H. Auden, 1939

items.alt: Bessie Smith poses for a photographic portrait while holding feathers in front of a floral backdrop.

items.alt: Natalie Clifford Barney sits for a photographic portrait in a billowy dress.

items.alt: Poster shows a group of nine women with different occupations and heritages.
items.title: A new era for women workers, minority women and lesbians, 1976

items.alt: Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdal pose in formal attire for a photographic portrait with sheet music between them.
items.title: Pianists Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdal, 1952

items.alt: Emma Stebbins stands for a photographic portrait wearing a patterned dress.
items.title: Sculptor Emma Stebbins, 1856

items.alt: Alvin Ailey poses for a photographic portrait with his head up and back to the camera.
items.title: Choreographer and dancer Alvin Ailey, 1955

items.alt: Charlotte Cushman sits for a photographic portrait wearing an elegant
items.title: Actress Charlotte Cushman, 1859

items.alt: Frances Benjamin Johnston poses for a photographic self-portrait with a cigarette, a beer stein, and her skirt raised.
items.title: Photographer Frances Benjamin Johnston, 1896

description:
People create libraries in all shapes and sizes to serve their local communities. This set of free to use images represents buildings in almost all 50 states of the United States.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.title: For greater knowledge, on more subjects, use your library more often. Illinois WPA Arts Project, 1936-1941. Prints & Photographs Division
Noyes Library for Young Children. Kensington, Maryland. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith,  2011. Prints & Photographs Division
Bethune-Cookman College. Students in the library reading room, Daytona Beach, Florida. Gordon Parks, 1943. Prints & Photographs Division
Public library in Antonito,  Colorado, near the New Mexico border. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2015. Prints & Photographs Division
Library and Innovation Center in New Castle, Delaware, defines itself as "a community learning and resource hub." Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2018. Prints & Photographs Division

"Bookmobile" bus belonging to the Perry County Public Library in Hazard, Kentucky. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2020. Prints & Photographs Division

description:
This set of images for American lighthouses primarily from the 1800s and 1900s can help you pick out landmarks that you'd like to learn more about. Lighthouses can tell many storiesâthe lives of their keepers, the engineering feats involved in their construction, and their roles in rescues and preventing disasters. All pictures are from the Prints & Photographs Division unless otherwise credited.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: Color photo shows a white tower and black lantern attached to a low building with a red roof and surrounded by green grass.
items.title: Heceta Head Lighthouse, Pacific Ocean, Oregon

items.alt: Color photo shows a  very tall tower with spiral bands in black and white. The base is red and surrounded by green grass.
items.title: Cape Hatteras Lighthouse, Outer Banks, North Carolina

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows details of the lighting mechanism inside the glass lens.
items.title: Bodie Island Lighthouse, Outer Banks, North Carolina. Lamp inside the lens

items.alt: Color photo shows a red-painted square tower at the end of a pier.
items.title: Holland Harbor Light,  Lake Michigan, Michigan. Also known as Big Red

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows a  white-painted tower on the beach. It is leaning over about seven degrees.
items.title: Cape St. George Light, Gulf of Mexico, Florida

items.alt: Map with a brown background for both land and water has a red starburst atop a vertical black bar to show lighthouse locations along the Atlantic Ocean coastline. The names of the lighthouses as well as cities, rivers, islands, and  bays, are printed in black.
items.title: A chart exhibiting the light houses and light vessels on the coast of the United States of America : from Maine to Virginia inclusive, 1848. Geography & Map Division

items.alt: Map with a brown tone for land and beige for the lakes has red symbols to show lighthouse locations. The names of the lakes, rivers, islands, bays, and channels are printed in black.
items.title: A chart exhibiting the lighthouses of the lake coast of the United States of America. Great Lakes, 1848. Geography & Map Division

items.alt: Black-and-white architectural drawing shows two elevations of a tall tower with windows and a black-and-white diamond pattern.
items.title: Cape Lookout Lighthouse, Outer Banks, North Carolina

items.alt: Color photo shows from a distance a white tower on a rocky shoreline with red-roof buildings nearby.
items.title: Portland Head Light, Casco Bay, Maine

items.alt: Color photo shows a tower with bands of red and white and a black lantern at the top.
items.title: West Quoddy Head Lighthouse, Lubec, Maine

items.alt: Color photo shows a  tower with white on the bottom and red on the top, at the shore's edge.
items.title: Barnegat Lighthouse, Atlantic Ocean, New Jersey

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows an octagonal tower with windows standing next to a keeper's house.
items.title: Lynde Point Lighthouse, Long Island Sound, Connecticut

items.alt: Color photo shows a short tower, painted white, with houses in the background.
items.title: Biloxi Light, Gulf of Mexico, Mississippi

items.alt: Black-and-white architectural drawing shows the exterior and interior of a tower with seven small plans for comparison to other lighthouses.

items.alt: Color photo shows a short white tower placed on a rocky point with a covered walkway to the keeper's house.

items.alt: Black-and-white architectural drawing shows the tower and several details of the entrance door.

items.alt: Color photo shows, at night, a short white tower above a house at the shoreline.

description:
Images from throughout the United States illustrate the variety of main streets or major thoroughfares in urban and rural America from the 1850s to the 2010s. The pictures are from the Prints & Photographs Division collections unless otherwise noted.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

description:
Scenes related to the sea through shipping, recreation, military, and daily life activities. Marine animals and river waterfronts are also included. Unless otherwise noted, the images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: Bow view of a historic vessel with bare masts anchored at a pier. The shipâs hull is painted, from bottom to top, red, grey, white, and black.
items.title: Ship Balclutha, international cargo sailing ship, San Francisco, California. Photo by Jet Lowe, 1988.

items.alt: Children wearing straw hats hold toy sailing ships in the foreground while men build a large, full-size wooden ship in the background of the shipyard.
items.title: Ship-building, Gloucester Harbor, Massachusetts. Engraving by  Winslow Homer, 1873. Published in Harper's Weekly.

items.alt: Bird's-eye view of a coastline with light-colored sand on the left and blue ocean water with white-crested waves on the right.
items.title: Oregon dunes along the Pacific Ocean. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, around 2000.

items.alt: A young sailor poses in front of a backdrop with a stone terrace and a manicured garden leading to a body of water.
items.title: African American sailor during the Civil War. Photo by Ball & Thomas, 1861-1865.

items.alt: A family of three people sits in front of their hide covered home with a dog.  A steep ridge with some snow is behind them.
items.title: Inuit family, Arctic Regions. Photo by Edward S. Curtis, 1899.

items.alt: A sea lion sitting on a rock is shown in profile with a drawing of a sea lion skull in the upper left corner.
items.title: Sea lion, Eumetopias stelleri, male. Color lithograph by L. Prang, 1874.

items.alt: A large three-masted ship at full sail with more than 30 white sails.
items.title: Clipper ship Three Brothers, 2972 tons: the largest sailing ship in the world. Colored lithograph by Currier & Ives, 1875.

items.alt: The large paddle steamboat âJohn Brooksâ is in the river foreground with sailboats and other ships. A large wharf with several docks and many soldiers is at the left. In the background, the large buildings include the U.S. Capitol.
items.title: Birds eye view of Sixth Street wharf, Washington, D.C. Colored lithograph by Charles Magnus, 1863.

items.alt: A group of nine white women and a girl stand in a line posing for the camera. All are wearing sailor-style shirts with dark bloomers. The girl holds a life preserver that reads âY.W.C.A. for Life Saving Only.â
items.title: Women's Life Saving Corps in action. A Red Cross life saving unit, San Francisco. Photo by Lothers & Young, 1922.

items.alt: A young man in work clothes and a cap sits cross-legged on a wooden bench. He holds a cigar in his right hand. The words on the back of the bench begin âEl Paraiso hay.â
items.title: Longshoreman. San Juan, Puerto Rico. Photo by Edwin Rosskam, 1938.

items.alt: Illustration shows a large sailing ship with many white sails in the center of the title page.
items.title: Moby Dick or The White Whale by Herman Melville. Title page illustration by Mead Schaeffer, 1922.

items.alt: Illustration shows about a dozen types of sea anemones arranged in a decorative layout.
items.title: Actiniae - Seeanemonen (Sea anemones). Illustration by Adolf Giltsch after sketch by Ernst Haeckel in Kunstformen der Natur, 1904.

items.alt: A sail boat with one yellow and one blue-and-white-striped sail is at the shoreline. Several people inside the boat watch while a few men push the boat off the beach and into the ocean.
items.title: Hawaii. Photo by Toni Frissell, 1957.

items.alt: Illustration shows a woman wearing a large hat with a feather and a long coat over pants. She holds a sword in her right hand and a pirateâs flag in her left hand.
items.title: Portrait of the female pirate. Title page illustration for the novel: Fanny Campbell, the Female Pirate Captain, by Maturin Murray Ballou, 1845. Rare Book Division

items.alt: Poster with a yellow and pink background shows a pair of long dark legs in pants making a long stride towards land across a bay. The text below his legs says âBy land or water. 250 feet above sea level. No mosquitos!â
items.title: Just one long step to Sea Cliff, L.I. (Long Island, New York). Poster, 1936-1939.

items.alt: A whale thrashing in the foreground spouts water from its blowhole while a small boat with six whalers are poised to attack from its left side. In the background, a ship with sails waits with dark smoke billowing out of its smokestacks.
items.title: Whale Fishery: Attacking a Right Whale. Lithograph by Currier & Ives, mid-1800s.

items.alt: A large naval warship with three rows of cannons is in the center of the print with bare masts flying several flags. Nautical instruments and rigging pieces are illustrated on three sides of the print.
items.title: The Ship & Its Furniture. Color lithograph by L. Brechemin and P.S. Duval, mid-1800s. (Naval warship)

items.alt: A large group of African-American men are sitting and standing on a wharf to take this portrait. All of the men wear hats and several hold shovels or tools. Masts of sailing ships appear behind them.
items.title: Quartermaster's Wharf, Alexandria, Va. Photo taken during the American Civil War, 1861-1865.

items.alt: The map-like view shows the city from above at the confluence of two rivers near the ocean. Wharves, streets, and landmarks are identified.
items.title: Bird's eye view of the city of Charleston, South Carolina. Color lithograph by C.N. Drie, 1872.

items.alt: Illustration shows a waterfront street crowded with people, horse-drawn carts, and wagons loaded with crates in the foreground. Large buildings, a locomotive, and masts of many ships are in the background.
items.title: At Dock Street wharf, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Engraving by James Louderbach after painting by Schell & Hogan, 1875.

items.alt: Two sailboats, each with two masts and sails, float near the coastline in water that reflects the golden colors of the sunset.
items.title: Sunset in Rockland Harbor, Maine. Chromolithograph by Louis K. Harlow and L. Prang & Co., 1896.

items.alt: Two large sailboats with tall masts have come aground on a wharf. A man and a boy observe the damage. Debris litters the ground.
items.title: Galveston disaster, high and dry, schooners on wharf, Texas. Stereograph photo published by M.H. Zahner, 1900.

items.alt: Many ships with sails furled are at the wharves, and horse-drawn wagons loaded with freight fill the waterfront street. The busy scene shows the Brooklyn Bridge in the background.
items.title: South Street and Brooklyn Bridge, New York City. Photochrom print by Detroit Publishing Co., 1901.

items.alt: Illustration shows Teddy Roosevelt is wearing a yellow hat and slicker and holding the ship helm in his hands.
items.title: 1902 finds the helm in safe hands. (Teddy Roosevelt steering the ship of state) Chromolithograph by Udo Keppler for the cover of Puck magazine, 1902.

items.alt: Illustration displays the varied shapes of more than 20 foraminifera arranged in decorative pattern.
items.title: Thalamophora - Kammerlinge (Foraminifer). Illustration by Adolf Giltsch after sketch by Ernst Haeckel in Kunstformen der Natur, 1904.

items.alt: Three boys wearing caps are using large knives to cut  fish on a table. A barrel and a basket are nearby.
items.title: Shows the way they cut the fish in sardine canneries. ... "The salt gits in the cuts an' they ache." Location: Eastport, Maine. Photo by Lewis Hine, 1911.

items.alt: An airplane floats in the water next to a beach where several men are sitting or walking around near plants with palm fronds.
items.title: Amphibious plane, Florida Keys. Photo by Albert M. Price, around 1920.

items.alt: Fine art print shows several surfers standing on their boards while riding a large wave towards the shore.
items.title: Surf riders, Honolulu. Woodcut by Charles W. Bartlett, 1920.

items.alt: A dramatic close-up view of the ship under construction, with scaffolding on either side.
items.title: U.S.S. Washington battleship - unique bow view, Camden, New Jersey. Photo, 1921.

items.alt: The silhouette of a traditional Hawaiian canoe and its occupants floats in the middle ground. The sky above them is lit up with the rays of the sun, partially blocked by a dark cloud.
items.title: Hawaiian canoe in Honolulu harbor. Photo by James .J. Williams, 1922.

items.alt: Four sailors in uniform are kneeling on a ship deck while holding a monkey and parrots and looking directly into the camera.
items.title: Massachusetts Nautical School. Photo by National Photo Co., 1923.

items.alt: Strips of meat hang from poles high above the ground, with an Indigenous person and a body of water in the background.
items.title: Drying whale meat--Hooper Bay, Alaska. Photo by Edward S. Curtis, 1929.

items.alt: Fine art print shows a yellow house with a rowboat beside it facing the street and a brown dock behind it over the water. Sailboats are in the background.
items.title: My wharf studio, Provincetown, Massachusetts. Color woodcut by Blanche Lazzell, 1937.

items.alt: A very large ship is under construction. A supportive frame surrounds the ship with two tall posts in the middle. Another large ship is under construction on the right.
items.title: Newport News, Virginia. A C-3 passenger and cargo boat. Photo by Alfred T. Palmer, 1941.

items.alt: Three women are brushing paint on an overturned boat.
items.title: Assault boat production for U.S. Marine Corps. Women workers apply preservative waterproof paint to bottom of boat which is nearing completion. Goodyear, Akron, Ohio. Photo by Alfred T. Palmer, 1941.

items.alt: Illustration shows a powerful coast guard boat moving through the waves beneath a cloud-filled blue sky.
items.title: Operators of small boats enlist now! U.S. Coast Guard. World War II recruiting poster in New Orleans, Louisiana. By Thomas A. Byrne, 1941-1943.

items.alt: A man with dark hair and a mustache poses on a boat in his deep sea diving suit while holding the large helmet in front of him.
items.title: Tarpon Springs, Florida. A Greek-American deep sea sponge diver with his helmet. Photo for U.S. Office of War Information, 1944.

items.alt: An underwater photo with actors in scuba diving gear gathered in a circle for a scene in the movie. Streams of bubbles and small fish float above their heads.
items.title: Filming the movie "Twenty-thousand Leagues Under the Sea." Photo by Charlotte Brooks, 1954

items.alt: The bow of the ocean liner appears to reach over the dock where several men and women are looking up at her. A woman in the foreground is aiming her camera at the large ship.
items.title: Spectators standing in front of the Queen Elizabeth ocean liner and Carol Moran tugboat at dock, New York City. Photo by Angel Rizzuto, 1959.

items.alt: Four men are shown inside the submarine. Two have their backs to the camera.
items.title: Men working with machinery on the Skipjack atomic submarine (SSN-585). Photo by Thomas H. O'Halloran, 1959

items.alt: A  beach scene with many people sunbathing, walking along the water's edge, or standing in the shallow water. On the left side is a boardwalk that curves into the background and is lined with buildings of different heights.
items.title: Beach, boardwalk overall, Ocean City, New Jersey. Photo by John Margolies, 1978.

items.alt: A blue sign on a wood pole in green grass says âHelp Our Ocean Cityâs Dune Experiments!â A sand beach with several buildings are in the background.
items.title: Dune preservation experiment, Ocean City, Maryland. Photo by John Margolies, 1985.

items.alt: Two men are hauling oysters into the boat, near the mast with a furled sail.
items.title: Port dredge basket being hauled with oysters. Kathryn, a two-sail Bateau "Skipjack," Dogwood Harbor, Chesapeake Bay, Tilghman, Maryland. Photo by Jet Lowe, 1997 or 1998.

items.alt: Men fish while seated on a bench on a wooden pier. In the background ocean waves roll onto the sand with a row of houses near the shoreline.
items.title: Surf fishing from the Hatteras pier on North Carolina's Outer Banks. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, about 2000.

items.alt: Three carved and painted figureheads of white men wearing outfits from different eras and facing forward with chins up and chests out.
items.title: Wooden ship's figureheads are featured at the Mystic Seaport Maritime Museum in Mystic, Connecticut. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, about 2000.

items.alt: A white-painted tugboat with a lot of rust and no glass in its top windows sits on sand and grass.
items.title: S.S. Hurricane Camille after Hurricane Katrina, Gulfport, Mississippi. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2006.

items.alt: A yellow seahorse has wrapped its tail around a thin vertical plant or anemone.
items.title: Seahorse at Monterey Bay Aquarium, Monterey, California. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2012.

items.alt: Four dolphins leap above the fountain's water jets.
items.title: Dolphin Fountain, Monterey Bay, California on the Pacific Ocean. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2012.

items.alt: Person in bright orange overalls and a red baseball cap is sorting fish parts in tubs on a dock.
items.title: A fishery worker processes a catch in Morro Bay on California's Central Coast. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2013.

items.alt: A large ship loaded high with hundreds of shipping containers in different colors moves through the middle of the river.
items.title: With a tugboat's help, a heavy-laden oceangoing container ship plies the busy Savannah River in Savannah, Georgia. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2017.

description:
From splendid color images of classic theaters to beautiful historical film posters to snapshots of American moviegoing life, our collections offer a robust and diverse cross-section of images devoted to movie theaters.

The Library has thousands of photos available online and many more can be viewed in person when you visit the Prints & Photographs Reading Room.

Browse more content that is free to use and reuse.
