description:
Selected images represent the historical experiences and achievements of indigenous peoples across North America. A formal celebration of Native American heritage occurs each year in the United States in November. Unless otherwise noted, the images here are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: Atene sits on a rock holding the baby in a cradleboard. Yazzie stands behind her. They wear brightly colored clothing, and the sandstone buttes in the background.
items.title: Loretta Yazzie, Eula M. Atene, and 3-month old Leon Clark (Navajo) pose in Monument Valley Navajo Tribal Park. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2018.

items.alt: Illustration shows four women and lists their names, organizational affiliations, and the time, date, and location of a program.
items.title: Public forum: Native American women in action: many fronts, one struggle. Poster design by D. Barnes and M. Hatch, 1976.

items.alt: David Blackbird holds a U.S. flag while entering a powwow dance circle during grand entry. He is wearing dance regalia in yellow, red, and many other colors.
items.title: Friday Night Grand Entry Starts. Leading the Grand Entry is David Blackbird, Omaha powwow, Macy, Nebraska. Photo by Carl Fleischhauer, 1983. American Folklife Center

items.alt: Illustration of Sequoya holding a document and pointing at characters of the syllabary. He is smoking a pipe and wearing a medallion around his neck.
items.title: Sequoyah holding the syllabary he created for writing the Cherokee language. Portrait print by John T. Bowen, 1838.

items.alt: Photograph shows a demure bride, and solemn groom, standing slightly off-center and overshadowed by large group of wedding guests surrounding them outside building.
items.title: Alaska Native wedding, St. Michael, Alaska. Created around 1906. Photo by Huey and Laws, 1906.

items.alt: Joy Harjo looks at the camera. She is wearing long earrings, and the U.S. Capitol is behind her.
items.title: U.S. Poet Laureate Joy Harjo. Photo by Shawn Miller, 2019.

items.alt: Illustration of Red Cloud standing at a podium and making a speech to a large audience in a great hall.
items.title: The Sioux Chief Red Cloud, in the Great Hall of the Cooper Institute, addressing a New York audience on the wrongs done to his people. Created in 1870. Wood engraving published in Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper, 1820.

items.alt: Council committee members sit at tables and listen to a speaker standing at another table. The tables are arranged in a rectangle. The walls of the room are covered with murals.
items.title: Navajo Tribal Council committee members listening to industry presentations, in the Council House in Window Rock, Arizona. Photo by Thomas OâHalloran, 1966.

items.alt: Shirl Bates stands holding feathers and a pair of photographs. She is wearing blue clothing and standing in front of a gray background.
items.title: Shirl Bates, of Chickasaw descent, photographed in Pueblo, Colorado, at a gathering of Native Americans. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2015.

items.alt: A man walks past the tipi, and a few people stand at a table nearby. The Washington Monument is in the background.
items.title: Tipi with sign "American Indian Movement" on the grounds of the Washington Monument, Washington, D.C. Photo by Warren K. Leffler, 1978.

items.alt: Half-length portrait, wearing eagle feather headdress. He faces the camera while also looking away from the photographer.
items.title: Chief Joseph, Nez PercÃ©. Photograph by Gill De Lancey, 1900

items.alt: A group of people stand in front of the adobe buildings. Mountains rise in the background.
items.title: Taos Pueblo, New Mexico. Photo by Cunningham and Co., 1880-1890.

items.alt: Clale Northrup and Barbara Ferguson look at the camera while sitting on a fence. They are wearing cowboy hats.
items.title: Clale Northrup (Paiute Nation) and Barbara Ferguson at the McDermitt Paiute Indian Reservation Rodeo. Photo by Howard W. Marshall, 1981. American Folklife Center

items.alt: Articles written in English and Cherokee cover a newspaper page. The paperâs title block includes an image of a phoenix rising from a fire.
items.title: Front page of the Cherokee Phoenix newspaper from April 10, 1828.

items.alt: A person sits at a large loom weaving a colorful patterned blanket. The weaver is wearing green.
items.title: A Navajo blanket weaver. Created 1901.

items.alt: An unfurled Navajo blanket. The blanket is red with black, white, green, and yellow geometric shapes.
items.title: Navajo blanket. Photo created 1900-1920.

items.alt: Tootch-Wu-Wu sits for a portrait wearing a beaded hat and shirt.
items.title: Tootch-Wu-Wu, an Alaksa Native woman, from Hoonah, Alaska. Photo by Case and Draper, around 1907.

items.alt: A beige poster with brown type advertises the 153rd Annual Omaha Tribal Pow-Wow, including the place, dates, events, and prices. It includes a photo of a He-Thu-Shka dancer.
items.title: 153rd Annual Omaha Tribal Pow-Wow Poster. Created 1983.

items.alt: A mural with two men wearing headgear and holding green plants, facing a woman and two children. One man stands and holds out his arm while the other kneels and grasps one of the children by the ankle.
items.title: Mural showing Navajo scenes by artist Gerald Nailor at the Interior Department Building, Washington, D.C. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2012.

items.alt: Jim Thorpe, wearing a pinstriped baseball cap and uniform, stands in a ballpark.
items.title: Jim Thorpe, New York National League, at Polo Grounds, NY. Photo by Bain News Service, 1913.

items.alt: A woman wearing glasses holds up a buckskin dress with fringe and a long beaded accessory.
items.title: Daughter of Ethel Cavanaugh (Paiute Nation), holding fancy buckskin dress that she made. Photo by Thomas Vennum, 1978. American Folklife Center

items.alt: Illustration of John Ross sitting at a desk, with his right hand on a paper that states "Protest and Memorial of the Cherokee Nation Sept. 1836".
items.title: Cherokee Chief John Ross. Lithograph by John T. Bowen for McKenney & Hall, 1843.

items.alt: Illustration shows a large group of men running on a large field carrying stickball sticks. Green hills stand in the background.
items.title: Choctaw men playing stickball. Lithograph from a painting by George Catlin, published 1844.

items.alt: Three people paint on a hide next to a log building.
items.title: Blackfeet  (Sihasapa) woman and men painting history. Photo by Bain News Service, 1910s.

items.alt: Douglas Esau wears dance regalia and stands by a dance ring eating a snow cone. Spectators sit on bleachers behind him.
items.title: Douglas Esau, a young traditional dancer. Photo by Dorothy Sara Lee, 1983. American Folklife Center

items.alt: Illustration of a man in elaborate attire dancing.
items.title: Eagle Dancer. Silkscreen print by Woody Crumbo around 1952.

items.alt: A group of people are gathered together on the porch of a log building
items.title: Indigenous people outside a log building in Alaska. Photo created between 1900 and 1916.

items.alt: A black-and-white poster shows an adult and a child standing in the foreground. Behind them is a line of silhouetted people carrying rifles with bayonets.
items.title: We remember Wounded Knee, 1890-1973. Poster created by Bruce Carter between 1973 and 1980.

items.alt: Illustration of John Brant posing for a portrait wearing headwear.
items.title: Joseph Fayadaneega, called the Brant, the Great Captain of the Six Nations. Engravign by John R. Smith from a painting by George Romney, around 1776.

items.alt: Chitto Harjo poses for a portrait wearing a vest and neckerchief.
items.title: Muscogee Creek Nation leader Chitto Harjo. Photo by Duncan around 1903.

items.alt: A map of the coast of Virginia with two ships and a sea monster in the foreground. Below the map is lengthy text in German.
items.title: The arrival of Englishmen in Virginia (Map of the coast with an Algonquin village shown on Roanoake Island). Engraving by Theodor de Bry from a watercolor by John White, 1590.

items.alt: Stancil Powell and Gus Welch stand side by side wearing football uniforms. Other players are visible at the edges of the image.
items.title: Stancil Powell and Gus Welch. Photo by Bain News Service, around 1910.

items.alt: A disc-shaped mural depicts different scenes within four quadrants, including human figures.
items.title: One of several murals by Hopi painter Fred Kabotie within the Desert View Watchtower, Grand Canyon National Park. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2018.

items.alt: A girl leans on the counter of a food stand while a man inside prepares an order. A sign board in the window lists the menu.
items.title: Food stand, Omaha pow-wow, Macy, Nebraska. Photo by Carl Fleischhauer, 1983. American Folklife Center

items.alt: Curly sits for his portrait with a blanket draped over his shoulders.
items.title: Ashishishe (also called Curly) was a Crow scout for the U.S. Army at the  Battle of Little BighornâCuster's Last Stand. Photo by Richard Throssel (Cree), around 1907.

items.alt: Long fringe hangs from the bottom of an unfurled blanket woven with many complex visual elements, including faces.
items.title: Chilkat blankets. Photo created between 1900 and 1930.

items.alt: Illustration of three women sitting in a birchbark canoe harvesting rice.
items.title: Gathering wild rice. Lithograph after Seth Eastman, around 1850.

items.alt: Baskets of many shapes and sizes are arranged on a table.
items.title: Baskets made by Alaska Natives. Photo created between 1900 and 1930.

items.alt: Illustration of Osceola standing with a long gun.
items.title: Osceola of Florida, a Seminole chief. Lithograph by George Catlin, 1838.

items.alt: Illustration of Piegan people standing on foot and sitting on horseback before a large encampment of tipis. In the background is a line of green hills.
items.title: Piegan encampment near Fort McKenzie in Montana. Lithograph after Karl Bodmer, 1842.

items.alt: Red lettering on a white sign offers welcome to the Omaha Indian Reservation. An image on the sign shows a white eagleâs head.
items.title: Sign at Gate to Pow-Wow, Macy, Nebraska. Photo by Carl Fleischhauer, 1983. American Folklife Center

items.alt: Mural of a woman walking toward the right. A baby rides on her back, wrapped in a red patterned cloth.
items.title: Detail of mural showing a Pueblo woman with child by artist Velino Herrara at the Interior Department Building, Washington, D.C. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2012.

items.alt: A woman wearing a beaded vest looks to the left while standing on the National Mall. The Washington Monument is visible behind her.
items.title: Participant in the "Million Indian March" on Washington, D.C. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2003.

description:
This set offers representative images of avalanches, blizzards, droughts and dust storms, earthquakes, floods, forest fires, heat waves, hurricanes, landslides, tornadoes, volcanic eruptions, and waterspouts from the 16th to the 21st centuries. The pictures are from the Prints & Photographs Division collections unless otherwise noted.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: A tornado funnel is shown in progress. There are light-colored clouds and a row of dark trees in the background.
items.title: Tornado. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1913-1917

items.alt: A pair of almost identical photos mounted on a card shows two young men, one bent over and one kneeling, sifting through debris. The debris field stretches far behind them and other male figures can be seen searching within the destruction.
items.title: Tornado. Tirelessly seeking lost ones, New Richmond, Wis., June 12, 1899. Photograph by Keystone, 1899

items.alt: Two panels depict large waterspouts in the distance with tiny human onlookers observing. The left panel shows a coastal village with palm trees and buildings. The right panel shows a street with a stone wall running alongside and a fenced-in building.
items.title: Representation of waterspouts at St. Jago de la Vega in Jamaica. Illustration from the Gentleman's Magazine, 1783

items.alt: Print shows a huge wave coming ashore with some people fleeing and others already dead in the water among wrecked houses and other debris. Border vignettes feature destroyed buildings and preparation of bodies for burial at sea and in fires.
items.title: Hurricane. Galveston's awful calamity - Gulf tidal wave, September 8th 1900. Print by Kurz & Allison, 1900

items.alt: Two women in long skirts, shirtwaist blouses, and hats, stand among a large pile of wood planks and debris. A roof-damaged house stands behind them.
items.title: Hurricane. Galveston disaster, trying to find where their home stood. Photo by M.H. Zahner, 1900

items.alt: A colorful poster depicts a woman in a dress with long hair grabbing her door to close it. Outside, a man and others hold tight to tree limbs that appear to bend in strong wind. The poster reads "Big Blow: A Drama of the Hurricane Country" by Theodore Pratt" and lists Maxine Elliott's Theatre, 109 West 39th Street, N.Y.C.
items.title: Hurricane. Federal Theatre presents "Big Blow" A drama of the hurricane country by Theodore Pratt. Poster by Richard  Halls, 1936-1939

items.alt: A house sits off its foundation with one side broken apart into planks of wood and debris. An American flag, a Christian cross, and graffiti adorn the intact front of the home.
items.title: Hurricane. Barber Shop located in Ninth Ward, New Orleans, Louisiana, damaged by Hurricane Katrina. Digital photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2005

items.alt: A pair of almost identical photos mounted on a card shows a house sits on its side with a large uprooted tree trunk sticking out of a missing upstairs window.
items.title: Flood. The Johnstown calamity. A slightly damaged house. Photo by George Barker, 1889

items.alt: A pair of almost identical photos mounted on a card shows a man in a hat siting on a riverbank in the foreground looking out at a flooded village. Church spires can be seen among the buildings.
items.title: Flood. Where Johnstown was (Pennsylvania). Photo by Filson & Son, 1889

items.alt: A young girl with short hair wearing a jacket looks at the camera while holding a cookie she is biting into. A small bowl of cookies sits on a desktop by her elbow.
items.title: Drought victim, girl in Duncan Consolidated School in Mississippi, eating cookies with currants, which came from Greece through the Junior Red Cross of that land. Photo by Lewis Hine, 1930 or 1931

items.alt: A group of people wait behind a desk while a seated man in glasses writes on sheets of paper. Labeled paper packages are piled on the right side of his desk. Two large Red Cross symbols on the wall flank a man standing apart from the others.
items.title: Drought. Red Cross food orders and free seed for quarter acre garden plots are given white and colored farmers by the Red Cross chapter at Cleveland, Mississippi. Photo by Lewis Hine, 1930 or 1931

items.alt: A typewritten note is titled "Thoughts" and dated July 3, 1901, by Alexander Graham Bell. The document quotes various newspaper headings describing a heat wave and includes a list of deaths from the heat according to location.
items.title: Heat wave. Notes by Alexander Graham Bell, July 3, 1901

items.alt: People are watching a group of children bent over to lick large blocks of ice on the sidewalk. A grocery storefront is in the background.
items.title: Heat wave. Licking blocks of ice on a hot day. Photograph by Bain News Service, 1910-1915

items.alt: A small group of people gather by a tent in front of a line of railroad cars. Beyond them are buildings standing in floodwaters in which people paddle boats.
items.title: Flood. Arkansas City, Ark., south section, Mississippi. Photo by Ewing, Inc., 1927 May.

items.alt: Groups of people in hats and head coverings sit in front of a row of tents on the slope of a grass-covered levee. Other people are walking on the dirt path at the top of the levee. Trees are in the distance.
items.title: Flood. Mississippi relief work. Twilight time, in the levee at Greenville, Miss., where the only shelter available is a tent, supplied by the Red Cross. Photo by the American National Red Cross, 1926 or 1927

items.alt: A map of the Pacific Ocean and the surrounding continents uses different colored lines to denote the percentage chances for activity along the coastlines.
items.title: Earthquake. Circum-Pacific seismic potential, 1989-1999. Map by the U.S. Geological Survey, [1991?]  Geography & Map Division

items.alt: A man in a hat and jacket stands on top of a brick wall and looks out over debris and ruined buildings. Very little is still standing.
items.title: Earthquake. On the ruins (April 1906), Chinatown, San Francisco. Photo by Arnold Genthe, 1906

items.alt: A man in dark clothing carries a gun over his shoulder and walks behind another darkly-dressed man on a sidewalk strewn with debris. A plume of smoke rises from the wreckage of a building in front of them.
items.title: Earthquake. The Fire on Market Street, San Francisco. Photo by unidentified photographer, 1906

items.alt: A pair of almost identical photos mounted on a card shows women in dark clothing taking in the sight of large Victorian houses standing crooked off their foundations.
items.title: After the earthquake - frame houses tumbled from their foundations, San Francisco Disaster, U.S.A. Photo by H.C. White, 1907

items.alt: A small group of firemen stand by a steam-powered water pump spraying water into a fire-damaged building. Tangled power lines and long water hoses are also visible.
items.title: Earthquake. Block of burned buildings in San Francisco after the 1906 earthquake with fire truck spraying water on them. Photograph by unidentified photographer, 1906.

items.alt: An aerial view of city blocks with a few ruined buildings standing amongst empty lots of rubble.
items.title: Earthquake. Bird's-eye-view of ruins of San Francisco from captive airship. Photo by George R. Lawrence, 1906

items.alt: Farm machinery nearly buried by piled up soil dust that gives the appearance of sand. Another piece of farm machinery lies buried behind it. Trees in the background are buried up to their upper branches.
items.title: Dust storm. Buried farm machinery. Cimarron County, Oklahoma. Photo by Arthur Rothstein, 1936.

items.alt: Buildings in the foreground are dwarfed by a large and dark cloud-wall of dust moving towards them.
items.title: Dust storm. One of South Dakota's "black blizzards." Photograph by Rosebud Photo, 1934

items.alt: The edge of a mountain top is soon to be eclipsed by a large cloud from a volcanic eruption.
items.title: Volcano. Katmai Volcano in eruption, Alaska. Photograph by M. Horner, 1913

items.alt: A plume of smoke rises from a steam locomotive behind a large wall of snow that has tumbled across the train tracks making them impassable. The tracks in the foreground are clear of snow. A mountain is visible in the background.
items.title: Avalanche of snow across railroad tracks, Alaska. Photograph by unidentified photographer, around 1900

items.alt: A group of burned tree trunks is surrounded by mud. A long line of unburned trees is in the background.
items.title: Fire. Remnants of a previous forest fire in Yellowstone National Park. Photo by Carol M. Highmith, 2015

items.alt: A colorful poster depicts a  burning cigarette givingg off a small sliver of smoke. In the background, trees are threatened by bands of fire.
items.title: Fire wrecks a forest. Poster, 1936-1939

items.alt: A man in dark clothing is attached to a dome-shaped parachute as he descends through the treetops. A wooded hill is visible in the distance.
items.title: Forest fire fighter. Para-fireman. This parachutist fights timber fires for the U.S. Forest Service. Much of his equipment is similar to that used at the battlefronts, since he encounters many of the same perils. Photo by U.S. Forest Service, 1943 or 1944

items.alt: Four people stand outside as snow blows sideways around them. Snowbanks are visible and the buildings behind them are obscured by the blowing snow.
items.title: Blizzard. New York City. Blizzard of 1888. Photo by C.H. Jordan

items.alt: An automobile sits parked and covered by a large quantity of snow. The buildings behind it have snow piled on their window sills.
items.title: Blizzard. Photo by National Photo Co., 1/28/22

items.alt: Groups of men are examining the wreckage in the interior of a large building. The letter K is visible on the curtain surrounding a stage at one end of the building.
items.title: Snow storm. Collapsed roof following snow storm on January 28, 1922, Washington, D.C. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1922

items.alt: Book page has a poem and an accompanying illustration that depicts three men on horses stopping at the foot of a mountain. Large, round boulders roll down the mountain towards the men.
items.title: Landslide. Illustration showing mountain landslide threatening 3 horsemen. Woodcut on vellum by Hans Schaufrerlein, 1517. Rare Book & Special Collections Division

description:
Women and men have long provided nursing services by caring for the sick and wounded at home and during wars and international relief efforts. The pictures in this set focus on the mid-1800s to mid-1900s, including portraits of such famous figures as Florence Nightingale and Clara Barton as well as women like Susie King Taylor who are gaining recognition for their courageous stories. The emphasis on nurses during the Civil War and in the American Red Cross represents significant nursing concentrations at the Library of Congress. Unless otherwise noted, the selected images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: Florence Nightingale poses for a photographic portrait.
items.title: Florence Nightingale (1820-1910) is known as "the founder of modern nursing." Photo by H. Lenthal, around 1856

items.alt: An aproned woman wraps medical supplies into a cloth bundle.
items.title: Midwife wrapping her kit to go on a call in Greene County, Georgia. Photo by Jack Delano, 1941

items.alt: Women in white gowns look after children on a beach.
items.title: American Red Cross in Italy. Scores of these little ones are taken in the water daily on the doctor's prescription watched carefully by their nurses. Red Cross Collection photo, 1919

items.alt: Illustration of a woman with a cross armband riding a horse.
items.title: The Public Health Nurse She answers humanity's call : Your Red Cross membership makes her work possible. Poster by Gordon Grant, 1914-1918

items.alt: Susie King Taylor stands for a photographic portrait in a U.S. Army nurse uniform.
items.title: Susie King Taylor (1848-1912), known as the first African American Army nurse

items.alt: Clara Barton sits for a photographic portrait by a small table and holds an open book.
items.title: Clara Barton (1812-1921), known for her roles in nursing during the Civil War and in founding the American Red Cross. Photo by Claflin, March 1865

items.alt: A woman in a nurse uniform tends to a man lying in a bed.
items.title: St. Rose's nuns and nurses with patient. Photo by Bernard Gotfryd, 1984

items.alt: A woman in a nurse uniform wearing a cross symbol armband wraps a dogâs paw with a bandage.
items.title: Dogs of War. Red Cross nurse bandaging up a wounded foot of collie. Photo by Underwood & Underwood, 1917

items.alt: Marie Brose Tepe stands for a photographic portrait wearing a uniform embellished with a cross medal.
items.title: Marie Brose Tepe (1834-1901), Civil War nurse and vivandiÃ¨re in zouave uniform with Kearny Cross medal, barrel canteen, and revolver. Photo by R.W. Addis, 1862-1864

items.alt: O.W. Waite poses for a photographic portrait wearing a Civil War Union uniform.
items.title: O.W. Waite, male Civil War nurse at smallpox hospital, in uniform. Photo, 1861-1865

items.alt: A woman wearing medical scrubs handles surgical instruments in an operating room.
items.title: Surgical nurse, Herrin Hospital (private), Herrin, Illinois. Photo by Arthur Rothstein, 1939

items.alt: A throng of women in nurse uniforms moves along an avenue.
items.title: Nurses parade, Chicago. Red Cross Collection photo, 1918

items.alt: Illustration of Uncle Sam standing near a woman in nursing attire reading to a man lying in a bed.
items.title: Remember the Nurse. Sheet music cover, 1918

items.alt: Uniformed men lay flowers on graves marked with crosses.
items.title: Group of American Red Cross men, Lts. Kelly, Dubois, Fraser and Vance, placing a wreath on Miss Edith Cavell's grave immediately after the departure of the Germans from Brussels. Red Cross Collection photo, around 1918

items.alt: A woman hands a medicine cup to a man across a table.
items.title: A nurse hands a cup of methadone to a man in a medical clinic at 456 C St., N.W., Washington, D.C. Photo by Warren Leffler, 1971

items.alt: Dorothea L. Dix sits for a photographic portrait with a medical bag at her feet.
items.title: Dorothea L. Dix, Superintendent of Army Nurses for the Union Army with a medical bag on the floor. Photo, 1865

items.alt: Women in nursing attire tend to a man lying on a medical table.
items.title: Japanese nurses attending to a patient in an operating room. Photo by Underwood & Underwood, 1905

items.alt: A woman stands for a photographic portrait wearing a U.S. Army nurse uniform.
items.title: An Army nurse wears the Caduceus, the winged staff and serpent of the Medical Corps, with the "U.S." on her outdoor uniform. Photo by Joel Feder, 1914

items.alt: A dog and a cat dressed in clothing are posed in an embrace.
items.title: The nurse. Photo by Harry Frees, 1914

items.alt: Women in nursing attire sit in a semicircle drinking tea.
items.title: Nurses at tea. Photo by Bain News Service, 1915-1920

items.alt: Front cover of a handbook for student nurses.
items.title: A handbook for school nurses. Book by Helen Kelly, 1918

items.alt: Girls wearing nursing attire pretend to work in a hospital nursery.
items.title: Junior Red Cross. Red Cross Collection photo, 1919-1929

items.alt: A nurse teaches medical techniques to young girls in nursing attire.
items.title: Little sisters class, Podgoritza Orphanage, Montenegro, where Miss Robinson is the director. Miss Jeannie Frasier, A.R.C. nurse is shown instructing. Red Cross Collection photo, 1919-1929

items.alt: A group of nurses in matching cloaks exits through a large gate.
items.title: The Queen and territorial nurses. Nurses leaving the palace on foot and in cabs. Red Cross Collection photo, 1917-1919

items.alt: A woman poses for a photographic portrait in nursing attire emblazoned with cross symbols.
items.title: Red Cross nurse. Photo by Adolf de Meyer, around 1920

items.alt: Medical instruments, sterile cloths, and a pair of opaque eyeglasses cover a tray.
items.title: Eye Tray. Army Training School for Nurses. Walter Reed Hospital. Red Cross Collection photo, 1920

items.alt: A ribbon embellished with a cross symbol supports a medal embossed with an image of Florence Nightingale.
items.title: Florence Nightingale medal. Red Cross Collection photo, 1920

items.alt: Illustration of a woman in nursing attire as seen from the front and back.
items.title: We Live and Laugh: The Nurse. Grey dress, white apron, black heels, and white nurse's cap. Costume design drawing by Emile Stoner, 1935-1939  (Music Division, Federal Theatre Project)

items.alt: A man pins a medal on a woman while another woman in nursing attire looks on.
items.title: U.S. Nurse wins international award. Miss Butler is the fifteenth American nurse to receive the Florence Nightingale award. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1937-1939

items.alt: Memorial statue of a woman wearing nursing attire.
items.title: Army and Navy Nurses Memorial. Photo by Harris & Ewing, around 1938

items.alt: A man and a woman in medical garb perform a procedure on a patientâs eyes.
items.title: The Dept. of Health, Mobile Ophthalmic Clinic. Operating in Arab villages of the South Country, N.E. of Gaza. Closer view of nurses tending to the eyes to prevent or heal the dreaded disease. Photo by American Colony, 1939

items.alt: Poster of two women posing in matching nursing attire emblazoned with cross symbols.
items.title: Uncle Sam Needs Nurses. World War II poster, 1941-1945

items.alt: Illustration of cross symbols transforming everyday women into nurses.
items.title: Train to be a nurse's aide Phone your boro Civilian Defense Volunteer Office. Poster by Federal Art Project, 1941-1943

items.alt: A group of women sits at student desks wearing matching uniforms.
items.title: Chicago, Illinois. Provident Hospital. A preliminary student nurses' class in bacteriology. Photo by Jack Delano, 1942

items.alt: A woman in nursing attire watches as another fills a hypodermic needle.
items.title: Nurse training. A graduate nurse (right) watches student Susan Petty prepare a hypodermic for a patient. Photo by Fritz Henle, 1942

items.alt: A woman in nursing attire weighs a baby on a scale.
items.title: Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, Maryland. Student nurse at work in the pediatrics ward. Photo by Ann Rosener, 1943

items.alt: An aproned woman tends to small children in metal cribs.
items.title: Orphanage (with nurse), Manzanar War Relocation Center. Photo by Ansel Adams,1943

items.alt: A woman gets into the driver's seat of a station wagon.
items.title: Penasco, New Mexico. Nurse Marjorie Muller, of the clinic operated by the Taos County cooperative health association, starting out on a call. Photo by John Collier, 1943

items.alt: Women in nursing attire pose in a room with a dresser and beds.
items.title: Hebron hospital, nurse's bedroom. Photo by Matson Photo Service, 1944

items.alt: A group of women in nurse uniforms stands together for a photographic portrait.
items.title: First group of African American nurses to arrive in England during World War II. Photo by U.S. Signal Corps, 1944.

items.alt: People in white coats ride on a parade float with realistic animal figures.
items.title: The Nurses' Float, decorated by registered nurses from across the United States, in the 124th Rose Parade in Pasadena, California. Photo by Carol Highsmith, 2013

description:
This selection of images from the 19th and 20th centuries shows older women and men in the United States. They appear in formal portraits; scenes at work and at home; as grandparents and veterans; with happiness, sorrow, and determination.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.alt: An old woman with white hair and a bent back stands at the sink and washes dishes in a pan. The curtains have flowers and the walls are light green.
items.title: Kate Carter washing dishes in a kitchen, Wentworth, North Carolina. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 1985.

items.alt: A head-and-shoulders portrait shows a woman with very wrinkled skin and short hair holding a stick in one hand and looking at the ground.
items.title: Old woman in mourning--Yuki people. Photo by Edward Curtis, 1924.

items.alt: An old man sits in a chair with two young children seated on the floor in front of him  and a man and another child seated across the room. Religious symbols and portraits are on the walls, and two kerosene lamps are on the fireplace.
items.title: The Lopez children often call on their grandfather in the evenings to hear tales of the old days when Trampas was a thriving sheep town. Photo by John Collier, 1943.

items.alt: A smiling man is seated outside with a smiling baby in his lap.
items.title: Grandfather and grandchild, New Orleans, Louisiana. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 1980-1990.

items.alt: An old woman stands in a room and reads aloud while several other women and a child sit nearby.
items.title: Star pupil, eighty-two years old, reading her lesson in adult class. Gee's Bend, Alabama.  Photo by Marion Post Wolcott, 1939.

items.alt: An old man sits with his hand spread out on an X-ray plate and looks towards the floor. The technician stands behind the man and holds his hand in place.
items.title: Michael Yonemitsu, x-ray technician, and Harry Sumida in x-ray room, Manzanar Relocation Center, California. Photo by Ansel Adams, 1943.

items.alt: An old woman sits on a column while an old man stands next to hear and holds a rake. Both wear patterned Asian jackets and pants.
items.title: Frances B. Johnston in garden in New Orleans with "Pops" Whitesell. Photo by Johnston, about 1950.

items.alt: An old woman (left) and old man (right) sit on opposite ends of a bench and face away from each other.
items.title: Old people [Senior citizens, N.Y.C.]. Photo by Bernard Gotfryd, 1970-1990.

items.alt: An old woman sits in front of a quilt with a red, white, and blue pattern.
items.title: Mrs. Fannie Lee Teals, quilting, Tifton, Georgia. Photo by Beverly J. Robinson, 1977.  American Folklife Center

items.alt: An old man looks directly at the camera with a brimmed hat and a bent-shaped pipel
items.title: Bearded man with a pipe. Photo by Lawrence V. Kupper, 1901.

items.alt: An old smiling woman holds the weighing scale basket with a crying baby while a nurse, three younger women, and a boy look on.
items.title: A tiny celestial goes on the scale, Chinatown, New York. Photo by Red Cros, 1922.

items.alt: An old man wearing glasses looks directly at the camera while holding a paint brush and a plate with paint. Behind him is a panoramic scene with mountains and desert plants.
items.title: C.T. Hibino, artist, Manzanar Relocation Center, California. Photo by Ansel Adams, 1943.

items.alt: Five old women sit in a line on an outdoor bench. They wear patterned dresses or aprons and have crossed their ankles.
items.title: Parishoners of St. Thomas Church resting after spending many hours preparing food for a benefit picnic supper. Near Bardstown, Kentucky. Photo by Marion Post Wolcott, 1940.

items.alt: Three old men stand by a machine and look at a part.
items.title: Babcock airplane plant, Deland, Florida. Together these three men have a total of 160 years of experience as skilled machinists. Photo by Howard Hollem, 1942.

items.alt: Two old women in a machine shop look down at what they are working on. Their hands are dirty. One wears overalls and a kerchief; the other wears a shirt and trousers.
items.title: Two grandmothers who are keeping up the production schedule of the La Roe's family shop at Eustis, Florida. Photo by Howard Hollem, 1942.

items.alt: Colored print shows 11 women as they progress from infancy to prime of life to age 100. They stand on steps that rise and descend.
items.title: The Life and age of woman, stages of woman's life from the cradle to the grave. Print by James Baillie, 1848.

items.alt: Colored print shows 11 men as they progress from infancy to prime of life to age 100. They stand on steps that rise and descend.
items.title: The Life and age of man, stages of man's life from the cradle to the grave. Print by James Baillie, 1848.

items.alt: Eight photos matted together show old men between 100 and 105 years old. Each man is seated and several hold walking sticks.
items.title: The last men of the Revolution. Photographs by Nelson and Roswell Moore, 1864.

items.alt: Stereograph photo shows an old man seated in front of his house in a rocking chair with a flintlock musket and a pair of crutches leaning against the wall behind him.
items.title: John L. Burns, the old hero of Gettysburg, recovering from his wounds. Photo by Brady's National Photographic Portrait Galleries, 1863.

items.alt: Photo shows a head-and-shoulders portrait of an old woman. She faces to the left and wears an elaborate lace cap and collar.
items.title: Nancy Maria Donaldson Johnson, teacher, inventor, missionary. Photo about 1875.

items.alt: Color sketch shows a standing woman in profileâslightly bent back. She wears a long dress, apron, and shawl.
items.title: Old woman in apron and shawl. Painting by Otto Bacher, 1876-1909.

items.alt: Brown-toned sketch shows a woman lifting the lid of a box while one child stands on stool ready to look inside. The other two children stand nearby with their hands behind their backs.
items.title: Old woman opening box while three children watch. Drawing by Edwin Austin Abbey, 1870-1911.

items.alt: Old woman sits in a room with books piled on a table nearby and a pair of crutches in front of her. The mirror shows her profile, and a low bed is in the background.
items.title: Elderly woman. Photo by Charles Henry Currier, 1890-1900.

items.alt: An old man seated next to a large cactus looks directly at the camera. An open top jar is nearby.
items.title: Old "Nana." (Warrior and chief of the Chiricahua Apache.) Photo copyright by A.F. Randall, 1884.

items.alt: A young smiling girl sits in a rocking chair and knits. She is dressed like a grandmother with a lace cap, eyeglasses, and shawl.
items.title: Playing grandmother. Chromolithograph, 1890.

items.alt: An old  woman wearing a long dress and checked apron sits in a rocking chair and holds a bowl of fruit in her lap. A young barefoot girl looks on as the woman peels the fruit.
items.title: Elderly woman in a rocking chair peeling apple with young girl standing in front of her. Photo by Elizabeth B. Brownell, about 1900.

items.alt: Old man looks into the camera while seated and wearing a striped blanket over one shoulder.
items.title: Chief Hoo-sis-mox-mox of the Palouse people. Photo by Lee Moorhouse, 1900.

items.alt: An old man shown in profile plays a violin while seated at a table. A lighted fireplace is in the background.
items.title: A Difficult passage. Photo by William Hirsch, 1902.

items.alt: Two old women with wrinkled faces and lace caps are seated close together as if sharing a secret. One has a tea cup in her lap, and another cup and teapot are on a table behind them.
items.title: Strictly Confidential. Chromolithograph, 1908.

items.alt: Portrait shows two men sitting together. An old man (on the left) wears a Civil War cap and medal. A young man (on the right) is in a World War I hat and uniform.
items.title: Unidentified Civil War veteran and unidentified World War I soldier. Photo by James B. Schriever, 1914-1918.

items.alt: Portrait shows an old man and two old women posed with a minister in front of a building. They look directly at the camera.
items.title: Reunion of people born into slaveryâLewis Martin, age 100, Martha Elizabeth Banks, age 104; and Amy War, age 103; with Rev. S.P. Drew, born free. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1917.

items.alt: An old woman wearing a long dress is seated outside is looking at her spinning wheel while holding the bobbin in one hand. A patterned woven fabric hangs behind her.
items.title: Woman spinning. Photo by Doris Ulmann, 1930

items.alt: An old woman with her hair pulled back stands outdoors and displays a quilt from her arm. She is wearing eye glasses and slippers.
items.title: Grandmother from Oklahoma and her pieced quilt. California, Kern County. (Dresden plate quilt pattern.) Photo by Dorothea Lange, 1936.

items.alt: An old woman with her hair in a bun is shown in profile as she holds a frying pan over a gas burner with two plates of tortillas nearby.
items.title: Mexican woman cooking tortillas. San Antonio, Texas. Photo by Russell Lee, 1939

items.alt: An old woman seated in a chair looks carefully at the pages of an open book that she is holding. Her hair is in careful waves and her long-sleeve blouse has a shiny fabric.
items.title: Life begins at 70. Washington, D.C., ... Mrs. Isabelle Haggett at 75 is now a co-ed at George Washington University. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1939

items.alt: An old man seated in a chair is looking at a small bottle and a large glass bottle that he holds in his hands. Many more bottles are on shelves behind him.
items.title: Collecting old bottles is hobby of retired professor W. Edwin Priest. Washington, D.C. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1939

items.alt: An old man seated on a rock holds his hands folded in front of him and wears a cap.
items.title: Jim Grey, retired old farmer of Ledyard, Connecticut, waiting for the noon mail at the crossroads. Photo by Jack Delano, 1940.

items.alt: An old woman seated in a chair faces the camera with both of her hands placed on top of a purse in her lap.
items.title: New York, New York. Old Chinese woman in Chinatown. Photo by Marjory Collins, 1942.

items.alt: An old woman in a checked dress wears heavy gloves while operating a machine.
items.title: Women in industry. Flare gun production. ... Mrs. Annette Caines of Detroit, who manned a milling machine in a gun factory during the last war and hasn't stopped work since. Photo by Ann Rosener, 1942

items.alt: An old man with a trimmed goatee beard is wearing a kufi cap and vest, tie, and suit coat as he stands in front of a glass plate window with a sign for "Garvey Club, U.N.I.A."
items.title: New York, New York. A follower of the late Marcus Garvey who started the "Back to Africa" movement. Photo by Gordon Parks, 1943.

items.alt: An old woman wearing sunglasses, a hat with a brim, and a fur trimmed coat looks to the left of the photographer.
items.title: Daytona Beach, Florida. Woman who says she is 104 years old. Photo by Gordon Parks, 1943.

items.alt: The oldest, apparently toothless, woman is seated in the front of the photo while the younger generations of women and children are behind her.
items.title: Gloucester, Massachusetts. Mrs. Mary Machado, her daughter Mrs. Isabell Lopez, her daughter Irene, an infant great-grandchild Dorothy, Jr. and her mother Dorothy, Sr., and a grandson Francis, the son of Irene. Photo by Gordon Parks, 1943.

items.alt: A large group of adults and children is seated on the floor of a large room. They appear to be singing and clapping hands.
items.title: Children's folktale contest and old people's birthday party, held at Shinsundo Studio, Chicago, Illinois. (Korean Americans) Photo by Chungmoo Choi, 1977.

items.alt: A smiling old man in a plaid shirt sits on a pier and holds a dog by a leash.
items.title: Senior citizens, Massachusetts. Photo by Bernard Gotfryd, about 1980.

items.alt: Two old men are talking to each other with many other men in the background.
items.title: Senior citizens, Florida, at Mets training camp. Photo by Bernard Gotfryd, about 1980.

description:
The Library of Congress holds the papers of 23 presidents from George Washington to Calvin Coolidge, all of which have been digitized and are available online as 3.3 million images. The selected documents represent the variety of materials available in the papers as well as some of the most important texts. A press release provides the web address for each collection.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.title: Draft of the Federal Constitution with marginal notes by George Washington, September 12, 1787. George Washington Papers, Manuscript Division.
Abraham Lincoln, Gettysburg Address,Â  delivered November 19, 1863 (Nicolay copy).Â  Abraham Lincoln Papers, Manuscript Division.
Theodore Roosevelt, diary entry, February 14, 1884, recording his despair after the deaths of both his wife and mother on the same day. Theodore Roosevelt Papers, Manuscript Division.

Telegram from Congressman John Franklin Miller of Washington state to Calvin Coolidgeâs secretary C. Bascom Slemp, September 30, 1924, requesting that he urge the president to call a special session of Congress so thatÂ members could return to see the Washington Senators play in the 1924 World Series. Calvin Coolidge Papers, Manuscript Division.
George Washington, inaugural address, April 30, 1789. George Washington Papers, Manuscript Division.
Farm report, George Augustine Washington to President George Washington, March 6, 1790, recording the births, sicknesses, and labor of slaves. George Washington Papers, Manuscript Division.
George Washington, September 17, 1796, Farewell Address. George Washington Papers, Manuscript Division.
Thomas Jefferson, Map of the Federal District, March 31, 1791, drawn while Secretary of State. Thomas Jefferson Papers, Manuscript Division.
Thomas Jefferson to Meriwether Lewis, cipher to use on the Lewis and Clark expedition, April 20, 1803. Thomas Jefferson Papers, Manuscript Division.
Thomas Jefferson, sixth annual message to Congress, December 2, 1806, putting into effect the Constitutionâs ban on the slave trade after twenty years. Thomas Jefferson Papers, Manuscript Division.
Thomas Jeffersonâs 1826 plan for his own tomb excluded mention of his role as third president of the United States. Thomas Jefferson Papers, Manuscript Division.
James Madison, notes for a speech on Constitutional amendments to constitute a Bill of Rights, June 8, 1789. James Madison Papers, Manuscript Division.
Former president John Adams to current president James Monroe regardingÂ appointments to office, June 27, 1817. James Monroe Papers, Manuscript Division.
Andrew Jackson, draft of first inaugural address, March 4, 1829. Andrew Jackson Papers, Manuscript Division.
James K. Polk, diary entry, August 26, 1846, on his reasons for keeping a diary.Â James K. Polk Papers, Manuscript Division.
Arrangements for the presidential inauguration of Zachary Taylor, March 5, 1849.Â  Zachary Taylor Papers, Manuscript Division.
Franklin Pierce, draft of last annual message to Congress, December 2, 1856. Franklin Pierce Papers, Manuscript Division.
Cigar box label featuring Republican presidential candidate Abraham Lincoln, 1860.Â  Abraham Lincoln Papers, Manuscript Division.
Final copy of Abraham Lincolnâs first inaugural address, delivered on March 4, 1861, with handwritten closing paragraph.Â Abraham Lincoln Papers, Manuscript Division.
Abraham Lincolnâs preliminary draft of an emancipation proclamation, first read to his cabinet on July 22, 1862.Â  Abraham Lincoln Papers, Manuscript Division.
Abraham Lincoln, âcut-and-pasteâ reading copy of second inaugural address, delivered March 4, 1865.Â  Abraham Lincoln Papers, Manuscript Division.
Andrew Johnson, speech in the U.S. Senate, May 20, 1858, on the Homestead Bill before Congress.Â  Andrew Johnson Papers, Manuscript Division.
Expense account, 1865, reflecting African American steward William Sladeâs grocery purchases for the Andrew Johnson White House.Â  Andrew Johnson Papers, Manuscript Division.
Ulysses S. Grant to Secretary of War Edwin M. Stanton, May 11, 1864. Ulysses S. Grant Papers, Manuscript Division.
Note exchanged between Ulysses S. Grant and his wife Julia, May 22, 1875, on the anniversary of their engagement.Â  Ulysses S. Grant Papers, Manuscript Division.
Letter of introduction for James A. Garfield by Librarian of Congress Ainsworth Rand Spofford, July 10, 1867. James A. Garfield Papers,Â  Manuscript Division.
James A. Garfield, final diary entry, July 1, 1881.Â James A. Garfield Papers,Â  Manuscript Division.
Bill submitted to Chester Alan Arthur from cigar importer G. W. Faber, October 20, 1873. Chester Alan Arthur Papers, Manuscript Division.
Letter, New Yorker Julia Sand to Chester Alan Arthur, March 1882, expressing her contempt for the Chinese exclusion bill then before Congress.Â Chester Alan Arthur Papers, Manuscript Division
Grover Cleveland, pictured on an 1888 presidential campaign ribbon. Grover Cleveland Papers, Manuscript Division.
Benjamin Harrisonâs envelope reply, refusing to make a political deal at the June 1888 Republican nominating convention. Benjamin Harrison Papers, Manuscript Division.
Broadside comparing the respective Civil War service of presidential candidates Benjamin Harrison and Grover Cleveland, 1888.Â  Benjamin Harrison Papers, Manuscript Division.
Grover Cleveland to his friend A. B. Farquhar, February 11, 1908, on being âan optimistic Americanâ despite current events.Â  Grover Cleveland Papers, Manuscript Division.
William McKinley, draft message, April 11, 1898, regarding the use of U.S. military forces in Cuba.Â William McKinley Papers, Manuscript Division.
Newspaper cartoon poking fun at New York City Police Commissioner Theodore Roosevelt, July 12, 1895.Â  Theodore Roosevelt Papers, Manuscript Division.
Theodore Roosevelt, 1902 sketch of brands used to identify his cattle while a rancher.Â  Theodore Roosevelt Papers, Manuscript Division.
Theodore Roosevelt to son Archibald Roosevelt, September 28, 1907, on the White House antics of youngest child, Quentin.Â  Theodore Roosevelt Papers, Manuscript Division
National Civil and Political League of American Negroes, Washington, D.C. Notice of meeting to support William H. Taftâs reelection, August 12, 1912. William H. Taft Papers, Manuscript Division.Â
Photograph of William H. Taft at a microphone, undated. William H. Taft Papers, Manuscript Division.Â
Cartoon, âThe Bluff,â predicting that Theodore Roosevelt would be the animating force in a Taft presidency, ca. 1908. William H. Taft Papers, Manuscript Division.Â
Courtship letter from President Woodrow Wilson to Edith Bolling Galt Wilson, May 6, 1915. Woodrow Wilson Papers, Manuscript Division.

Woodrow Wilsonâs signature, 1917, transformed into an inkblot in an unusual autograph book titled Your Hidden Skeleton (Philadelphia: John C. Winston Co., n.d.). Woodrow Wilson Papers, Manuscript Division.
Carrie Chapman Catt to Woodrow Wilson, November 26, 1918, urging him to speak on behalf of the womanâs suffrage amendment. Woodrow Wilson Papers, Manuscript Division.
Woodrow Wilson's speech notes, in shorthand, for his "Fourteen Points" address, [8 January 1918]. Woodrow Wilson Papers, Manuscript Division.

Photograph, James L. Callahan, Boston Globe, of newly sworn-in President Calvin Coolidge greeting eight-year-old Bernard âPinkieâ Sinay, in North Bennington, Vermont, August 3, 1923. Calvin Coolidge Papers, Manuscript Division.
