description:
Where do you like to read? The pictures in this set confirm that you can enjoy reading just about anywhere. You might be walking with a dog, sitting on a crate, rowing a boat, or visiting a library. What you read also ranges widely--from books and scrolls to maps, magazines, newspapers, letters, and computers.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.
children.meta_description: Where do you like to read? The pictures in this set confirm that you can enjoy reading just about anywhere. You might be walking with a dog, sitting on a crate, rowing a boat, or visiting a library. What you read also ranges widely--from books and scrolls to maps, magazines, newspapers, letters, and computers.

items.alt: A colorful poster depicts an outdoor scene with woman in a white dress and hat holding a book in her hand. She is reading as she walks toward an orange rocking chair with red tulips draped on its arm. On the ground is a black and white dog. Text across the top reads "Harper's June."
items.title: Harper's, June. Poster by Edward Penfield, 1897. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A colorful poster depicts two people sitting on a globe beneath a tree, reading books. A sun shines on them from a distance. Below them are a ring of clouds, a crescent moon, and stars. The word "Books" appears at the top of the poster. The phrase "The best gifts" appears at the bottom.
items.title: Books, the best gift. Poster by Edward A. Wilson, 1927. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: An antique wooden tablet  with a h handle at the bottom holds a small sheet of paper covered by a transparent sheet of horn. The alphabet and Lord's Prayer are printed on the paper. Along the top edge are small rails with abacus beads for doing arithmetic.
items.title: Wood hornbook, 18th century. Rare Book & Special Collections Division

items.alt: A colorful map depicts the island and surrounding environs with inset illustrations of animals, tall ships, and swashbucklers. An illustrated montage of Crusoe's manual labor on the island is at the bottom right.
items.title: Map relating to the book Robinson Crusoe by Daniel Defoe. By Kenneth Riley, 1964. Geography & Map Division

items.alt: A uniformed African American man wearing thick gloves is reading an open book. He is reclining on the running board of an armored military vehicle with his legs crossed.
items.title: Reading a salvage book by one of the Salvage men on the salvage truck of the A.T.S. salvage office. St. Nazaire. Photo by American Library Association, 1919. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A professionally-dressed woman sits in a wooden chair at a desk. She rests her fingertips on an open page while reading text in braille. A coat rack and a filing cabinet are in the background.
items.title: Woman reading braille. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1931 or 1932. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A colorful poster depicts multiple children of varying ages playing amidst larger-than-life-size books standing upright with open pages. At the top of the poster are the words "Explore with Books." The bottom reads "Book Week Nov. 17-23."
items.title: Explore with books. Book week, Nov. 17-23. Poster by Alice Provensen, 1957. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A woman and a small child sit in chairs while looking at a computer monitor with a large bird cutout on top and stuffed animals on the floor in the foreground. Around them are multiple shelves filled with books. On the wall above them is a painted mural and beyond them is a row of high windows.
items.title: Free Library of Philadelphia, Passyunk Branch. Photo by Joseph E. Elliot, 2007. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A colorful woodcut print depicts four men in ornate robes sitting and reading a long scroll. One man holds a fan. Texts in Japanese characters frame the men.
items.title: Eight great KyÅka poets. Color woodcut by Gogaku Yajima, 1818-1824. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A man in a straw boater hat and a waist apron sits on a wooden milk crate, reading a newspaper on a city sidewalk. Behind him, magazines are hung up and also stacked on a table.
items.title: Man in straw hat seated on milk crate, reading a newspaper written in the Hebrew alphabet, New York City. Photo by Angelo Rizzuto, 1958. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: Five boys sit in a circle. One of the boys reads a handwritten text on a long strip of paper. Three of the boys are busy writing. One boy looks at the camera and smiles.
items.title: Class learning to read and write, Sikkim. Photo by Alice Kandell, 1963. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A colorful poster in the shape of a bookmark depicts a human-like being with green skin holding a magazine. It sits atop a pile of stacked books with legs hanging over the edge. The top of the poster reads "The Little Green God of the Library Slip." A coupon related to magazines and books is at the bottom of the poster.
items.title: The Little Green God of the Library Slip. Poster by Magazine & Book Co., 1910. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: The book is in the shape of a girl with a wolf at her feet while wearing a red cloak and holding a basket. She stands atop a volume that reads "Red Riding Hood" on its edge.
items.title: Book: Little Red Riding Hood. Published by L. Prang, 1863. Rare Book & Special Collections Division

items.alt: An ink drawing shows a man in a robe seated on the floor, reading a scroll. Seven rolled scrolls sit on a small table in front of him.
items.title: Religious figure, probably a monk, reading a scroll. Drawing, 1878. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A colorful poster depicts a frog in a suit and bowtie rowing a boat while reading an open book. In the foreground, a fish reads a book next to a cattail. The poster reads, "It's a Whole Great Big Fun Thing."
items.title: It's a whole great big fun thing. Poster by Tomi Ungerer, 1972. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A man in overalls sits in a wooden rocking chair, reading the newspaper. A radio sits on a table to his left. Another table holds a ceramic statue of an antlered deer and miscellaneous items. Family portraits and needlework adorn the walls.
items.title: Spanish-American farmer reading in living room of his home, Chamisal, New Mexico. Photo by Russell Lee, 1940. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A relief sculpture in an architectural arch depicts two men reading. The young man on the left holds a scroll. The old man on the right holds a stone tablet. Above them are the words Library of Congress. Beyond them, an archway with a mural is visible above double doors.
items.title: Old and young man reading.  Sculpture by Olin L. Warner in the Library of Congress Great Hall. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2007. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: Brick buildings are visible beyond the yellow lines of a parking lot. One building's wall is painted with a large and colorful mural of a young girl reading a book with imaginary creatures and plants abover her. The phrase "Philadelphia Reads" descends along the mural's edge. The adjacent building has multiple windows and doors and a black fire escape. More buildings are in the background.
items.title: Joshua Sarantitis's mural, "Secret Book," in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, was sponsored by the Philadelphia Reads program. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2019. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A man with glasses wears a white dress shirt and black pants and sits on a wooden chair atop a wooden desk. He is reading a newspaper out loud while men and women work at wooden tables beyond him. In front of him are wooden beams that hold several metal buckets.
items.title: A "Reader" in cigar factory, Tampa, Florida. He reads books and newspapers at top of his voice all day long.  Photo by Lewis W. Hine, 1909. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A painted sculpture of a Gila monster is positioned on the ground next to a Little Free Library box with books painted on its door. The statue's hand rests on a sculpture of an open book. Behind it, a prickly pear cactus plant grows from the ground, and a stucco building is visible in the background.
items.title: Even a sculpted gila monster appears to be into reading, Tucson, Arizona. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2018. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: Two women are reading a magazine by a window. The woman in a dark, full-length dress leans over the seated woman in a light dress. Behind them, a framed and matted picture hangs on the wall.
items.title: The readers (Letitia Felix and Ada Follett), Newark, Ohio. Photo by Clarence H. White, 1897. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A sketch depicts a soldier in uniform lying on his side on the ground. He reads a newspaper laid out in front of him.
items.title: News from home. Civil War drawing by Edwin Forbes, 1863. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: An African American man in glasses sits at a table and cradles his chin with his hand. He is intently reading a newspaper that is folded in front of him. Blurred people are visible behind him.
items.title: Young man reading newspaper. Photo by Angelo Rizzuto, 1956. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A relief sculpture on a staircase depicts two children. The child at left holds an open book in his lap and wears a mortar board. The child on the right is next to a printing press. A sculpted garland weaves around them.
items.title: Student with a book on the staircase in the Great Hall, Library of Congress. Sculpture by Philip Martiny. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2007. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A watercolor illustration depicts an African American man in glasses sitting on a chair at a makeshift wooden table. He holds a newspaper with both hands and reads by candlelight. A dog sleeps on the floor.
items.title: Man reading a newspaper with headline, "Presidential Proclamation, Slavery," which refers to the Jan. 1863 Emancipation Proclamation. Drawing by Henry L. Stephens, 1863? Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A young African American child wearing a gingham dress sits at a wooden school desk and holds an open book. The book's pages show text and an illustration of a female figure holding flowers. The background is blurred.
items.title: A Pupil in Pleasant Green School - Pocahontas County, Marlinton, West Virginia. Photo by Lewis W. Hine, 1921. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A mural depicts two men in Renaissance-style clothing who are reading a text on a large sheet of paper. A man to their left pulls on the large wooden lever of a printing press.
items.title: Printing Press mural in Evolution of the Book series. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2007. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A young woman in a dress sits on a porch swing next to a boy in overalls. Her arm is around him, and she holds a book they are reading. A vegetable garden and wooden fence posts are visible behind them.
items.title: Wife of FSA (Farm Security Administration) client reading book to her son on swing on her front porch. Photo by Russell Lee, 1939. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A colorful cover of a children's book depicts a woman, a young boy, and various animals, some wearing human clothing. Several figures and part of the title are upside down.
items.title: The Twelve Magic Changelings. By M.A. Glen, 1907. Rare Book & Special Collections Division

items.alt: Black outline figures on beige paper depict well-dressed parents and two children sitting on a curved bench. They are all reading books. Below them are the words "Books the Ideal Gift."
items.title: Books, the ideal gift. Poster by Ethel Taylor, 1920-1930. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A map depicts colorfully outlined continents and features location arrows pinpointing locales featured in literary works. Illustrations of ships, airplanes, animals, and sea creatures are featured throughout.
items.title: Map of adventures for boys and girls : stories, trails, voyages, discoveries, explorations & places to read about. Map by Paul M. Paine, 1925. Geography & Map Division

items.alt: A man in glasses stands with his back against a building's wall with a sign that says "Office of Reports Free Press." He is reading a copy of the Manzanar Free Press. Behind him is another building, a group of men, and a sizeable snowcapped mountain.
items.title: Roy Takeno reading paper in front of office, Manzanar War Relocation Center, California. Photo by Ansel Adams, 1943. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A colorful poster for a magazine cover depicts a woman in a long floral dress lounging in a chair. She is reading a book while a cat sits on her lap. The top of the poster reads "For Sale Here," and below the image are the words "The Chap-book."
items.title: The Chap-book. Poster by J.C. Leyendecker, 1890s. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A bearded man in a striped hat and robe sits on a striped blanket with a small child who is similarly dressed. The man helps the child hold a book and rests his other hand on the child's head. They both appear to be reading.
items.title: Zaravshan okrug. First lessons. Photo, 1865-1872. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A red and green book cover depicts a child in a toga-like garment standing before a door with a hand on a door knocker. Two cranes and vases flank the upper part of the doorway. A mouse, frog, and blades of grass flank the lower doorway. The text reads "Baby's Own Aesop," and "Walter Crane."
items.title: The Baby's Own Aesop. Illustration by Walter Crane, 1887. Rare Book & Special Collections Division

items.alt: A bluish gray and white print depicts a seated woman in a flowing dress who is reading a book that she holds with one hand. A child in a billowy gown stands near her, holding a torch that provides her light to read.
items.title: Sibyl reading. Chiaroscuro woodcut by Ugo da Carpi, after Raphael, 1517 or 1518. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A large group of African American people of all ages stands next to one another in a long line. Each person is holding and reading a book. Behind the people is a large building with multiple windows and doors.
items.title: Freedman's Village, Alexandria, Virginia. Photo, 1862-1865. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A young girl in a light dress lies across a quilt-covered bed and reads a book she holds in her hands. Behind her, a framed photograph and a magazine illustration decorate the warped and peeling paper that covers the wooden wall of the room.
items.title: Southeast Missouri Farms. Child of sharecropper reading on bed in living room. Photo by Russell Lee, 1938. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: Two men in sunglasses, knitted caps, bright matching red  jackets, and ski boots kneel in the snow while reading a map. One of the men points to the map while the other man's arm rests on his shoulder. A snowcapped mountain peak is visible in the background.
items.title: Map reading while skiing the Haute Route. Photo by Toni Frissell, 1961. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A green and black poster depicts three children in hats and glasses riding in the basket of a striped hot air balloon. Each child is reading from a book they hold in their hands. The text on the balloon says, "I Like Books." Below the balloon's basket are clouds and a city skyline.
items.title: I Like Books. Poster by Children's Book Council, Leonard Kessler, 1962. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A man in Civil War era clothing sits in a wooden rolling chair and is flanked by three small children who are similarly dressed. Each of them holds a book or photo album in their hands.
items.title: "Learning is wealth. Wilson, Charley, Rebecca, and Rosa. Slaves from New Orleans." Photo by Charles Paxson, 1864. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A colorful illustration depicts the scarecrow, tinman, lion and Dorothy talking with the Good Witch. The printed caption says, "Bring me the golden cap."
items.title: The Wonderful Wizard of Oz -The Good Witch Grants Dorothy's Wish. Illustration by W. W. Denslow, 1899. Rare Book & Special Collections Division

items.alt: A colorful poster depicts a group of people of all ages riding in the tasseled basket of a hot air balloon. Everyone has a book, and the two adults lean out of the basket with their books in outstretched hands. The text on the balloon says, "Three cheers for books!" Below the basket, the additional text says, "Book Week November 10-16, 1963."
items.title: Three cheers for books. Book Week poster by Adrienne Adams, 1963. Prints & Photographs Division

items.alt: A colorful mural depicts two people outdoors reading books. A man leans with his leg up against a brick chimney, and a woman lies on her stomach in the grass. A fireplace and mantel with a clock are illustrated in the adjoining mural in the corner where two walls meet.
items.title: Great Depression-era mural in the World Food Prize Hall of Laureates Building, once the Des Moines, Iowa, Public Library. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2016. Prints & Photographs Division

children.title: Free to Use and Reuse: Reading--Books, Maps, and More

description:
These images document the role of railroads and subways in the history of transportation and primarily in the United States. Unless otherwise noted, the images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.
children.meta_description: These images document the role of railroads and subways in the history of transportation and primarily in the United States. Unless otherwise noted, the images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

items.alt: The Tom Thumb engine and an open air railroad car.
items.title: Peter Cooper's "Tom Thumb," 1829-30, Baltimore & Ohio Railroad

items.alt: Group of steam trains filled with passengers in front of station.
items.title: Lightning express trains leaving the junction, 1874

items.alt: An empty black Pullman car is parked on a track.
items.title: A vintage rail passenger car outside the Railroad Museum and Park in Moberly, Missouri, 2021

items.alt: Seven passenger and freight trains going across bridges and intersecting tracks.
items.title: Zig Zag Passenger and Freight Trains, 1885

items.alt: A man in a wheelchair rolls towards an open car door on the subway.
items.title: Washington, D.C., Metro subway access for handicapped individuals, 1977

items.alt: A steam locomotive rolls towards the viewer with army tanks on its freight cars.
items.title: Life-line of the nation, American railroads. World War II poster, 1942

items.alt: Two women and a man examine the coupling area of a rail car.
items.title: Women subway guards looking at a railway car on the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company line, New York City, 1917

items.alt: Several red train cars with a pine tree overhanging them.
items.title: Steam Train, Japan, 1872

items.alt: Two steam locomotives pulling a train through deep standing water
items.title: High Water, 1907

items.alt: Woman adheres the logo to the side of a silver railroad car.
items.title: Worker applies the Acela logo to Amtrak's new high-speed train, 1999

items.alt: Group of workers stand on flatcars atop a tall wood trestle bridge.
items.title: Trestle work - Promontory Point, Salt Lake Valley, 1869

items.alt: Map or rail routes, lists of stations, and scenic vignettes.
items.title: Very best line! Chicago, Milwaukee, and St. Paul Railway, 1874

items.alt: Old locomotive labeled "47" and "Canadian National Railways."
items.title: Weathered steam locomotive at the Steamtown National Historic Site, Scranton, Pennsylvania, 2008

items.alt: Train car appears above the street between two office buildings.
items.title: Seattle, Washington, monorail train, 2018

items.alt: Crowds watch while men work to clear the wreckage.
items.title: Wreck on the Illinois Central Railroad near Farmer City, Illinois, October 6, 1909 (Two trains met head-on as they rounded a sharp curve.)

items.alt: Two men face the viewer with hills behind them.
items.title: Two men posed on a railroad handcar, 1869

items.alt: A strip of photos show the tracks, the cars, and the platform with passengers.
items.title: Subway to Senate office buildings, 1998

items.alt: Men sit on two open-sided subway cars powered from a monorail above the cars.
items.title: Senate subway monorail, around 1910s

items.alt: Locomotive stopped at a crossing gate.
items.title: Greenfield Village railroad crossing and steam locomotive, 2003

items.alt: Locomotive rolls towards the viewer with mountains in the background.
items.title: North Coast Limited in the Montana Rockies. Poster, 1920s (Steam engine pulling cars through Bozeman Pass.)

items.alt: Passenger train car stopped while women approach with trays, filled with goods, balanced on their heads.
items.title: Typical Passenger Train of Costa Rica, 1904

items.alt: A man labeled "Hayseed Legislator" has laid out wood planks and logs to block a steam train labeled "New York City Reforms."
items.title: The Same Old Train Wrecker. Political cartoon, 1885

items.alt: Blue and silver locomotive waits at a railroad crossing.
items.title: An Amtrak passenger train makes a quick stop in Mendota, Illinois, 2020

items.alt: An airplane flies above a long train pulled by a steam locomotive train in rural landscape.
items.title: Giant conquerors of space and time: Pennsylvania Railroad. Poster, 1931 (Ford Tri-Motor airplane)

items.alt: Advertisement for steam passenger train with image of an older railroad train with two passenger cars styled after a stagecoach.
items.title: First Steam Railroad Passenger Train in America, 1870  (The Mohawk & Hudson Rail Road of the 1830s.)

items.alt: Red caboose between two other red cabooses.
items.title: The caboose track at the Chicago and North Western railroad's Proviso Yard, Chicago, Illinois, 1942

items.alt: Map showing railroad and other transportation connections throughout Alaska
items.title: The Alaska Line. Map, 1934

items.alt: People boarding the back of a train while two women hug each other on the platform.
items.title: Passengers boarding the California Limited of the Santa Fe Railroad, 1905

items.alt: Multi-car train stopped at a platform facing the viewer.
items.title: Subway train on an elevated track, around 1910

items.alt: Crowd of people stand on the concrete bridge with a steam locomotive railroad train on a higher bridge just behind them.
items.title: Red Jacket Concrete Bridge Dedication, 1911

items.alt: Illustration shows a locomotive labeled "Private Monopoly Special" racing down tracks labeled "Opportunity" while two trains labeled "Plain People Local" and "Legitimate Business" have been side-tracked, giving the monopoly the "right of way."
items.title: The right of way. Editorial cartoon, 1910

items.alt: Illustration shows a steam locomotive pulling several passenger cars towards the viewer.
items.title: The Express Train, 1870

items.alt: Silver passenger train rolls towards the viewer, with the Hudson River and hills on the right.
items.title: Highlands of the Hudson--New York Central System. Travel poster, 1940s

items.alt: Railroad routes throughout the United States bordered by scenic vignettes.
items.title: New map of the Union Pacific Railway and connections, 1883

items.alt: Steam locomotive with one freight car and one passenger car stopped on a high trestle bridge.
items.title: High bridge near Buena Vista, Colorado, 1880-1900

items.alt: Construction inside a subway station with decorative brick designs.
items.title: City Hall Subway Station in New York, 1900-1906

items.alt: View down twin tunnels underground.
items.title: LaSalle St. Tunnel, Chicago, Illinois, 1912

items.alt: A few passengers stand on the platform while a train arrives, blurred by its motion.
items.title: Subway train entering the Hollywood/Vine Metro subway station in the Hollywood section of Los Angeles, 2013

items.alt: Railroad train paused between a bush and trees.
items.title: Santa Fe train in Barstow, California. Infrared photo, 2012

items.alt: Locomotive painted gold and burgundy.
items.title: Napa Valley Wine Train, California, 2012

children.title: Free to Use and Reuse: Ride the Rails

description:
This set highlights the work of American scientists and inventors in many fields. Their careers represent many kinds of scientific investigations, primarily from the 1800s to 1900s. The images can encourage discussion about the history of science as an endeavor influenced by social conditions and political and financial aims. Unless otherwise noted, the images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.
children.meta_description: This set highlights the work of American scientists and inventors in many fields. Their careers represent many kinds of scientific investigations, primarily from the 1800s to 1900s. The images can encourage discussion about the history of science as an endeavor influenced by social conditions and political and financial aims. Unless otherwise noted, the images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

items.alt: A book open to two pages, with electrical equipment on the left and a title page of the book on the right.
items.title: Scientist and inventor Benjamin Franklin'sÂ  book "Experiments and observations on electricity." 1774

items.alt: Poster shows the magazine title above an illustration of an airship hovering above a bridge.
items.title: Scientific American magazine. Poster advertisement. 1905

items.alt: In an empty field, a man wearing a suit holds a bucket in one hand and a large clump of dirt in the other.
items.title: Agricultural research scientist George Washington Carver standing in a field, probably at Tuskegee. 1906

items.alt: Woman in a lab coat holding a tray of test tubes with her left hand and examining one test tube closely in her right hand.
items.title: Microbiologist Alice C. Evans working in her laboratory in Washington, D.C. 1928

items.alt: A man stands at a lab bench full of equipment by a large window.
items.title: A scientist studies a beeker containing adult stem-cell samples at the Gates Center for Regenerative Medicine at theÂ  University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Center. 2016

items.alt: A man works on the tail of a dinosaur skeleton.
items.title: Paleontologist Norman Ross preparing the skeleton of a baby dinosaur at the National Museum. 1921

items.alt: Illustration showing a white- gloved hand holding a test tube over yellow light.
items.title: Polio research: a light is beginning to dawn. Poster, 1949

items.alt: A judge shakes the hand of Albert Einstein while people watch in the background.
items.title: Physicist Albert Einstein receiving his American citizenship. 1940Â

items.alt: A statue of a woman sitting on a bench while looking at a notebook in her hand and holding a clipboard in her lap.
items.title: Mathematician and aerospace engineer Mary Jackson. This statute is at Hampton University in Virginia. 2019

items.alt: Group portrait of men standing and seated in a formal room talking with each other.
items.title: American scientists and inventors. 1862 (reprinted 1956)

items.alt: A man wearing a white coat presses a syringe into the neck of a horse.
items.title: Inoculating a horse with diphtheria bacteria to produce an antitoxin at the New York City Department of Health serum and vaccine farm, Otisville, New York. 1944

items.alt: Man in white coat sits behind equipment in a lab and looks up at the photographer.
items.title: Physicist Dr. Leo Esaki at IBM corporate headquarters lab in New York. 1975-1980

items.alt: Two astronauts in helmets and space suits float upside down inside a padded aircraft.Â
items.title: Project Mercury astronauts shown floating upside down in a weightless experimental flight. 1959

items.alt: Head-and-shoulders portrait of a woman wearing a lace cap and collar.
items.title: Inventor and teacher Nancy Maria Donaldson Johnson, who patented the first hand-crank mechanism for ice cream freezers. Around 1875

items.alt: A woman sits at a desk holding a pen and a page on top of a stack of papers.
items.title: AIDS researcher Dr. Mathilde Krim. 1987

items.alt: Notebook page with rough sketches of men speaking into cones connected by wires.
items.title: Telephone invention. Drawing by Alexander Graham Bell. 1876.

items.alt: Illustration features 7 men in various positions around a room with large tables and shelves filled with supplies.
items.title: Laboratory of inventor Thomas Edison, known for incandescent light bulb, phonograph, and movie camera. 1880

items.alt: A large group of men in suits stand outdoors on a set of stairs to pose for a portrait.
items.title: American Chemical Society members with Dr. Harvey Wiley. 1892-1899

items.alt: Large group portrait showing the faces of men and one woman in 10 rows of up to 19 small ovals.
items.title: Geological Society of America, all but 60 of their fellows. 1899

items.alt: A biplane lifts off from a rail in the sand, while a man looks on.
items.title: Aeronautical engineers Orville and Wilbur Wright at their first flight, Kitty Hawk, North Carolina. 1903

items.alt: Two men stand behind a radiator.
items.title: Inventor Charles S.L. Baker with his radiator system. 1906

items.alt: Four women pose behind a table with microscopes and small glass jars.
items.title: Women scientists (plant pathologists) at the US Department of Agriculture: Nellie A. Brown, Lucia McCollock, Mary K. Bryan, and Florence Hedges. 1910-1920

items.alt: Head-and-shoulders portrait of a woman facing the camera with a warm expression and wearing a dress with braided wrapped around her head.
items.title: Chemist Ellen Swallow Richards specialized in sanitary engineering and environmental science. 1915.

items.alt: Head-and-shoulders portrait of a woman facing front and wearing glasses and a dark blouse with a white collar.
items.title: Astronomer Anne Sewell Young. 1915-1920

items.alt: A woman stands in front of shelves containing chemicals while holding something with tongs above a large glass container.
items.title: Margaret D. Foster, "Uncle Sam's only woman chemist." 1919

items.alt: Sketched portrait of a man wearing glasses and a suit, seated.Â
items.title: Zoologist George R. Agassiz. 1915

items.alt: A woman uses a stethoscope on the chest of a woman wearing a cloak that covers her head.
items.title: "Dr. Sara Foulks, of Burlington, N.J., examining a tubercular Mohammedan woman." 1920

items.alt: Three man wearing suits standing in a laboratory.
items.title: Inventor Guglielmo Marconi in the General Electric Research Laboratory, New York. 1922

items.alt: A woman wearing a dress sits on a railing holding a bulb containing a plant.
items.title: "Miss Louise Thorne, of the National Academy of Sciences in Washington, holding a small living plant hermetically sealed in an old electric light bulb." 1923-1929

items.alt: Men standing on the roof of a building looking into telescopes pointed in the same direction at the sky.
items.title: Astronomers at Naval Observatory viewing eclipse of sun, Washington, D.C. 1925

items.alt: Two men standing in a greenhouse looking at corn cobs.
items.title: Genetics: Luther Burbank with Nobumi Hasegawa, visiting student from Japan, selecting corn for seed, Santa Rosa, California. 1925

items.alt: Five men in suits sit in chairs facing the camera, behind one microphone that says "Columbia."
items.title: Group of scientists from the Carnegie Institution for Science broadcast over CBS radio. 1930

items.alt: In an automotive factory, a man uses a stethoscope to listen to an engine.
items.title: "The Automotive Section of the Bureau of Standards is studying the anti-knock proportion of fuel used in automobile and aircraft engines." 1930

items.alt: One man stands holding a sheep's head still while another man kneels holding the sheep's mouth open to insert a long tool.
items.title: Doctoring a sick sheep. U.S. National Agricultural Research Center. 1935-1942

items.alt: Man sitting in a chair at a table holding a metal cast of an insect. Other insect models are on the table.
items.title: Entomologist making metal casts of insects. 1937

items.alt: A man sitting outside a barn holds a small tube of liquid and shows the amount measured by a caliper.
items.title: "Small farmers hire a scientist. Measuring the butter fat content in a sample of milk ...Â  Blackhawk County, Iowa." 1939

items.alt: Three men in suits, seated and in conversation.
items.title: Television inventor Philo Farnsworth (center) talking about his patents. 1939

items.alt: A seated woman wearing a lab coat looks into a microscope.
items.title: Laboratory technician, Provident Hospital, Chicago, Illinois. 1942

items.alt: A man standing in a greenhouse holds a pipette in one hand and a funnel in the other hand.
items.title: Botanist, Tuskegee Institute, Alabama. 1942

items.alt: A seated woman wearing a suit looks at a slide in her hand. A microscope, test tube, and cork particles are on the table.
items.title: "Forest Products Laboratory, Madison, Wisconsin: Miss Eloise Gerry conducting experiments on cork substitutes made from American woods." 1942

items.alt: A typed letter dated June 29, 1943, with the handwritten word "secret" at the top and "The White House Washington" printed at the top.Â
items.title: Letter from president Franklin D. Roosevelt to J. Robert Oppenheimer with thanks for the ongoing secret atomic research. First of two pages, 1943 (Manuscript Division)

items.alt: A man wearing a white lab coat holds a magnifying glass up to an apparatus in a lab.
items.title: Chemist Dr. C. K. Liang working at the National Institute of Health, Bethesda, Maryalnd. 1944

items.alt: A man holding aÂ  pen seated at a table with open books and files in front of him and full bookshelves behind him.
items.title: Chemist Gerald Edelman, Nobel Prize winner. 1970-1985

items.alt: Two men look at a white board covered in a diagram and words.
items.title: Physicist Dr. Walter Kato (right) at the Brookhaven simulator lab. 1979

items.alt: Statue of a man kneeling and smiling while holding binoculars in his right hand.
items.title: Zoologist Marlin Perkins. Statue in Carthage, Missouri. 2020

children.title: Free to Use and Reuse: Scientists & Inventors

description:
This set offers pictures about making, selling, wearing, shining, repairing, and also needing shoes. Search tip: It can be hard to find pictures of shoes, because they are often a small part of a picture. To bring interesting footwear to light, try using words that describe circumstances where feet are likely to appear in pictures, including dance, fashion, military, and full-length portraits.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

items.title: John Mundell & Co's solar tip shoes. Advertisement, Wells & Hope Co., 1889. Prints & Photographs Division
Tap dancing class in the gymnasium at Iowa State College. Ames, Iowa. Photo by Jack Delano, 1942. Prints & Photographs Division
Bob's Shoe Repair sign, Rapid City, South Dakota. Photo by John Margolies, 1987. Prints & Photographs Division
Shine 'em up, Flanders, ... Photo for American National Red Cross, 1920. Prints & Photographs Division
Lieutenant Wesley Herbert Jamison of 351st Machine Gun Battalion, World War I. Photo postcard, 1917 or 1918. Prints & Photographs Division
A few of the young workers in West End Shoe Factory, Lynchburg, (Va.). Photo by Lewis Hine, 1911. Prints & Photographs Division
Shoe factory, Lynn, Mass. Photo by Frances B. Johnston, 1895? Prints & Photographs Division
L. Candee & Co., Rubber Works, manufacturers of all kinds of rubber boots & shoes. New Haven, Conn. established 1842. Prints & Photographs Division
General view sewing room--large shoe factory, Syracuse, N.Y. Stereograph by Keystone View Co., 1916. Prints & Photographs Division
The defunct Johnson-Endicott shoe factory in West Endicott, New York. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2018. Prints & Photographs Division
Sanbashi no onna (Young woman wearing geta). Ukiyo-e print by Kuniyoshi Utagawa, 1844-1850. Prints & Photographs Division
The black knight. Ukiyo-e print by Masanobu Okumura, 1743. Prints & Photographs Division
New York, New York. Italian-American shoe repair man.  Photo by Marjory Collins, 1943. Prints & Photographs Division
Shoe house, Wacky Golf, Myrtle Beach, South Carolina. Photo by John Margolies, 1979. Prints & Photographs Division
Opera singer Beniamino Gigli (Wearing spats). Photo by Bain News Service, 1920-1925. Prints & Photographs Division
Lamas play horns at temple door, Sikkim. Photo by Alice Kandell, 1965-1971. Prints & Photographs Division
Group. (Myself with two others, Murman), Russian Empire. Photo by Sergei M. Prokudin-Gorskii, 1915. Prints & Photographs Division
Edward C. Gleed and two unidentified Tuskegee airmen, at air base at Ramitelli, Italy. Photo by Toni Frisssell, 1945. Prints & Photographs Division.
On snow shoes to the barren grounds ... Poster by Edward Penfield, 1895. Prints & Photographs Division
Baby with club feet wearing homemade splints inside shoes. Tulare County, California. Photo by Dorothea Lange, 1939. Prints & Photographs Division
Children in front of moving picture theater, Easter Sunday matinee, Black Belt, Chicago, Illinois. Photo by Edwin Rosskam, 1941. Prints & Photographs Division
Shoes. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1909-1914. Prints & Photographs Division
This is the Herbster shoe supply. A new pair of shoes a month is needed by the family. ... Photo by Office of Emergency Management, 1941. Prints & Photographs Division
Army, U.S. Old and new Army field service shoes. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1911-1917. Prints & Photographs Division
Shoe. Photo by Harris & Ewing, 1909-1914. Prints & Photographs Division
Stitching pattern on uppers of boots. Boot shop, Alpine, Texas. Photo by Russell Lee, 1939. Prints & Photographs Division
Leather which forms the heel is applied in layers and is filed down for accurate shaping. Boot shop, Alpine, Texas. Photo by Russell Lee, 1939. Prints & Photographs Division
One of 19 colorful giant boots, a signature of Cheyenne, Wyoming. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2015. Prints & Photographs Division
Fancy cowboy boots for sale at the San Antonio Stock Show and Rodeo in San Antonio, Texas. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2014. Prints & Photographs Division
Sign for Leddy handmade boots in San Angelo, the seat of Tom Green County, Texas. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2014. Prints & Photographs Division
"Hopi mending moccasins." Photo by Detroit Publishing Co., 1900-1915. Prints & Photographs Division
The Big Shoe, straight-on view, 10th & Chester, Bakersfield, California. Photo by John Margolies, 2003. Prints & Photographs Division
Spanish-American farmer repairing his wife's shoes. Chamisal, New Mexico. Photo by Russell Lee, 1940. Prints & Photographs Division
In the shoe repair shop. San Augustine, Texas. Photo by Russell Lee, 1939. Prints & Photographs Division
Where shoes are needed. Toes of a Budapest girl protuding through the holes in the remnants of a pair of shoes.... Photo by American National Red Cross, 1921. Prints & Photographs Division
Pa Pa 'as walked holes in his shoes. Cherry Blossom Festival, Washington, D.C. Photo by Martha M. Roberts, 1941. Prints & Photographs Division
Montgomery Ballet performs in Montgomery, Alabama. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2010. Prints & Photographs Division
Two little girls in a park near Union Station, Washington, D.C. Photograph, approx. 1943. Prints & Photographs Division.
Fashion model wearing tennis outfit. Photo by Toni Frissell, 1947. Prints & Photographs Division
Greel's Shoe-shining Parlor, Indianapolis, Ind. Photo by Lewis Hine, 1908. Prints & Photographs Division
Shoe-shine. Photo by Matson Photo Co., 1898-1947. Prints & Photographs Division
Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. A Greyhound driver getting his shoes shined by a porter at the garage. Photo by Esther Bubley, 1943. Prints & Photographs Division
Wife of fruit vendor having shoes shined at market in San Antonio, Texas. Photo by Russell Lee, 1939. Prints & Photographs Division
Fort Belvoir, Virginia. A regular part of Sergeant George Camblair's chores is shoe shining. Photo by Jack Delano, 1942. Prints & Photographs Division
Alexander Hamilton. Print after painting by T. Hamilton Crawford, 1932. Prints & Photographs Division
Unidentified boy in Union zouave uniform with drum (Civil War). Photograph, 1861-1865. Prints & Photographs Division
Babe Ruth (with baseball shoes). Photo by Irwin, La Broad, & Pudlin, 1920. Prints & Photographs Division
Washington, D.C. Moccasins are worn without socks at Woodrow Wilson High School. Photo by Esther Bubley, 1943. Prints & Photographs Division
Amb. Matsudaira with wife and daughters. Photo by National Photo Co., 1925. Prints & Photographs Division
Shoe hole, Mini-Golf at Splashdown Amusement Park, Rapid City, South Dakota. Photo by John Margolies, 1987. Prints & Photographs Division

description:
The term "skyscrapers" vividly represents the world of very tall buildings. This set offers images from the oldest acknowledged skyscraper--the 10-story Home Insurance Building in Chicagoâto the crowded skylines of the 21st century. You'll also see one of the tallest buildings in the United States--the Willis Tower in Chicago, built in 1974 with 108 floors, as well as diverse architectural styles.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.
children.meta_description: The term "skyscrapers" vividly represents the world of very tall buildings. This set offers images from the oldest acknowledged skyscraper--the 10-story Home Insurance Building in Chicagoâto the crowded skylines of the 21st century. You'll also see one of the tallest buildings in the United States--the Willis Tower in Chicago, built in 1974 with 108 floors, as well as diverse architectural styles.

items.alt: Photo shows several skyscrapers with the Chrysler Building's pointed crown and spire in the background.
items.title: Chrysler Building (1930) and other skyscrapers, New York City. Photo by Irving Underhill, 1930.

items.alt: Photo shows two pigeons sitting on a ledge in the foreground flanking the distinctive crown and spire of Manhattan's Chrysler Building in the distant background.
items.title: Two pigeons on ledge with spire of the Chrysler Building (1930) in background. Photo by Angelo Rizzuto, 1957.

items.alt: Color print shows a red brick and gray stone building located on a street corner with horse-drawn vehicles and pedestrians in the street.
items.title: Described as the world's first skyscraper due to its structural steel frame, the Home Insurance Building was completed in Chicago in 1885. Lithograph by L. Prang & Co., 1885.

items.alt: Still image from a film shows several men wearing hats while suspended from a cable hanging high above city streets with buildings in the background.
items.title: "The skyscrapers of New York." An 11-minute film drama by the American Mutoscope and Biograph Company, 1906. (National Audiovisual Conservation Center)

items.alt: Color photo shows One Detroit Center in the middle as well as several nearby skyscrapers. A U.S. flag is flying from the top of one with water in the background.
items.title: One Detroit Center, Guardian Building, Detroit, Michigan. Photo by Balthazar Korab, 2007. (Opened in 1993, now the Ally Detroit Center)

items.alt: Black-and-white photo shows three girls playing with dolls and a woman standing under a metal structure on the roof of a skyscraper. Clothes hang on a clothesline behind them.
items.title: "Living on a skyscraper," New York City. Photo by Bain News Service, about 1919.

items.alt: Color photo shows a busy city street with people, trolleys, and horse-drawn wagons. A domed tower skyscraper with a pale stone exterior looms large on one side of the street, and smaller buildings line both sides of the street, including one with a green advertisement billboard that reads "Eagleson's shirts."
items.title: Market Street, San Francisco, with the Call Building (completed in 1897). Photochrom print by Detroit Publishing Co., 1900.

items.alt: Photo shows a man wearing a dark top hat and coat standing among rubble and burned out buildings in foreground with steel frame in background.
items.title: "Unfinished steel structure intact after quake, San Francisco." Photograph by George R. Lawrence, 1906.

items.alt: Pair of almost identical, side-by-side photos shows three men, two sitting and one standing, on an iron beam suspended in air high above the ground.
items.title: "Sailors on land--agile construction men on a suspended iron section, 200 ft. above ground, New York City." Stereograph by H.C. White, 1907.

items.alt: Detailed architectural rendering of the front exterior of a many-storied skyscraper, with a floor plan at the bottom.
items.title: Skyscraper office building. Drawing by architect Henry Wilbur Adams, 1927 or 1928. (Never built)

items.alt: Color photo shows a rectangular skyscraper higher than any other in a bird's-eye view of downtown Philadelphia. The building's glass screen reflects other buildings and white clouds in the sky.
items.title: Comcast Center,  Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, has a distinctive cutout feature near its top. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2019.  (Opened 2008)

items.alt: Architectural drawing shows both the South Elevation and the East Elevation from the ground floor to the roof of a tower-like building.
items.title: The 1891 Pontiac Building, Chicago, Illinois. Measured drawing by the Historic American Buildings Survey, 1967.

items.alt: Photo shows the building's top corner with various geometric shapes that create a complex pattern surrounding several arched windows and five carved male heads above the windows.
items.title: Top story detail of the Schiller Theater Building,  Chicago, Illinois. Photo by Richard Nickel, 1961. (Opened in 1892 and shown shortly before it was razed.)

items.alt: Photo of a skyscraper in the foreground that stands high above city streets below with a mountain in the background.
items.title: L.C. Smith Building (Pioneer Building), Seattle, Washington. Photo by Curtis & Miller, 1914. (Completed in 1892)

items.alt: Photo shows buildings on both sides of the street with trolley cars on it. Caption identifies the Lester Bookstore at left, the tall triangular Flatiron Building in the center with rounded corners, and the Candler Building on the right.
items.title: Lower Peachtree Street, Atlanta, Georgia. Photo by the Albertype Company, early 1900s.

items.alt: Color postcard shows a night view of a tall, triangular-shaped building with a light in each window and a beacon light shining out from its highest point into the city below. Fireworks appear in the sky and people crowd the surrounding city streets.
items.title: "Election night illumination, Flatiron Building," New York City. Postcard copyrighted by William Randolph Hearst, 1904. (Building completed in 1902)

items.alt: Illustration shows a massive office building structure surrounding all but the front side of a church that looks small in comparison. Large groups of people enter the office and no one is at the church.
items.title: "The Future of Trinity Church," New York City. Cartoon illustration by Albert Levering, published in Puck, March 6, 1907. (This Gothic Revival style church was completed in the mid-1800s and was for a time the tallest building in the United States.)

items.alt: Postcard shows one side of a city block with the full height of four buildings. The tallest building is labeled "W.S.H." on its front and "Woman Suffrage Headquarters" on its side.
items.title: "Votes for Women." National American Woman Suffrage Association headquarters, 17th floor of 505 Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street, New York City. Postcard, 1909.

items.alt: Black-and-white print resembling a sketch shows an active construction site at night with large structural supports and men, horses, and wagons at work. A fence surrounds the site with pedestrians walking by, and a few stopping to watch the construction from the sidewalk.
items.title: "The Foundations--Building a Skyscraper." Lithograph by Joseph Pennell, 1910.

items.alt: Color postcard illustration shows a tower-like building illuminated by electric lights and a cloudy night sky with a full moon. A domed building across the street is also lit up with people, cars, and buses on the streets. Light shines from most windows.
items.title: Electric Building at Night, Buffalo, N.Y. Postcard, about 1920.  (General Electric Tower, built in 1912)

items.alt: Black-and-white print resembling a sketch shows low buildings in the foreground leading to skyscrapers in the background.
items.title: Skyscrapers from the Gladstone, with City Hall in the background, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Lithograph by Joseph Pennell, 1912.

items.alt: Image shows eight early New York City skyscrapers, each labeled with the building's name and key details.
items.title: "City's first skyscraper now being razed." The Sun (New York, N.Y.), January 4, 1914.

items.alt: Photo shows the head, chest, and arm of a man wearing glasses with a mustache and holding a model of a building that reaches slightly above his head.
items.title: The 1913 Woolworth Building, New York, New York. This sculpture of architect Cass Gilbert holding a model of the skyscraper is in the lobby. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2009.

items.alt: Aerial photo shows only the top of the skyscraper surrounded by many clouds.
items.title: Woolworth tower in clouds, New York City. Photo by Fairchild Aerial Surveys, 1928.

items.alt: Photo of a 15-story building made of a light stone with lots of windows. A taller structure looms behind it, and a few pedestrians and cars are on the surrounding city streets.
items.title: The 1913 Palmetto Building, 1400 Main Street at Washington Street, Columbia, South Carolina. Photo by Jack Boucher, 1986.

items.alt: Photo shows a building with large ground-level windows, a wide black awning, and an old-fashioned clock that extends out over the city sidewalk.
items.title: Entrance to the 1919 Mid-Continent Tower, one of the most recognizable skyscrapers in Tulsa, Oklahoma, with its white terracotta facade. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2020.

items.alt: Architectural drawing with color sketches of decorative elements for the building's interior using square-like patterns.
items.title: Proposed decorations for Fisher Building, Detroit. Soffit of stair no. 2 and elevator lobbies 202 & 302. Design drawing by Winold Reiss, about 1928.

items.alt: Color photo shows three skyscrapers with the gold-topped Trust Company in the center and excavation sites in the foreground.
items.title: The 1929 Baltimore Trust Company Building, Baltimore, Maryland. Photo by James W. Rosenthal, 2001. (At left is the First National Bank Building, completed 1924. At right is the Schaefer Tower, completed 1986)

items.alt: Photo of a distant, illuminated skyscraper shaped like a tower and fireworks  in the sky above it.
items.title: Foshay Tower dedication fireworks as seen from the parade, more than a mile away, Minneapolis, Minnesota. Photo by Verne V. Gunsolley, 1929.

items.alt: Photo shows the Empire State Building lit up at night and looming above the city. Other Manhattan buildings and a city street with vehicular traffic are illuminated in the background.
items.title: Bird's-eye view of the 1931 Empire State Building at night. Photo by Angelo Rizzuto, 1953.

items.alt: Photo shows a man standing in front of a towering skyscraper and pointing a camera up toward its highest floor.
items.title: "The big one." Photo by Angelo Rizzuto, 1959. (The 1931 Empire State Building, New York City)

items.alt: Color photo shows a painting on glass of the Empire State Building in various shades of blue similar to the shades of blue in the sky above it. Many smaller, multi-colored buildings and a yellow horizon surround the skyscraper.
items.title: Painted glass located in the lobby of the 1931 Empire State Building, New York, New York. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, between 1980 and 2006.

items.alt: Color illustration shows a man carrying items on his back as he approaches a city where enormous skyscrapers tilt at angles in the background and overwhelm a residential area with an elevated railroad and clothesline skyscrapers.
items.title: "Sol Lesser presents 'City of Contrasts.'" Movie poster by Plampin Litho, 1931.

items.alt: Color photo shows men and women, nearly all wearing hats, standing on the high roof of a skyscraper and looking out at the city below on a sunny day. One woman is using a large observation telescope in the foreground.
items.title: "Rockefeller Center, New York City. The observation roofs are in reality commodious promenades overlooking the vast city from a height of 850 feet." Mophochrom by Irving Browning, about 1935.  (Built 1930-1939)

items.alt: Pair of almost identical, side-by-side photos show a single tall building surrounded by lower  buildings. In the foreground are a parking lot with cars and trees.
items.title: "The skyscraper section of Birmingham, Alabama." Stereograph by the Keystone View Company, 1935.

items.alt: Color photo shows a lone skyscraper surrounded by a tree and low buildings along an empty road.
items.title: Price Tower, Bartlesville, Oklahoma, built in 1956. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, between 1980 and 2006.

items.alt: Color photo shows the entrance to an enormous concrete building featuring vertical lines, flared black columns, and a wide staircase.
items.title: Base of the brutalist-style 30-story Xerox Tower building in Rochester, New York. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2018.  (Completed in 1967)

items.alt: Photo shows an enormous skyscraper with large X braces looming in the background with a castle-like structure in the foreground.
items.title: John Hancock Center, Chicago, Illinois. Photo by Hedrich-Blessing, 1969. (Skyscraper completed in 1969 with Chicago Water Tower in foreground)

items.alt: Photo shows a group of people standing inside a glass elevator that extends beyond a high floor of a skyscraper's reflective exterior. The view shows many city blocks in the distance and a blue sky with clouds.
items.title: A glass observation deck attached to the outside of the 100-story 875 North Michigan Avenue Building (John Hancock Center), in Chicago, Illinois. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2017.

items.alt: Color photo shows the full length of the twin tower buildings of the World Trade Center as seen from the river.
items.title: World Trade Center, New York, New York. Exterior. Twilight view from harbor. Photo by Balthazar Korab, 1976. (Opened 1973)

items.alt: Photo of Houston, Texas, skyline on a cloudy day with a field in the foreground.
items.title: Houston, Texas. Skyline with skyscrapers and the Large Spindle Piece sculpture in foreground. Photo by Balthazar Korab Studios, 1987.

items.alt: Color photo shows a big blue tower that is reflecting large white clouds in the surrounding sky. Smaller buildings and cars parked along a street are in the foreground.
items.title: The 31-story Lexington Financial Center, known as the "Big Blue Building" in Lexington, Kentucky. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2020. (Completed in 1987)

items.alt: Color photo shows skyscrapers with lights that outline their shapes. White lights outline the sphere.
items.title: Dusk view of the skyline, Dallas, Texas, with the lighted sphere on Reunion Tower and many skyscrapers. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, about 1990.

items.alt: Color photo shows the skyline with skyscrapers and other tall structures and a blue sky. In the foreground the renovated brick powerhouse has a large parking lot with cars.
items.title: Flats District of Cleveland, Ohio, with several skyscrapers in the background--Key Tower, 200 Public Square, and Terminal Towerâand The Powerhouse in the foreground. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 1990s.

items.alt: Color photo shows high-rise buildings with palm trees and people on a sandy beach in the foreground.
items.title: Hotels and other high-rise buildings on Waikiki Beach, Honolulu, Hawaii. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, between 1980 and 2006.

items.alt: Photo shows the city skyline rising up in between trees and water in the foreground and mountains in the background. A low white building with a red roof also appears in the foreground.
items.title: Skyline, Denver, Colorado. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, between 1980 and 2006.

items.alt: Photo shows the Chicago skyline at night with colored lights from the largest skyscraper and others reflected in the lake water in the foreground.
items.title: Skyline at dusk along Lake Michigan, dominated by the Willis Tower (Sears Tower), Chicago, Illinois. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, between 1980 and 2006.

items.alt: Color photo looks up at the lighted pyramidal crown of the skyscraper shown against a night sky.  The glass curtain walls show interior lights on various floors and the reflection of a nearby building.
items.title: The upper reaches of Frost Bank Tower, completed 2003, Austin, Texas, skyscraper. Photograph by Carol M. Highsmith, 2014.

items.alt: Photo of downtown Los Angeles buildings, including the tall tower of City Hall, with mountains in the background.
items.title: Skyline view of Los Angeles, California, centering on the 1928 City Hall building. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2013.

items.alt: Color photo shows many of the tall buildings in Boston with the John Hancock Tower rising above others in the center and residential areas on the right and in the distance.
items.title: Aerial view of Boston, Massachusetts, with a focus on one of its iconic skyscrapers: the (shiny blue) John Hancock Tower, completed in 1976. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2019.

items.alt: Photo shows a city street with parked cars and a palm tree in the foreground and several skyscrapers in the background.
items.title: A view of downtown Miami, Florida, skyscrapers from the Overtown District. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2020.

children.title: Free to Use and Reuse: Skyscrapers

description:
This set features "Liberty Enlightening the World," more often called the Statue of Liberty. From the early fundraising and construction years to the dedication in 1886 and the present day, this symbol of freedom has captured the public imagination. Unless otherwise noted, the images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.
children.meta_description: This set features "Liberty Enlightening the World," more often called the Statue of Liberty. From the early fundraising and construction years to the dedication in 1886 and the present day, this symbol of freedom has captured the public imagination. Unless otherwise noted, the images are from the Prints & Photographs Division.

items.alt: People stand on the torch held in the disembodied hand of the Statue of Liberty. Another group stands on the ground near an adjoining booth.
items.title: Colossal hand and torch "Liberty" displayed to raise construction funds at the Centennial Exposition in Philadelphia. Stereograph by the Centennial Photographic Co., 1876.

items.alt: Colorful frontal view of the Statue of Liberty rising above an island in New York Harbor.
items.title: Statue of Liberty, New York harbor. Photo by Detroit Publishing Co., 1905.

items.alt: The Statue of Liberty stands atop its pedestal in a scale drawing of the statue from the front.
items.title: South Pedestal Elevation - Statue of Liberty, Liberty Island, New York City. Drawing by Dana Lockett, 2011.

items.alt: Closeup view of the Statue of Libertyâs hand holding the torch as seen through the spikes of the statueâs crown.
items.title: Torch and hand of the Statue of Liberty. Photo by Angelo Rizzuto, 1952.

items.alt: Colorful view of the Statue of Liberty from the torso up, shot from below.
items.title: Statue of Liberty, New York, New York. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, around 2000.

items.alt: The Statue of Liberty is in ruins and New York City is aflame in a colorful illustration from World War I.
items.title: Lest Liberty Perish from the Face of the Earth - Buy Bonds. Drawing for a World War I poster by Joseph Pennell, 1918

items.alt: The Statue of Liberty rendered as a human intently stares at the viewer of the poster while pointing her finger in a colorful illustration.
items.title: You. Buy a Liberty Bond Lest I Perish. World War I poster by C.R. Macauley, 1917.

items.alt: Close-up view of the stylized flame atop the Statue of Libertyâs torch with skyscrapers visible in the background as if they are above the flame.
items.title: Detail of flame with Manhattan skyline in background-Statue of Liberty, Liberty Island, New York City. Photo by Jet Lowe, 1985.

items.alt: Spotlights point up at the Statue of Liberty, whose torch is illuminated and whose pedestal is strung with lights.
items.title: Statue of Liberty, New York, illuminated at night. Photo by A. Loeffler, 1909.

items.alt: A rudimentary replica of the Statue of Liberty is positioned over one of the putting areas at a miniature golf course.
items.title: Valleybrook Mini Golf, Statue of Liberty, Route 202, Chadds Ford, Pennsylvania. Photo by John Margolies, 1984.

items.alt: The crowned head of the Statue of Liberty is displayed near trees and benches in Parisâs Champ-de-Mars park.
items.title: Head of the Statue of Liberty on display at Champ-de-Mars, Exposition Universelle, Paris, 1878. Photograph published in 1883.

items.alt: A group of men is assembled around the wood slats forming the unfinished arm of a plaster model of the Statue of Liberty.
items.title: Construction of the skeleton and plaster surface of the left arm and hand of the Statue of Liberty, at the Gaget, Gauthier & Co. workshop in Paris. Photo by Pierre Petit, 1881-83.

items.alt: Scaffolding and construction equipment surround the body of the Statue of Liberty. The statueâs head, arm and torch rest on the ground nearby.
items.title: Assemblage of the Statue of Liberty in Paris, showing the bottom half of the statue erect under scaffolding, the head and torch at its feet, at the Gaget, Gauthier & Co. workshop in Paris, 1881-1883. Photo by Albert Fernique, 1883.

items.alt: The Statue of Liberty wears a long sash that reads "Wilson for Suffrage" in a cartoon-style illustration.
items.title: The New Freedom. Suffrage caricature published in Puck, 1915.

items.alt: The Statue of Liberty stands in shadow as beams of light emanate from her torch in a color illustration. A boat with a spotlight is visible in the water below.
items.title: For Liberty's Sake, Enlist in the Navy. World War I poster by Smith & Porter Press, 1917.

items.alt: A shadowed Statue of Liberty can be seen on the horizon of a body of water in a color illustration.
items.title: Pour la libertÃ© du monde. French World War I poster by Sem, 1917.

items.alt: A large group of military members stands assembled in a pattern formation that, from the air, replicates the Statue of Liberty.
items.title: Human Statue of Liberty; 18,000 officers and men at Camp Dodge, Des Moines, Iowa. Formation photo by Moles & Thomas, 1918.

items.alt: A beam of light passes behind the Statue of Liberty in a colorful illustration. Harbor boats and the New York City skyline are in the distance.
items.title: New York, the Wonder City of the World. Travel by train. Poster by Adolph Treidler, 1927.

items.alt: The feet of the Statue of Liberty are surrounded by scaffolding in a colorful view from above.
items.title: Detail looking down on left foot, Statue of Liberty, New York City. Photo by Jet Lowe, 1984.

items.alt: People stand on a spiral staircase surrounded by support beams inside the Statue of Liberty.
items.title: Detail view of double helical staircase with engineers evaluating a prospective railing design. Statue of Liberty, New York, NY. Photo by Jet Lowe, 2009.

items.alt: The spiral staircase and the crown viewing platform within the interior of the Statue of Liberty are visible in a cross-section drawing.
items.title: Statue of Liberty, New York, NY . Drawing by Corey Edwards, 2011.

items.alt: The Statue of Liberty stands above Liberty Island, with with buildings in the far distance.
items.title: Statue of Liberty, officially "Liberty Enlightening the World," with (from left to right) New Jersey, Ellis Island, and Manhattan. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 1990s.

items.alt: Harbor cruise boats surround a dock off Liberty Island. The Statue of Liberty rises from her pedestal at the islandâs opposite end.
items.title: The Statue of Liberty on Liberty Island, New Jersey, with Ellis Island and the Manhattan skyline in the distance. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2017.

items.alt: The Statue of Liberty rises from its pedestal on Liberty Island with tall city buildings visible in the background.
items.title: The Statue of Liberty on Liberty Island, New Jersey, with Ellis Island, Jersey City, and Manhattan skyline in the background. Photo by Carol M. Highsmith, 2017.

items.alt: An overhead view of the layout of Liberty Island is visible in a detailed site plan.
items.title: Liberty Island Site Plan - Statue of Liberty, New York, NY. Technical drawing by Ananta Patel, 2011.

description:
This set illustrates the wide variety of school, home, and informal learning environments that brought teachers and students together from kindergarten through college and adult continuing education, primarily in the 20th century. The pictures are from the Prints & Photographs Division collections unless otherwise noted.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.
children.meta_description: This set illustrates the wide variety of school, home, and informal learning environments that brought teachers and students together from kindergarten through college and adult continuing education, primarily in the 20th century. The pictures are from the Prints & Photographs Division collections unless otherwise noted.

items.alt: A group of seven smiling boys and girls stand in front of the American flag.
items.title: Deaf children of St. Rita's School, Cincinnati, OH, singing the Star Spangled Banner in sign language. Photo by J.R. Schmidt, 1918

items.alt: A female  teacher stands over one of three children studying at desks in a wood-slatted room.
items.title: One-room school, Ojo Sarco, New Mexico. Photo by John Collier, Jr,. 1943.

items.alt: An African American woman  points at the number 7 in a home-made number and alphabet chart while two young children sit in chairs facing the chart.
items.title: Mother teaching children in home of sharecropper, Transylvania, Louisiana. Photo by Rusell Lee,   1939

items.alt: A male teacher in a t-shirt stands in front of a chalkboard illustrated with music notes and points towards adult students sitting in chairs.
items.title: Johnny Colon School of Music, New York City. Photo by Jefferson Miller, 1982.

items.alt: Captioned newspaper page with two group portraits--a large group of children (above) and a small group of adults (below).
items.title: Faculty and students at the Seba Dalkai School, Arizona, 1955. Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers

items.alt: A female teacher stands in front of a blank blackboard while holding envelopes and gesturing with her hand. Two young men look at a book off to the side.
items.title: Adult ESL (English as Second Language) class, Khmer Village, Houston, Texas. Photo by Frank Proschan, 1982. American Folklife Center

items.alt: A man in a suit holds up his baton while a group of mostly children crowds together behind him. All are facing the camera.
items.title: High school teacher leading band at Decoration Day Ceremony, Gallipolis, Ohio. Photo by Arthur Siegel, 1943.

items.alt: A female teacher stands at the front of a room next to a chalkboard filled with writing and looks towards a group of young children sitting at desks.
items.title: Integration in D.C. schools. Photo by Warren Leffler, 1964.

items.alt: A casually-dressed woman cuts fabric with scissors while a girl in a vest looks on beside her. A sewing machine sits off to one side.
items.title: 4-H sewing class, Paradise Valley, Nevada. Photo by Carl Fleischhauer, 1978. American Folklife Center

items.alt: A woman stands near a desk surrounded by children, some of whom hold books. Shelves with books line the walls behind them.
items.title: Elmer Avenue Elementary School library, Schenectady, New York. Photo by Philip Bonn, 1943.

items.alt: A group of young girls and boys are playing in a room with a piano and large open windows. Several children have crutches or wear leg braces; others are in a wheel chair, bed, and sling chair.
items.title: Hodge Open Air School, Cleveland, Ohio. Unattributed photo, 1900-1920

items.alt: A man in a suit jacket and tie smiles while standing in a hallway with young people passing by around him.
items.title: Scott County High School principal Gregory Figgs, Georgetown, Kentucky. Photo by Scott J. Ferrell, 1998.

items.alt: A female teacher in a head covering leans towards a boy at a desk to show him the open pages of a  book. Other children are also in the classroom. A long chalkboard lines the wall behind the teacher.
items.title: Islamic School of Seattle, Washington. Photo by Susan Dwyer-Schick, 1982. American Folklife Center

items.alt: A female teacher stands next to a boy at a chalkboard covered with Korean characters. The boy holds a piece of chalk against the board and looks toward the teacher.
items.title: First Korean School, Silver Spring, Maryland. Photo by Carl Fleischhauer, 1982. American Folklife Center

items.alt: A nun  stands in front of children seated at desks. Some children raise their hands. A large chalkboard covers the back wall.
items.title: St. Peter's School, Washington, D.C. Photo by Warren Leffler, 1969.

items.alt: A man in a suit stands on a platform and points towards a large group of mostly children sitting on long benches.
items.title: Zion School, Charleston, South Carolina. Wood engraved illustration from a sketch by Alfred R. Waud, 1866.

items.alt: Portrait photo of a woman wearing ornate clothing and an intricate hairstyle.
items.title: Emma V. Brown, teacher at the first government funded school for African American children in Washington, D.C. Photo by M.P. and A.I. Rice, between 1874 and 1876.

items.alt: Several male students and one female student are working at countertops with elevated shelves filled with glass bottles and tubes. A male teacher stands at the side.
items.title: Chemistry lab, Central High School, Washington, D.C. Photo by Frances Benjamin Johnston, around 1899.

items.alt: A group of well-dressed African American women and children stand in a line looking up at a mural. Archways and murals are visible above them.
items.title: A visit to the Library of Congress. Photo by Frances Benjamin Johnston, around 1899.

items.alt: Eight girls are posed in basketball positions as one girl aims the ball towards the basket. They wear belted, knee-length outfits and stockings.
items.title: Female students playing basketball, Western High School, Washington, DC. Photo by Frances Benjamin Johnston, 1899

items.alt: A male teacher in a suit stands behind a globe while young adults sit on stools with maps and stereo photos out on their wooden tables. Maps hang on a back wall.
items.title: Physiography lesson by the Underwood Stereograph System, high school, Plainfield, N.J. Stereograph card photo by Underwood, 1900-1910.

items.alt: Five African American women sit on the front steps of a house with large windows and an open porch.
items.title: Nannie Helen Burroughs and others at the National Training School, Washington, D.C. About 1909.

items.alt: A group of smiling children look at their  female teacher in a blouse and long skirt who stands with her back to the camera. The children hold papers in their hands. The mill is in the background.
items.title: Cotton mill kindergarten, Dallas, Texas. Photo by Lewis Wickes Hine, 1913.

items.alt: A group of children sit indoors reading and writing around a table and at wooden crates. A male teacher in a suit stands reading a book in the back of the scene.
items.title: Textile mill school, Huntsville, Alabama. Photo by Lewis Wickes Hine, 1913.

items.alt: A long panoramic view photo shows a very large group of people posed on a grass field. Several college buildings are in the background.
items.title: The North Texas State Teacher's College, Denton, Texas, Summer school of 1928, 3100 enrollment. Photo by Charles E. Carruth.

items.alt: A female teacher leans over to check the paper of a girl seated at a desk. Other children sit at desks behind them.
items.title: Grade school, San Augustine, Texas. Photo by Russell Lee, 1939.

items.alt: A male teacher in a shirt and vest points to Mexico on a map of North America. A chalkboard filled with numbers is to his left.
items.title: School teacher in grade school teaching geography. Concho, Arizona. Photo by Russell Lee, 1940.

items.alt: A female teacher in a long coat kneels while adjusting the clothing of a small child. Other children and playground equipment are visible in the background.
items.title: Children and their teacher at the FSA (Farm Security Administration) farm family migratory labor camp. Yakima, Washington. Photo by Russell Lee, 1941.

items.alt: Seven teenagers are running in and out between posts in a dirt track.
items.title: Benjamin Franklin High School, New York, New York. High school boys growing physically fit through exercise. Photo by William Perlitch, 1942

items.alt: An African American male teacher stands watching a group of African American men and women painting at a table. Paintings hang from a board on the back wall.
items.title: Painting class at the South Side Community Art Center, Chicago, Illinois. Photo by Jack Delano, 1942.

items.alt: Three people sit at a long table covered with paper binders and a lantern slide projector. One of them, a uniformed woman, reads a book. Three other people tare in the background.
items.title: Mrs. Mary Spangler, a Woodrow Wilson High School teacher, at a class in organic chemistry which she attends in the evening. Photo by Esther Bubley, 1943.

items.alt: A Japanese American female teacher holds a measuring tape near small scale evening gowns while a group of young women watch her carefully. Their work  table is covered with fabric and spools of thread.
items.title: Fashion designing class, Manzanar Relocation Center, California. Photograph by Ansel Adams, around 1943.

items.alt: An African American woman sits in a leather chair at a large wooden desk. Portraits hang on the walls and shelves and file boxes are visible behind her.
items.title: Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune, Bethune-Cookman College. Photo by Gordon Parks, 1943.

items.alt: Two African American women wearing coats stand talking to each other. A college building is behind them.
items.title: Two teachers having a conversation, Bethune-Cookman College, Daytona Beach, Florida. Photo by Gordon Parks, 1943.

items.alt: Female teachers sits between two male teachers at paper-filled desks with book shelves behind them.
items.title: Miss Mae Kelly, director of instruction, with teachers at Randolph Henry High School, Keysville, Virginia. Photo by Philip Bonn, 1943.

description:
The sport of tennis dates back to the 12th century though the version we play today celebrates its roots in lawn tennis starting in late 19th century and quickly spread across the globe. This selection of rights-free pictures can be used to examine the equipment, courts, athletes and recreational players through the years.

Browse moreÂ content that is free to use and reuse.

description:
This Free to Use set focuses on American veterans throughout history and features photos, sheet music, letters, films and more from the Library's collections. Are you a veteran?

Do you know a veteran? Participate in the Veterans History Project. The Library's Veterans History Project collects, preserves and makes accessible the personal accounts of American war veterans so that future generations may hear directly from veterans and better understand the realities of war.

Browse more content that is free to use and reuse.
